I kept noticing that whenever I needed to check e-mail or Facebook, it was more convenient to put away the Kindle and to get out my iPhone than it was to deal with the Kindle apps.I think I was most disappointed to learn that the Kindle Fire cannot play digital copies of movies that I've purchased on Blu-Ray. I had bought extra storage in the Amazon Cloud, expecting to upload several of my movies to access whenever I desired to. But despite trying a variety of video player apps, I had to give up. Frankly, as you cannot play the common types of movie files that would necessitate larger cloud storage, despite a great job of integrating Kindle Fire with the Amazon Cloud, this renders the service much less useful than it would be otherwise.To summarize:Amazon has done an outstanding job on the Kindle Fire HD in terms of its hardware, its physical design, and its integration with Amazon. If what you are wanting is a device specifically for viewing Amazon video content, Kindle books, and playing games, this is an awesome purchase.I wanted a device for those reasons, but I also really wanted it for a bit of other productivity purposes, such as e-mail, internet, Facebook, etc. Unfortunately, as of the time of my review, the software for other basic uses is just too buggy. I was disappointed to see just how low of a priority it is for many developers to make apps for Android type devices. It wasn't that I couldn't get most of the types of apps I wanted; it was that the quality of apps developed is just so far lagging behind what I can get on my Apple devices.So in the end, I sincerely hope that in the upcoming months, Amazon will be successful in getting the bugs out of a lot of the software for the Kindle Fire HD. But for now, I just couldn't justify spending close to $500 for a device (after purchasing the 32GB 8.9" with extended warranty) that was so unreliable for e-mail, Facebook, Skype, and other apps. If you already have a tablet for productivity, and just need another tablet to keep you and your family from fighting over who gets to play a game or watch a movie, this makes a great second tablet.Incidentally, I did NOT go out and buy an iPad, and am planning to hold out for a few more months to see how things progress. Amazon has an amazing piece of hardware, but the software leaves a lot to be desired. I'll continue to root for them. If the software were as good as the hardware, this would be the best item on the market.

Reviews.Title: Hate then Loved
Reviews.Author: Keith Hamilton
Reviews.Content: I was concerned with my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 because the WiFi was loading all internet content slow. After retuning the first Kindle 8.9 then the replacement kindles 8.9 was acting the same as the initial, so I drove to the nearest Lowe's center to use their free WiFi.  Rightly, Kindle worked like a charm, so I knew it had something to do with my home network.  I have a smart-TV and Roku system, and the original Kindle Fire that worked well with my network so it came as a surprise that the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 was having slow connection problems.I fixed the problem by going online and changing a setting on my netgear wireless router. I had wpa-psk [tkip] + wpa2-psk [aes] as my wireless setting. By changing the setting to wpa2-psk [aes] I started to experience the WiFi speeds that I was accustomed to.So I must say now that Fire HD 8.9 is a wonderful tablet, and I highly recommend this product.

Reviews.Title: A very good option (for some)
Reviews.Author: Scott Edison "se"
Reviews.Content: First of all, I will admit that I am biased. I'm a loyal Amazon customer and have been for years. I use Amazon Prime and the benefits that filter down to the Fire family of products pretty much makes the Fire HD a no-brainer.Other reviewers have provided thorough accounts of the good and bad aspects of the hardware, software etc.I'm going to keep this short and sweet.Who should buy the Kindle Fire HD 8.9?-Amazon enthusiasts. Do you already buy books, movies, music, spoken word audio, or have a Prime membership?-Value seekers. This is a very well spec'd device for the $. I don't think there is a better all around tablet in this range-Kindle owners that want to extend their experience to include music and video-Parents that are looking for a tablet that can be shared with kids. The on-board parental controls are good and it is pretty darn tough. You may want to consider the 7" for this purpose however.Who should not buy the Kindle Fire HD 8.9?-iOS fanatics. If you've already bought into that ecosystem and own music, movies, books and apps it clearly is not a great value-Bleeding edgers. If you are most interested in ultimate customization/flexibility this is not your tablet. It is easy to use, intuitive, and somewhat rigid in terms of configuration. If you want to customize, get a Nexus 10.I've owned two ipads and tried most of the competitive Android tablets and I think the Amazon Fire HD 8.9 is on par with the best if you set aside the fact that Apple's products feel more premium in your hand. The metal back, the higher res screen, and the Apple UI makes the iPad a little sexier. For me its not sexy enough to pay a premium on the device and for every piece of content going forward, but you can decide for yourself.

Reviews.Title: Awesome device!
Reviews.Author: Rogue, **Kindle Forum Pro** "Rogue, **Kindle ...
Reviews.Content: I've only had mine for 48 hours and so far i am thrilled with it. The screen quality is second to none. Everything looks fabulous on it. Text is crisp, pictures are sharp with great color and contrast and HD video is stunning. Dolby sound is the best I've heard on a tablet. Response time in regard to opening apps or starting a movie is very fast. Haven't found anything to dislike as of now other then the volume control buttons are flush with the bezel and not easy to feel. HDMI out to TV works seamlessly and picture and sound are superb. Well done Amazon!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Buy Dispute a Few Problems
Reviews.Author: John Staradumsky
Reviews.Content: Has it really gotten to the point where we have to upgrade our electronic gadgets every year? It was just last fall, after all, that I bought my first Kindle Fire (that's when it was launched after all). I've been addicted to it ever since, and it goes wherever I do. Or at least it did. That's because Amazon announced a refreshed line of Kindle Fires for 2012, and I knew that I had to have one.Not so much because of the fact that there was anything wrong with my trusty Kindle Fire, mind you. It was just that the new ones packed some amazing features that I knew would enhance my Kindle experience with books, videos, music, audiobooks, games, and apps.New Kindle ModelsThe classic Kindle Fire would be dropped to $159, and is a great value at that price if you are looking for a solid, entry level device. It has even been slightly improved since 2011. The new Kindle Fire HD would boast even better screen resolution and a faster processor, more memory, and better Wi-Fi for $199. It was released shortly after being introduced in late September.I, however, was holding out for the larger, 8.9" Kindle Fire that was set to be released on November 20th. This was a trade-off to be sure, as my old Kindle, at 7 inches, was not much larger than a paperback book and immensely portable for that very reason. Still, I decided that I wanted the larger model at 8.9 inch screen size.The 8.9 inch kindle Fire HD comes in several flavors. I opted for the basic model that runs $299 and has 16 GB of internal storage. The next model up will run you $70 more at $369, with the only difference being 32 GB of onboard memory. Both of these kindles are Wi-Fi only.If you want a 4G LTE model, those are available starting at $499 for a 32 GB model and $599 for a 64 GB version. Monthly data plans are available, as well. For occasional use beyond the reach of a Wi-Fi network, you can pay $49 and get 250 MB of data a month for a year. This also includes an extra 20GB of free cloud storage and a $10 credit towards the Amazon app store.It should be noted that all of the Kindle Fire models will display ads when you start up the device. This is no big deal for me, but if you want to remove that feature it will cost you another $15.Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch vs. ipad MiniAs I said, I had opted for the $299 Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch model. But a funny thing happened on the way to the tablet. Apple, sensing that other makers were eating its lunch with smaller, cheaper tablets than the ipad, launched the ipad Mini before I received my new Kindle.That, I think, makes an excellent segue into an ipad Mini to Kindle Fire comparison. Obviously, at $299, the Kindle HD 8.9 inch will save you a few hundred over the ipad 3. But what about a comparison to the new ipad mini? I had a decision to make when the ipad mini was announced, especially since most of my family is already hooked on Apple and has been bugging me to convert. I had a considerable amount invested in Amazon content, though, which was a consideration. Most of it would be portable to an ipad, but the easy interface to your content that the Fire features would not be the same.For starters, the ipad Mini would cost me $30 more for a similar 16GB, Wi-Fi only model. Not so much as to make a difference, but then I started to look at the specs. First off was the display, and the Kindle clearly had the advantage over the ipad Mini. The 1920 by 1200 anti-glare display was clearly superior to the ipad's 1024 by 768 display, and of course the Kindle's screen is an inch larger. The Kindle HD also boasts a faster processor and Wi-Fi, and better speakers. The ipad mini seems to have the edge with it's camera.I decided to stick with my order for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch model.The Kindle HD ArrivesEarlier I mentioned that my new kindle HD was to ship on November 20th. But as I was checking my Amazon account on the preceding Friday, I noticed that the $299 for the device had already been charged to my account. Sure enough, a quick hop over to Amazon.com indicated that the Kinddle HD had shipped the day before, and was on the UPS truck for delivery.Initial ImpressionsI was happy to get my kindle HD early, and popped it out of the box posthaste. I was immediately impressed by the larger display and new design. The device did not have the same heft as my own kindle in proportion to its size, and as a result felt less sturdy. Still, it's clear Amazon has learned from some of the mistakes they made with the original Kindle Fire.First off is the power button, which has been moved from the bottom to the top of the device. This was a major annoyance on my old Kindle Fire, as it had an alarming habit of being depressed when the tablet was held upright and trying to shut the power off.A volume control button is another welcome change; the first Kindle Fire did not have one at all. There's a new front facing camera and improved speakers on the sides of the device as well. The micro USB connection is joined by a micro HDMI output, too.One pet peeve that I have is that there is no power adapter included. While you do get a micro USB cable, this is really for connection purposes to a PC; same will not effectively charge your tablet. Actually, it's not really the omission of the power adapter that bugs me. Let's be fair, the kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch is a steal at $299, and you can get an Amazon "Powerfast" adapter for $19.99. It's just the plug really, and connects to the device via the included cable.My peeve, then, is that I would have liked to have known ahead of time that I needed to buy the power feed. Luckily, my old Kindle charger is compatible, but won't charge the device as quickly as the new one will. Annoyingly, Amazon changed the price to $9.99 on the adapter, but then when I went to buy one the price had changed again to $19.99 again with a $3 MP3 credit. I will hold off, I think, to see if it goes back down.My Kindle HD arrived fully charged and already configured to my Amazon account. I did need to download a software update which took about 30 minutes to fully configure and delayed my ability to start playing.Incompatible AppsWhile the power adapter omission was mildly irritating, the inability to use a number of the apps I had purchased for my Fire was downright infuriating, such to the point that I called Amazon and obtained an RMA. To be fair, most of my apps work on the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet. One in particular, though, that I use almost daily was incompatible when I received my tablet.The app in question is Comics by Comixology. I use this app almost daily, and have spent a considerable amount on digital comics that I and my sons read. To be unable to access these was intolerable, and I called Amazon Tech Support and e-mailed Comixology about the problem.I wasn't alone in my dismay; a number of new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet owners also posted their displeasure on Amazon and the Comixology Facebook page. It seemed amazing to me that Amazon would not correct this, since they get a cut of every comic sold through the tablet app.Fortunately, Amazon and Comixology worked to resolve the incompatibility issues and I was able to download the app the following day. Of course, you may not find my tale of woe all that disheartening, especially if you don't read comics. You should, though, be concerned about the incompatibility of apps, and I should further advise that I do have a number still that won't work. This is  not a problem that Apple has had from ipad model to ipad model.NavigationAs with the original Fire, you will find navigation is fairly intuitive, and not much has changed in the department. The home screen is where the action is at, and you can always navigate to it from any book, video, or app by tapping the screen at the bottom to retrieve the menu; then hit the home icon. It's that easy. Once there, you will notice key information displayed at the top of the screen: "alerts" about software updates, new e-mail, and even a friend's latest move in "Words With friends"; the time; Wi Fi status; and battery strength.Gone, though, is the "Gear" icon that brught you to your settings menu in the past. Instead, you need to swipe down from the top center of the screen to get to some options: you can lock and unlock your device, adjust volume, screen brightness, see and choose wireless networks, sync with Amazon, see device information, and much more.You have several ways to access your content. The home screen is presented as a row of your most recently used books, apps, videos, and websites. This is called the "carousel", and you can scroll through it with the touch of a finger. Any time you access anything in the carousel, it gets bumped to the front of the line. Again, this is much the same as the first Kindle Fire.Holding your finger on a content pane in the carousel allows you to delete it from rotation, delete it from the device, or add it to your favorites. Favorites, however, are no longer displayed on a lower "shelf" on the home screen. Instead, there's now a favorites icon in the shape of a star beneath the carousel (it's also accessible from most other areas in the device). Tapping it at any time will bring up all the content in your favorites menu.You can also access content directly by category from a menu above the carousel.  In addition to the original Kindle Fire Options of Newsstand, Books, Music, Video, Docs, Apps, and Web, you can also choose from Shop, Games, Audiobooks, Photos, and Offers. From each of these categories, you can see content on the device and in the "cloud", and also access the Amazon store to purchase more. As with the first Fire, there is a search box on the home page and for each content category.How Much Storage Do I Need?The amount of storage that's right for you is entirely dependent upon the way you use your Kindle. At 16 GB of memory internally (only 12.8 GB of which is user accessible), I have roughly twice the storage that I had with my old Kindle Fire. Truth be told, I never used all of that, though I came close. Mostly that is because I generally access my content from the cloud. If you are not often in range of Wi-Fi and store more content locally, you may choose to opt for more storage.Managing your content and the amount of memory it consumes is simpler with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet. From the settings menu, simply choose "Device" and "Storage" and you'll get a detailed analysis of your usage by content type. Tapping any of these categories will bring you to a list of that content; you can delete what you no longer want locally to increase available memory.The CloudThe Cloud allows you to store content on Amazon's servers for access through a Wi-Fi or cellular connection with compatible models of the Fire HD. The Fire HD has excellent Wi Fi detection and transfer speed capabilities, indeed even better than the ipad 3 offers thanks to the dual Wi-Fi antennas. This allows you to transfer files to your device in no time.Amazon gives anyone with an Amazon account 5 GB of storage space for free. You can use it to store documents, videos, and music for your Fire. Any music, magazines, books, and videos you purchase through Amazon do not count towards your limit. Need more space for your stuff? Amazon offers the option to buy more, the cheapest plan being $20 for an upgrade to 20 GB. Best of all, this option includes unlimited music storage. Amazon recently copied Apple's "matching" option; if they have the same music in their library that you are uploading they will automatically upgrade your tracks to 256K or better quality. There is no charge for this with one of the paid cloud plans.Available ContentAmazon has the drop on anybody else in the content category. Not even Apple comes close, except perhaps in music, but Amazon offers reduced price songs and albums that I have rarely seen on itunes. In addition, many purchases on Amazon come with promotional MP3 credits, so you can download songs as a bonus. While it's true that you can access this content through other devices, for me the integrated interface with the Kindle Fire makes them much easier to get to.While it is true that the content is not unique to this device and may seem a curious component of a review of the Kindle Fire HD, I truly believe that it is a very important factor in your decision on whether or not to buy this device or an ipad, Surface, or Nexus tablet.NewsstandAmazon offers a number of magazines and newspapers by single issue or by subscription. You can find such favorites as Time, The Economist, Forbes, Us, Popular Science, and much more.BooksAmazon has a massive library of books to choose from, most of the latest titles and lots of classics, too. Many books are free. I had a large library already from Amazon, so I was good to go with my new Fire HD. I generally keep a few on my device and store the rest in the cloud for later retrieval. As with all e-readers, I love the convenience of being able to download a book the day it is released. No trip to the store required.Also par for the course is the ability to adjust display (meaning font and print size) to your liking, though sadly the text-to-speech option that was present on the very first Kindle is still not available. Here's hoping Amazon brings it back someday.MusicThe Fire is a surprisingly good music player. Although it will never replace my Zune as my preferred music device, I do enjoy streaming music from the cloud while web surfing or playing games. As with the Kindle Fire, the Fire HD boasts an impressive little music player that streams high-quality audio to your headphones from the cloud or local storage.There are a number of apps available for music lovers as well, most of them free. Pandora, Spotify, and Iheart Radio are all available for the Fire HD.VideoStill annoying is the inability to play digital copy from my blu ray purchases. That said, there are plenty of options for video with the Fire. The Amazon video store offers a large library to select from, with much content available for rental or purchase. Any purchased content can be accessed from the cloud or the device.When renting a title, Amazon offers the convenient option of downloading to the device so that it can be accessed when Wi Fi is not available. You have 30 days to start watching; once you do the content will be deleted after a 48-hour window.DocumentsDocuments can be accessed from the cloud or the device for access as well. Quickoffice is included at no charge with your Fire HD. This comes in handy, though the files are locked for read access (though different apps allow you to alter them).You can upgrade to the full version of Quickoffice for just $15. I in fact did this shortly after purchasing my first Kindle Fire. This allows easy editing and creation of documents.AppsAmazon is not even close to offering the app content that Apple does, and likely never will. While the library of Android apps available for the Kindle has grown, it is still only a subset of those available on most dedicated Android devices (such as my cell phone). Bottom line for me, though, is that the apps catalog on Amazon suits my needs, and while I may not always be able to get an app I want, I can usually find the app I need.AudiobooksA large library of audiobooks is available through Audible.com, an Amazon company. These are my constant companions on the way to and from work, and help me to endure the traffic.WebThe Fire HD uses the Amazon Silk browser. It's intuitive, learns from the sites you visit most frequently, and starts loading them in advance on its servers when you start surfing (you can shut this off if you prefer). You can bookmark favorites, and websites look good when displayed in either mobile or normal formats. Overall, though, it's not all that different than most of the popular browsers out there.PerformanceAs with the Kindle Fire, Performance of the Kindle Fire HD has pleased me overall. Using the performance of my old Kindle Fire as a baseline, it's easy to see the improved performance on this model.Wi-FiWeb pages load more quickly than in the past with the improved Wi-Fi connectivity. Video and music stream flawlessly with a strong source as well. All the better to access your content from the cloud.Video DisplayThe display is perhaps the most impressive new aspect of the Kindle Fire HD. Video is crisp and clear, and HD movies look better than ever. Apps and games are most impressive, with some HD Apps like "Angry Birds Star Wars" appearing in glorious, sharp detail and amazingly rich, vibrant colors. Digital comics from the Comixology app truly dazzle.Books, also, are easier to read, at least for me. One of the disadvantages of the Fire line is that it lacks the e-ink of the original Kindle. That device was much like reading a conventional book with e-ink. The Fire's display was prone to impart eye fatigue for this reviewer much more quickly. Happily, with the higher resolution and improved display, this does not seem so much a problem with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet.On Screen KeyboardCertainly, the larger display of the Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet allows facilitates the use of the keyboard for e-mail and word processing much more easily. Quite simply, it's much easier to type on the screen keys with the larger display. Often, I found myself making numerous typos on my old Kindle Fire because the keys were just too small; tilting is sideways to increase size reduced my content space. Not as much of an issue with the larger Fire HD.ProcessorSo far, I haven't noticed any benefit from the faster processor. All my games and apps run pretty much as smoothly as they did on the original Kindle Fire. Perhaps that's a compliment to that device.SpeakersAnother of the features that Amazon touts as much improved are the speakers. "Exclusive Dolby audio and dual stereo speakers for crisp, booming sound without distortion"  are promised. From my standpoint? Not so much. While it's true they are slightly louder, a welcome improvement, and have a marked increase in stereo separation, they have little bass at all. I'm not really disappointed about this in such a small chassis to be fair, just don't expect to replace your boom box with the Kindle Fire HD for audio playback.Battery Life and ChargingBattery life has averaged about ten hours of assorted use (apps, books, music, videos) from a full charge. Your mileage may vary with your usage mix; apps and games devour power the most quickly. The device does take a long time to charge with my old Kindle Fire adapter (similar AC adapters can also be used).An hour's charge brought me from 5% to 40% charged; it took another two hours to fully charge my tablet.A Few New FeaturesBluetoothWorth mentioning is Bluetooth capability, not present on the original Kindle Fire. So far, I have been unable use it to play audiobooks and music through my car's speakers, though I was able to successfully pair my new Kindle to the car.CameraA front-facing HD camera is another new feature on the Kindle HD. While there is no native app for it, it does work with Skype for video calls. You can also use it with facebook to record photos and videos; there are several apps for the camera available for purchase. Picture quality and sound recording are very good, indeed, though I find that the front-facing aspect makes it difficult to take photos of things other than yourself.Amazon PrimeIn addition to the second-day shipping upgrades Amazon prime offers, you can also access a large library of movies and TV shows with your Kindle Fire HD as a member. In addition, there is a large library of books that are not otherwise free available for borrowing, one per month. Prime is, it should be noted, an additional $79 a year, and you are under no obligation to purchase it.Overall ImpressionsAlthough I still have major concerns about the incompatibility of apps, I am nonetheless very happy with my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch tablet. Concerns remain that content I purchase now may not be available for future models. Amazon uses the perpetual access of your purchased content from the cloud as a selling point, so I would expect to be able to use it in the future.Still, the Kindle Fire HD shines in so many other areas that I can overlook this. The brilliant display, increased size, faster Wi-Fi, camera, Bluetooth, slightly better sound, all make this a truly useful one-stop entertainment device. The $299 price seals the deal.The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 inch device truly completes the evolution of the Kindle from dedicated e-reader to multi-purpose tablet.

Reviews.Title: Very Nice
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I'm not going to write a book here.  Many others have talked the stats and features.  I am very happy with this device.  I had the original Fire and my new 8.9 blows it away.  Amazon has fixed most everything that I had issues with on my original Fire.  Everything is great!Update#1:  11/17/12  After playing with this all morning, I'm tempted to raise it a star.  I will say that the browser has crashed a few times, which is a problem that I had with my old Kindle Fire.Update#2:  11/30/12  I'm still enjoying the Kindle.  I've yet to try out the bluetooth.  I've been looking for a good bluetooth headset.  I'm still waiting on my case, I hope to have it today.  I'm really hoping the case helps with holding the tablet while reading.  That is about the one thing that I prefer the 7" for was it was easier to hold for long reading sessions.

Reviews.Title: very disappointing
Reviews.Author: S. Sutton
Reviews.Content: This kindle does not compare to the quality of the first kindle I purchased.  The silk browser is the main problem and locks up constantly and has performed that way since day one.  Can't even shop on Amazon with it without it locking up several times per session.

Reviews.Title: I like it, I really like it!
Reviews.Author: Stephensa
Reviews.Content: So, I've owned the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" for just over a month. Just long enough to not be able to return it and buy the  32 gig 4G version at near the  same price I paid for my 32 gig non-4G version. It really sticks in my craw as it were, but that's the way the technology ball crumbles. Its irritating but no reflection on the device. As for the device, I Love It! I use it every day, often and with much glee and happiness.  I own an original Kindle e-reader, a first generation Kindle Fire, and now the HD. My wife has an IPAD and when I got the first gen  Kindle Fire, I liked it. I really did. However I still looked longingly and with much envy at her Ipad.  For good reason.  No longer my friends, no longer.  My new  8.9" Fire HD is wonderful. It has plenty of storage for video, books and apps when I am out of Wi Fi range and when using wi-fi it is very quick on loading web pages, downloads of various media, and I can watch Hulu, Netflix, etc with impunity. Also, I have downloaded some very graphic/ram intensive games and the action is smooth and the video amazing. It really is a fantastic experience. I also like the feature wherein I can plug the unit into my television (HDMI) and watch movies or play games on a big screen. Is it an Ipad? No. In some ways it is better, in some ways not so much.  Is it a laptop?  No.  But that is not what it is meant to be. It is a great media device at a fantastic price.  It is not a portable work computer. You will not crunch numbers or create elaborate spreadsheets though they do have some office type apps available. Its a media device and I believe it does that job very well at a great price point. Do your research, know what you are buying and if it meets your needs go for it.  I give it both  thumbs up.

Reviews.Title: Kindle HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: Richard Mantz
Reviews.Content: Hello all,I thought I would give a brief review of the Kindle HD after using for a couple of weeks now including a trip to Korea.I have used Kindle products for a couple of years now, so it made sense to try the Fire, IF it would meet my expectations. I have a Kindle touch that has been my constant companion for since they were released. I had and earlier kindle reader, and my wife has the original Kindle Fire.I can say that overall, I have been very impressed! Since I travel extensively for work, most out of the country, i was concerned that the HD would be basically a brick outside the USA. Not so. I was able to use FEAT VPN app, then a VPN service. I was able to stream video with no issues.Picture quality was outstanding! IF streaming speed slowed down, I would see some pixelation, but this is streaming speed not the device. Hd movie I downloaded to the device had extremely good detail. WAY better than my laptop!Sound quality was surprisingly good. No, you are not going to get big booming bass on movies and music. But the sound quality was better than any tablet I have had a chance to play with, including the almighty iPad. In fact, the sound had nearly a surround sound quality. I found that in my hotel I preferred to listen through the device speakers and not my headphones. The surround effect was that good!Apps. People make a big deal about this. I borrowed a friends ipad, and yes there are more apps. More worthless apps! Seriously, just because there are a gazzilion apps doesn't make anything better. Are there apps that do what you need? That is what you need to find out. For me, I have found everything I need without an issue, and quite a few more i don't need! I'm not a big game player, so maybe that's why I haven't had an issue.Navigation. I actually find the navigation pretty intuitive, but then again, I have an Android phone. I find it easier to use than the phone, and easier than my wife's original fire. Maybe it's just the bigger screen size. Also, I did not not notice the "lag" that many people mention, except once. Something must have been going wrong because the response was getting slower, then, the Kindle re-booted itself. after that, it was back to normal. I'll keep an I on this to see if it happens again.Browsing. Pretty good. From a user standpoint, I don't see where Silk is either faster or slower for most browsing activities. The recent tabs gets a bit full, but that's easy to clear. Overall, I pretty pleased, but I do miss flash on occasion. I found that the Kindle stayed connected much better than my laptop, and picked up a lot more wifi networks as well. On my n-network at home, it is killer fast! The only issue i had was at the Inchon airport Asiana lounge. I could not get the kindle to connect to their wifi service. My phone had trouble as well, but not my laptop. I noticed other people with different devices not having issues, so there was some sort of compatibility issue.Reading. Ok. I much prefer reading on my kindle touch. It's just much easier on the eyes, and superior in daylight. This is true on with comparing to anything that's not e-ink. Not to mention that the battery on my touch will last for a month with wireless off. The touch will NOT be leaving by bag of toys no matter what other device i have.Music--pretty much a player. Good sound from speakers but way better with headphones.Overall, I am very pleased. I found i used my Kindle far more than my laptop on this trip, including checking and responding to emails with the built in exchange client. I only have the 16gb version, so I might upgrade to the 32gb so I can put more movies on to watch while on the plane.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Mary A. Prudner
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle Fire HD 8.9"!  I am still learning what I can do on it but so far it is great fun!The picture quality is outstanding!

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9"
Reviews.Author: Todd in SC
Reviews.Content: I got the original Kindle Fire last year, but couldn't decide if I wanted to upgrade or not, since I've thoroughly enjoyed it.  But, the bigger screen was the main selling point, given these aging eyes, as well as the specs.I ordered it on Sunday night, Dec 9th, around 10pm EST, and it was on my doorstep less than 48 hours later.  I opened the box, and it exceeded my expectations in size.  It's heavier than the original Fire, but thinner.  I booted it up, and to my surprise, all the books I had purchased over the past year were already downloaded on it (a fact that I had overlooked when ordering).  You do have to tap on them to download, but it takes maybe 2 seconds.  There are more options for the font size, and moving from page to page is just as smooth as the original.The screen is beautiful, and crystal clear.  Scrolling through the books and apps is very easy.  I'm not big on the games, except for Angry Birds, and it plays just fine.  I'm more into the news apps, as well as Facebook and Twitter, and the HD screen makes the pictures and text crisp and clear.  The speakers sound better than on the original, however as other people have said, their position on the back sometimes makes it hard to hear, especially if you're holding it to where they're covered.  But, connect it to a set of speakers or earphones, and there's no problem. I haven't tried the Bluetooth option yet, but do have Bluetooth enabled speakers.I would highly recommend this.  I had thought about joining the iPad craze, but for the price, this device was the best option for me, given what I use it for.  I just couldn't see spending that much more money, when Amazon makes a quality product like this that performs just as well, in my opinion.

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I just first want to say that I was a little bit skeptical about our Kindle Fire HD 8.9".  I have an ipod and was used to how the apps and the layout were.  So when I began using the Kindle all I did was kept comparing it to Apple.  Well this is NOT an Apple product.  This is such an amazing device by an amazing company.  One of our main reasons for buying the Kindle was b/c we love to watch movies.  We are able to watch all of our movies that we have bought from Amazon right on the Kindle.  The picture is so clear and the sound quality is wonderful even with headphones on.  We were able to download all of our movies and still have plenty of room.  The other thing that has really impressed me is the Kindle FreeTime app for kids.  I have a 4 year old son who knows how to navigate the Kindle already.  We set up his profile on the FreeTime app and now I do not have to worry about him clicking on something he should not.  Now we have the Kindle locked down pretty good so that so get to anything you have to put in your pin, but with this App I do not have to worry at all.  We have put his games, movies and books in this spot and let him at it.  He will ask us in the morning can he play his Kindle.  I will say I wish you were able to download apps from the Google sight instead of thru Amazon but one thing I have noticed is they are always adding apps so I know the ones I would like will be there sometime in the future.  The screen is big enough so that if I need to enter in information on a website my fingers are not fumbling around.  We have even gotten rid of Netflix and began using the Amazon Prime feature.  We love it.  There are so many movies to choose from that are free.  I highly recommend this tablet especially to people with children.

Reviews.Title: Short, sweet, dumb-dumb review
Reviews.Author: fredsfan
Reviews.Content: I received this on Saturday, immediately took it out of the box to play with it - no charging required.  I turned it on, followed the steps on the screen and was ready to go.  The Kindle is pre-registered so there is nothing really to do except set up the wi-fi and the Kindle walks you through the steps. I purchased the AT&T; package and it too was extremely simple.  I honestly don't understand people complaining about how they can't figure this out. If you do have trouble, there is a help section that is clearly marked.LOVE how the "back" button is on the of the screen, IMHO, much smarter. The swiping on this kindle is far superior than on my Samsung Galaxy S II phone, few, if any wrong words. Keyboard is easy to use, numbers/letters/characters where you expect them.  Internet speed is great, able to play videos on youtube for my son.  Volume sounds great. I very easily found the settings features and played around with all the options. Obviously there will be a little exploring time to find where stuff is located, this is expected and part of the fun.This is really a very easy to use tablet. I don't want to say it is only for "beginners" because it has a lot of great features if you want to delve into it, but it is easy to use and doesn't take a lot of figuring out. If you have a smart phone, this is easier to use.  If you are familiar with a touch screen, it is a snap.  If you know how to surf the internet, you are golden.  If you are not familiar with the above, it is not the tablet it is the learning curve - don't rate the tablet low because you don't know how to use it. If you WANT to learn how to use it, it is very simple. Some of the negatives are coming from people who expect to know how to use something they have never used before and aren't interested in learning.It come with a USB charging cord, not an issue to me as this standard. It doesn't have a huge users manual but again, standard and there is a help section on the kindle that walks you through things in exact detail.I love this, it does what I expect it to do. Picture is amazing, touch screen responive, sound is great.

Reviews.Title: My Kindle Fire grew up and learned some new tricks
Reviews.Author: Victor A. Buttaro
Reviews.Content: Upgraded from the Fire first edition to the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 (with special offers) and I got to  say it's well worth the upgrade. The larger size and the the sleeker case design help it fit into one's hands a lot better than the first edition. The 8.9 inch screen with a resolution of 1920x1200 makes for beautiful viewing experience. It's my home PC resolution squeezed into a display 1/3 the size. The Dual-band, dual-antenna Wi-Fi (MIMO) is also a welcome addition. Finally I can use the 5 GHz frequency on my router. (As a side note; if you're looking to upgrade make sure you get one that can transmit in both frequencies at the same time)The new UI runs a lot smoother than the last edition and looks nicer. The black background just works much better. Please note the UI runs though runs on top of a newer version of Android than the last revision so some thing have changed slightly. But it's nothing that one won't pick up in 15 minutes or less. Haven't had a chance to test out many games that would actually stress the tablet out yet. My favorite pinball game does run smoother and just look beautiful under the new higher resolution.She isn't just a pretty face; my baby also knows how to sing! While I haven't tested it out with any movies yet; the new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is also much improved in the sound department over the first version.It's not all perfect though. My only real issue is with the removable of the power/charge light. Not really sure why this was removed as it was helpful. having said that though there is (as other have probably mentioned) a program called Battery HD that you can download/buy. I purchased the Pro version and one of the things it allows is to set alerts for battery level. It's the perfect way for your Fire to tell you when it's all charged up or when it gets to a level you wished to be warned about. Still wish that the light hadn't been removed though. Hopefully Amazon will add a software method that will make it easier to see/hear charge status.And yes, unfortunately it doesn't come with a charger. I would think in this day and age people already have chargers but that seems to be a major complaint. My suggestion is get Amazon's high powered charger if you don't have one. You're going to need one for other devices in your life anyway and a high powered one is the way to go. This one will charge your Kindle and probably every other device without a charger you'll get in the future.So finally, should you upgrade from the first edition Kindle Fire? YES without a doubt. You already know what you're getting into with Amazon's device and the market place, so that won't be an issue. And you'll be getting something that is much improved. As for new users, as long as you know what you'll be getting in advance I say go for it! The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is a great piece of hardware for the price.

Reviews.Title: Holy Cow, what a unit.
Reviews.Author: Charles W. Weigand "Crossfire Chuck"
Reviews.Content: Crystal clear is an understatement.  We pre-ordered and received the unit before any retail stores in the area.  As an avid I Pad user, this is the absolute closest thing at a price you can actually afford without taking out a loan.  I purchased it for my wife due tot he size and abilities.  Yikes, did I get a special treat (That alone made the purchase outstanding).  I call it the "fun pad" because that is exactly what it is, FUN.  Let us not diminish the work abilities and multi tasking.  The size is more comfortable without making it bulky and difficult to hold (for those midnight oil reading sessions).  Set up was a couple of minutes.  What a knock out picture.  For those who cannot swing the I Pad; this would be the way to go.  Maybe some accessories will result in another  "special treat".  The possibilities are endless.  With all the tablets out there, it is difficult to chose.  I purchased some early Kindles for relatives who are "hooked" on reading their books, magazines anywhere, anytime.  With declining eye sight, options can help.  I will admit I have not been able to "play" with the HD, my wife says you can have it when you pry it from my cold dead hands.  I guess that says it all!

Reviews.Title: Kindle fire Hd 8.9 New User
Reviews.Author: Val4
Reviews.Content: I am new to tablets. Im no computer expert, so I guess this review is for the everyday person like me that knows enough about computers to use them effectively but doesnt really get into all of the technicalities. I got my kindlefire hd 8.9 about a week ago and I havent been able to put it down. A few months ago I ordered the Ipad but I returned it right away after having buyers remorse about the price tag of almost $1000.  Im so happy that I decided to go with the kindle. I think it is definitely worth the price. A lot of people have complained about the ads but I only see an ad when I turn on the kindle or when I wake it up, other than that, I havent seen any ads. If you're a bargain shopper like me, you wont mind the ads one bit for the lower price.I love that it seems that attention was given to the details like a rubber back, light weight, the size is perfect to fit in my purse, and the ability to hold it in any position and type. Ive read a lot of reviews about how great the speakers are but since this is my first tablet I really dont have anything to compare them to but I can say that they are clear at the maximum volume.Im thinking about getting one for my 22 year old daughter. Her first question was does it have instagram. Unless I need to do more searching, no there is no instagram app which is disappointing.  I even went directly to the instagram site and my pics wouldnt load.  Im also disappointed with the facebook app that does not allow me to scroll down my wall as far as I want. I can only go partly down the page then it stops scrolling. Another problem that Ive had is that the internet browser keeps crashing, very irritating. Ive gone to websites that require flash to open content but the kindle says that its not supported, again irritating.  I dont know if this is the norm for certain content not to be able to open on tablets but if it is then this is a major drawback of tablets for me.  The point of having a tablet is so that I dont have to pull my laptop out just to browse the web. I also have to add that the volume and power buttons are hard to find since they are sort of hidden around the edge. It would be helpful if these buttons stood out more maybe by being a different color or even making the power button a switch that slides up and down vs a push button which is what it is now. Finally amazon NEEDS to include the charger. It was very inconvenient to get the kindle then realize that I could only charge it on a pc so I had to go back, buy the charger, and wait for UPS to deliver it.So far the kindle fire hd 8.9 has been fun to play around with and learn but if the concerns that I expressed were fixed, it would be perfect.UPDATE for new users like me:Check out The Android Guy on youtube. He has great tips on downloading other apps and browsers that arent usually available on the kindle. I was even able to get Instagram! I love him!

Reviews.Title: Not disappointed
Reviews.Author: kylee1
Reviews.Content: I owned an ipad2, the original kindle fire, and a kindle e-reader. I used the ipad mostly for watching movies and playing games because of the larger screen, but prefered Amazon movie streaming to itunes because I have an Amazon Prime account, so I can get tons of movies and tv shows for free. I used the kindle fire to read in bed so I didn't have to use a separate light source and found the ipad to be too big and heavy for reading. I then had to get the kindle e-reader for reading outside. I wanted something that would do the job of all three and I found it in the Kindle Fire HD 8.9inch. I thought I would need a kindle paperwhite for reading in bed , but have found the Fire to be the perfect size and I like the option of using a black background with white type because it doesn't let off a lot of light and doesn't cause eye strain. I have sold my ipad and don't miss it at all! I never used the camera on the ipad except for skyping or facetime so I don't see what the big deal is about the Fire only having a front facing camera because I don't know why you would want to use it for a camera anyway.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9 is great!
Reviews.Author: Rebecca McLane
Reviews.Content: I got mine yesterday, and have already been able to do so many things with it without having to do much searching for help.  I already have a Toshiba Thrive tablet, which I really really like, but it certainly does not have anything close to the high resolution of this tablet.  Unlike a lot of reviews for the smaller version, which came out several weeks ago, I found that it is very intuitive and easy to set up and use.  I have been watching the app store, and more and more apps are becoming available for the HD.  Most of the apps which I had purchased previously for my Thrive can be used on this tablet, and I found some wonderful RPG's which are not available for my Thrive (Final Fantasy III, for one example).  I am just beginning to explore all the things I can do, and I will be looking at a way to organize my books (Amazon - you REALLY need to develop a collection app for the Fire and Fire HD!!!), since I have over 1600 of them.  I strongly recommend the Battery HD Pro app, since you can set it to give you an audible alert both when your battery is low (can choose what level it gives the alert) and when the battery charging is complete.  All in all, so fare I love it and feel that it was a great deal for the price!

Reviews.Title: Whats Wrong With These People?
Reviews.Author: DonnaMae
Reviews.Content: Kindle Fire HD 8.9", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 32 GB - Includes Special OffersI received my Fire about 2 weeks ago, as a elderly lady, and not very computer savvy, I was expecting lots of problems getting it up and running, Within 5 minutes its was going through its paces.its everything I had hoped for and more. If I can navigate through the books and buy some, set up Skype, my email account, and zip around the net, anybody should be able to do this!Some of these reviews borrow on downright stupid, and its now fair to even have to post them and bring the rating of the Kindle Fire down! Is it really perfect??? No, but what is in this world now?? I'm hoping for many fun years with this product.

Reviews.Title: A good tablet but you need to know some tricks to get most out of it
Reviews.Author: Shalandra Sharma
Reviews.Content: First thing first, i think you need to have alittle bit of technical background to get the most out of this. The main reason for that is that Google play app store is not accessible on it and the Amazon app store is just not that good at this point in time as it does not have all the apps. Thus you need to know how to access other app stores like getjar etc. It will also help if you know how to sideload apps.There are a lot of articles on the net which provides you tips and tricks to get most out of this great device. I would recommend the following apps.1. An app like es file share that lets you explore the contents of your kindle. This will help you to find the apps which you can download from other app does our forums. Once you download the apps using ess file share you can find the downloaded apk file and install the app.2. Dolphin or chrome browser. I am not impressed with silk and find dolphin to be a better choice. Chrome is my second choice as it syncs all my activities from other devices but to install chrome and other google apps you will have to a little bit of research.there is a post on xda developers forum which provides step by step instructions to install google apps without rooting your kindle.3. Google apps. As i said in the point above kindle does not come pre installed with Google apps, so you will have to download them using the instructions on the net. The email client that comes puree installed sucks big time with gmail. For me it will stop syncing and i will have to remove and re add my account. Also it does not had a lot of other features provided by google gmail app.I will also advise a user guide like the one by Shelby Johnson. It has step by step instructions to get the most out of your kindle.It might sound like you have to go through a lot of hoops to get all your favorite stuff on it, but that actually is a plus point for me as it shows me the power of open source world (again different people will have different opinion about that but that's my personal opinion) and i can choose what apps i want and which ones i don't and i can get the apps from multiple sources rather being tied to just one.I will also recommend Adobe reader app over the default pdf reader. It's a free app and provides great features for your personal pdf files.Of course the default book, video and music apps for the content downloaded from Amazon app store are great.So in a nut shell the hardware on this tablet is great while the pre-installed software is so so. But the deficiencies of the software can be easily rectified using the other available alternatives. I like it and will recommend to others.

Reviews.Title: Perfect item if you know what you want
Reviews.Author: C. Northcutt
Reviews.Content: I wanted an item that could do 5 things.1. Read textbook/published papers in PDF format2. Fast internet browsing3. Syncs well with Amazon Prime and Amazon services4. Has a high resolution screen5. Allows sideload installation of APKs (Google Android applications).I bought the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" because it is the only tablet on the market that does all 5 of these things VERY well for less than $500. After using the product, I have tried all 5 of my needs and have been impressed with the performance in all five categories.Most consumers don't stop and think what they actually want from a product - they just buy whatever has the best specifications (best screen, Gorilla glass, largest memory, fastest processor, blah blah blah...) This is not the smart way to be a consumer. If you want an apple, you don't need to buy an apple orchard. The Kindle is a product aimed at a specific set of use cases. If you are someone who likes reading, reads textbooks in PDF format, likes ridiculously fast web browsing, and wishes to sideload APKs, this is the item for you. If you want something smaller than 9 inches (not useful for reading PDFs), or something that has widgets and the Anrdoid interface, or something that has cloud storage that isn't amazon products, or something that is clearly stated in the product description as not being a service that Kindle Fire provides... then don't buy it.If everyone who bought kindle, read everything in the description and bought the product based on what it does well, this item would have no less than 5 stars. Every Android application can be installed on the Amazon Kindle without the Google Play Marketplace by simply directly downloading the APK and installing it.If you want an item for these five things, there is absolutely no better product on the market. I can't believe how lucky I was to find something that perfectly suits my consumer needs. I'm sure Kindle Fire HD "8.9 does other things well, but I don't care about them. I wanted a product that fulfilled this set of 5 criteria, and this product has been AS ADVERTISED and BETTER.

Reviews.Title: GREAT TABLET!
Reviews.Author: D. Hastur
Reviews.Content: I really liked the first generation Kindle Fire, but I love the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" even more.Pros:the addition of volume buttons; the addition of and HDMI output jack; more memory; higher resolution screen; faster processor; dual-band wi-fi; Dolby audio; the ON/OFF button, the volume buttons, and the line out jack (head phone jack) are not on the same side as the power and HDMI jacks (which should make a media dock possible); and more.Cons:I would still like to see Amazon add an SD Card slot or the ability to access external storage (thumb drive, etc.) by the way of an OTG cable.The 8.9" screen is a great size; not as bulky as the 10" or larger tablets, but better suited for browsing the internet, reading emails, viewing photos and videos, than the smaller tablets.I have, and will continue, to recommend this Kindle Fire.

Reviews.Title: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G Certainly Delivers And Some
Reviews.Author: Conrad P. Weller "Multi-tasker"
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G does everything it's been advertised to do, and it does it well.  The images on the screen are crisp and detailed, and the sound is gorgeous, even without earphones.  You can play an MP3-recorded  Bruckner symphony on it, without earphones, and get a very decent rendition (with earphones you'd think you're smack in the concert hall).  The Silk engine is quick and reliable, so going online is a cinch.  As a reader, it has resolved the problem of reading Tables on the Kindle, not only because text is easily readable, even if small, as a result of the bright background and the high resolution, but also because the Fire HD has a feature that allows you to focus on a Table section and enlarge it by tapping.When I first got my device, in late November of 2012, I had problems receiving email from a non-preinstalled provider (Earthlink in my case) but the problem was resoved around Christmastime with the latest software update (version 8.1.4) and, since then, I've had no problem receiving email from Earthlink (Hotmail and Yahoo have never been a problem).  Incidentally, the very annoying deficiency that plagues the first-generation Kindle Fire, and even the Kindle Fire II (non-HD), i.e., the inability to target a text search, has been resolved in both the 7" and the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD.So, the device truly delivers.  Amazon, on the other hand, is still behind with some issues.  For instance, the Kindle Fire HD can't yet install or read reference works, such as dictionaries, which are readily available on other Kindle readers, such as the Kindle Touch or the Kindle Paperwhite.  This limitation unfortunately robs the Kindle Fire HD of the bragging right to being  a "work and play" gadget.  But not everything is lost.  The Kindle Fire HD has a nice feature that allows you to both listen to and at the same time read an audio book.Though I still depend on my Kindle Paperwhite (or my beloved Kindle Touch) for some specific consultation functions, I have found the Kindle Fire HD to be a superior mobile device for enjoying almost everything that Amazon provides in the way of consumer content.  Even por those consultative functions that are still only available on other Kindle readers, I can still rely on the Silk engine and, a bit less efficiently, connect to Wikipedia or to other online sites and get my questions resolved. Since mine is a 4G-capable device, the online option is always available (though expensive) anywhere, WiFi or no WiFi.Finally, I'd like to emphasize that, as a machine, the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G is beautifully compact and streamlined.  Though larger than any other Kindle, it is still easily portable, and its more ample screen offers many advantages.  I have the magnetized cover, which allows you to sart the device or to put it to sleep by just opening or closing the lid, and this feature (also available for the Kindle Paperwhite) makes everything quick and easy.For the above reasons, the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G deserves an unqualified thumbs up.  Get it and enjoy it!  By the way, I believe that the 64 gigabyte option is worth the extra $100 but that the Special Offers may prove distracting (so, I parted with $15 and had them removed).

Reviews.Title: Great Device For The Money!!
Reviews.Author: Ben
Reviews.Content: I will start off by saying we have an iPad2 at home and have been iPhone users since day one, I was very skeptical about buying something not only Android but modified Android at that. I am a 911 Dispatcher working 12hr shifts and was looking for something I could use to read on as well as play some basic games and surf the web, knowing this I could not justify the cost of another iPad.Controversy:I read hundreds of reviews prior to buying this device and saw the same thing over and over so I will address them here1.) No Charger!!! I read this and knew it, considering I have 4 iPhone and 2 original Kindle chargers this was 100% a non-issue for me and anyone who reads the description would know this is the case.2.) No Flash! Sorry to inform but Flash is no longer supported on mobile devices as it is basically on its way out, you can't get mad at the Kindle because the sites you visit haven't been updated.3.) Ad's! The lock screen ad doesn't bother me at all, the much complained about recomendations can be turned off the in the software and are gone.Display:Fantastic! The screen is so crisp and great I love it!Operating System:I would prefer a more open version of Android but the Amazon OS has been very stable and quick with -0- issues since unboxing, is it 100% as smooth as the iPad-no it isn't but it is very close and for the price difference it is a non-issueContent:As always Amazon content is awesome, I have subscribed to a few magazines and they work great on the larger screen, I have not gotten Prime yet but plan to soon.Apps:I read alot fo complaints about the lack of apps, I found there were so many I didn't know what to get and I suspect as more and more Fires are sold more developers will port over existing games and apps.Summary:If you want an iPad, get an iPad-you aren't going to buy one for less than $300 and for less than $300 you aren't going to get 100% of the capability-I am sorry but that is how it is, if you need a device like I did for web surfing, reading, games and nothing really heavy or involved then get the Fire, I don't think anyone who knows going into it what they are buying can complain about it!

Reviews.Title: EARLY CHRISTMAS PRESENT FOR THOSE WHO ARE NAUGHTY
Reviews.Author: R. C. Lindner "I am here, yet I am gone"
Reviews.Content: I have bought myself an early Christmas present to replace my Google Nexus 7 tabletthat was stolen from me in Spain.I chose the Kindle Fire HD 8.9"...which was a strange choice.  The Google  Nexus 10 was preferredbut the price was much higher.Kindle Fire HD Pros:1) Screen size and resolution....does a genuine screen 12:9 1080p HD resolution.2) Sound...stereo Dolby....sounds great thru Noise-cancelling headphones3) Fastest wifi with great range...I can watch HD movies from everywhere in the house.4) Cheapest price...reduced right down to compete with Apple, but make revenue from content.5) Amazon Prime gives access to all of Amazon content, including movies (like TinTin in HD) and free Amazon 2day shipping.6) HDMI out so you can watch/listen on the TV. I bought a 15' micro HDMI cable for <$10 and an HDMI splitter to expand my hdmi in's from 2 to 3+Cons:1) Size  ....I think the 7" is the best tablet size, but need the hi res. 10" is too large to fit in a pocket.2) No GPS or Maps3) No Voice to Text ...(speech recognition) . Nexus and the iPad are excellent for this4) Screen and case are hard to keep smudge-free....there is some special coating on the glass that shows fingerprints.5) Amazon runs a modified O/S, not the Android JellyBean.  It's less of a computer, and more of a viewer.6) No rear-facing cameraI got the 16gb WI-fi version, not the (more expensive) 4G.Its a great value...It is nice to watch 'TV' without commercials..

Reviews.Title: Great Kindle!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I received my Kindle 4 days ago and I love it! I was surprised to receive it way ahead of schdule but I have enjoyed learning the features on it since it arrived. The only issue (if you could call it an issue) that I had was that there was no quick start guide in the box but with just a little effort I located the instructions on the Amazon website. The size is just right and it is not too heavy to hold comfortably in your hands. I like the option the change the page color for books to sepia and this has made it very easy on my eyes for reading. I like the option of being able to see what you have downloaded on the device as well as what is on your cloud. The variety of apps for the kindle is very good and they are always adding more. Since I have amazon prime I am able to view a lot of movies and shows for free. The quality of the video is excellent! The location of the power button is the only thing that I am not really fond of although it really isn't a major drawback. It is very easy to accidentally push it and have the kindle go into the "sleep" mode. I just have to be careful where I am holding the kindle and hopefully this will no longer an issue at all after I receive my cover. I still need to put a screen protector on it and will do that soon. I would DEFINITELY order this again and have told several friends about the new kindle already.

Reviews.Title: 4G only $49 for first year... then $180+/yr
Reviews.Author: this_moment
Reviews.Content: I'll make this short and sweet, since there are some great, very detailed reviews already left by others. The one thing I don't see mentioned in any other reviews that I think is critical decision-making data for anyone thinking of paying for the 4G model, is that after the first year you pay AT&T;'s normal monthly data rates. Those are currently $15/m for the same amount of data as in the first year (so now $180/yr instead of $49) or $30/m once you get into the GBs range. However, note that with other Kindle devices you get free lifetime 3G!

Reviews.Title: Exactly what the (Me) Ordered for College
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "BookEnd"
Reviews.Content: Well, I did it. I went ahead and ordered the 32 GB Kindle Fire HD 8.9". I was in sticker shock, of course, as it came out to a good $500 when I added Poetic KeyBook Bluetooth Keyboard Case for Kindle Fire HD 8.9 Black (Support Auto Sleep/Wake Function)(3 Year Manufacturer Warranty From Poetic)and the warranty and a decal (for when it's not in the case).  But what the heck, you only live once, right?  I was extremely excited to receive it, and with the Amazon Prime Student 2 day shipping, it came in the mail exactly two days later.  The sleek black box contains the Kindle, a USB cord, and nothing else- but I'm a repeat Kindle customer, so I have plenty of micro USBs lying around the house.  The quality of the micro USB charger you use does seem to make a difference however, as some of my chargers didn't work at all (though they were working on other devices just fine), while others charged pretty decently.  I would say, after having my Kindle for a couple of days now, that it is worth it to purchase the rapid charger that Amazon offers you for $9.99 when you add the Kindle to your cart.Just a word of warning...a full charge lasts me quite awhile, but I like to charge it to 100% when I do charge it, and that takes FOREVER on a regular micro USB.  When I turned it on, I was pleasantly surprised to see how the carousel was already customized with some of my favorite books. The carousel can be easily changed to what you use, read, listen to, or watch the most often.  My carousel is a mix of the email shortcut, the Amazon Silk(that's Amazon's web browsing brand, for want of a better description) shortcut, which shows a pic of my last page visited, some game apps, and my favorite books.  The carousel is very responsive, and it changes functionality depending on whether you are in landscape or portrait mode. In landscape mode( my favorite mode) you see your carousel on a black background, and a row of options across the top that are shortcuts to music, video, books, apps, etc.  In the bottom right hand corner is the star button, which allows you to look up your favorites, though those might already be on your carousel.  In portrait mode, the carousel is obviously narrower, and across the bottom, for every item on your carousel, you see "Customers Also Bought" and a row of pictorial suggestions based on those selections.  I didn't notice this when I went to look at a display of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" at my local Best Buy.  One of the reasons I was so eager to purchase the new Kindle Fires is that I'm rough on electronics; I have accidentally damaged three kindle keyboard editions by leaving them in bad spots, where the screens were pushed on (mostly by dogs on the couch) a tad too hard, rendering them useless. The gorilla glass of the Kindle Fire is nice and sturdy- though I am glad that I purchased the 2 year warranty, just in case.  Fingerprints/smudges can be rather annoying to look at when the kindle is off and all you see are your prints marring the pristine black of the screen.  But I don't often stare at my kindle when it's in standby mode, so I don't consider it a big deal whatsoever.  But I thought I would bring it up in case that does bother other people thinking about buying this.  I was SO surprised at how fast the downloads and web browsing and toggling are on this Kindle.  It's freaking WONDERFUL. You just don't get a grasp of how fast this device is when you are looking at it in a retail store.  I did have a one or two times when Silk wouldn't load at work, but it quickly resolved itself. No different from network issues on a computer, so it didn't phase me whatsoever.  I would definitely suggest that if you are someone buying this for school, to go to the pull down menu at the top of the kindle screen, click on the more button and then onto the device link. Add this devices personal email address to your email accounts, so that you can directly email the device documents from Microsoft Word. It might work with the whole Microsoft Suite, but so far I've only tried Word.  This way it shows up quick and easy in your documents, and its' SO easy to use.  Before I figured out how to use the documents, I kept having to go to the drafts folder in my yahoo email to look up the text I wanted to read.  I'm a full time college student, as well as working full time, and I needed a device that was powerful, easy to use, and that had some great browsing, organization, and research capabilities. With my Kindle Fire HD, I can read critical analyses, Wikipedia the author of the book I'm reading, add homework to my calender, and watch lectures online, all without taxing the device.  I would definitely suggest getting a Bluetooth keyboard, as the typing, while intuitive, doesn't really lend itself to getting notes down quickly.  I'm enrolled in a winter semester (mini-mester)class and I'm really looking forward to keeping updated on class assignments, reading textbooks, and using Evernote to load notes for use later, all from my Kindle Fire.  And with the 32 gb model, I'm confident that I won't run out of room anytime soon.  I am glad, after seeing how many books I have in my Cloud drive, that I got the 32gb model rather than the cheaper 16gb model.  I've had this for almost a week now, and I'm feeling really confident that I made the right choice.  If you've already invested in the Amazon universe, and you need a tablet for school, or work, or play, I would very highly recommend this device.  I'm not too impressed with Amazon Prime's selection of free movies, and I probably won't purchase the full edition of it unless the library grows rapidly in the next 6 months. But Netflix works pretty well on the Fire, as well as Hulu Plus, so I wouldn't say that Prime's light offering of movies/tv to stream is that much of a hardship.Sorry if this review is too long, but I tried to review this for the things I would want to know, personally.  Everyone else has already exhaustively covered the specs, so I think readers are covered there...All in all, I am a very satisfied Amazon customer.

Reviews.Title: sending Samsung note 10.1 back..will never give up my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD- THE BEST TABLET OUT THERE
Reviews.Author: Kindle Customer "BBB"
Reviews.Content: Plus Amazon has THE BEST customer service out there...and that can be equally as important as the quality of the device. We wont repeat whats been said other than if you're looking for the BEST picture & sound quality for movies...Netflix....Huluplus...HBOGO etc. reading...web surfing and more...this is far better than Samsungs 10.1 note and even our ipad!!! If/when Amazon ever decides to do a 10.1 or larger tablet...they'll blow EVERYONE including Apple, out of the water! This is an Exceptional product.... you won't regret purchasing!!

Reviews.Title: Love it, Love it, Love it!!!!!
Reviews.Author: camping queen
Reviews.Content: After hours of research I decided that this was the device for me.Than the long and some what impatient wait for this to arrive, I have to say that I am very happy.I do not seem to have a problem with the power button, once I found it, which did take a minute, I havenot had a problem since than.Set up was very easy and the device walks you right through it.Books look great on this device.  I do have to turn down the brightness to read, my eyes are somewhat light sensitive, other that that they are very crisp and clean looking.  I could see not havinga way to organize your books in the future being a pain, but at this time I don't have that many booksin my library.There are more than enough apps for me.  Haven't run across one that I am missing at thistime.My email is not compatible with this device, but I really don't care.  I prefer to go to my emailthrough the web anyway, which I am able to do with no issues using silk.I have watched tv shows available through my amazon prime account and they have been veryclear and the sound has been great. Netflix was a little glitchey at first, but than it cleared itself up,I only used it for a few minutes to test out the app, so I am not sure how it would work for a longperiod of time.I have surfed the web with silk almost everyday.  I have not run into any issues.The keyboard does not give me any problems, if you are used to using an iphone or smartphonekeyboard you should be fine.  If not, it will take a little time to get used to.Just to give people an idea about this kindle,  I do not feel that it will ever replace my laptop, nor doI want it to. I have a macbook that I paid a lot of money for so why would I want it to.I have an iphone as well, which I enjoy using and am comfortable with, therefore if there are apps Iwant from apple I can get them on my iphone.  I also use my iphone for music so I at this time I don't see theneed to have my music on my kindle, that may change or it may not.I bought the prowerfast charger, it does what it is supposed to do, no issues there either.Over all if you are looking for an ereader that has a few more bells and whistles, this is a great choice.If you are looking for a machine to do everything a computer does, this is not it.  I would recommend youlook into some of the newer computers coming out.

Reviews.Title: Sleek, Thinner, Tablet
Reviews.Author: prisrob "pris,"
Reviews.Content: I have the first generation kindle, a Kindle Fire and now the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 16 GB. I pre-ordered this Kindle the day it was announced in September. I was pleased to receive my new Kindle at least two weeks earlier than advertised.The Kindle arrived in the same black packaging as the Kindle Fire. Easy to open with the side zip. Once out of it's box, the Kindle is sleek, thinner than the i-Pad. It is the same height. Simple directions are found in a side pocket of the inner packaging.The buttons are placed along the upper right side, horizontally. They are flush to the tablet, and for some these buttons seem to be more difficult to find.  Turn the Fire on, swipe the lock key, the tablet asks for your Wi-Fi password, you select your time zone and confirm your account. Very easy compared to many other tablets. Now, the real experience begins. Your apps have been automatically configured from other kindles. There is an amazing array of other apps to choose from. The Kindle brings you through the entire process. You click on next to go from one page to the next in the setup process.One of the best improvements, among many is email. Very easy to set up, the email is crisp and clear.  The Fire HD 8.9 is the version to get. Its larger, higher-resolution screen better facilitates Amazon's still-new Kindle Fire interface, and its faster processor makes for a much smoother and zippier experience.. The tablet's availability in a Wi-Fi-only version ($299 for 16GB, $369 for 32GB) and a 4G LTE Wireless version $499 for 32GB, $599 for 64GB, is superb. Speakers are mounted on either side and the sound is so much better.Streaming films from Netflix or Amazon Prime is the way to go. Crisp, clear vision and the HD sound!  Moving from one app to another is very fast. I purchased 'Best 100 Kindle Fire HD Apps' as suggested by another reviewer, and it is an excellent source. For $.99, a great deal of information is available.So far, I have been disappointed with the selection of Kindle Fire HD covers, expensive. I will do more research to find one that is perfect for me.I am extremely pleased with this Kindle Fire HD 8.9 tablet. It has everything I have wanted in a tablet with faster service and Amazon's experience. The lack of a specific charger is not a problem, I have several I can use. I have been listening to Mumford and Sons while writing this review, and the sound is just superb!Highly Recommended. prisrob 11-20-12Amazon Kindle PowerFast for Accelerated Charging (not included with device, for use with the new Kindle Fire or Kindle Fire HD models)

Reviews.Title: Vast Improvement
Reviews.Author: Mbail
Reviews.Content: Very impressed with my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9.  I have the original Kindle Fire and have been happy with it, but the new version addresses most of my gripes with the previous version.  First and foremost, storage; I purchased the 32 Gb version and it was well worth the extra money.  I have download a couple audio books, a music playlist with about 50 songs, all of my magazines, a few books and most of my apps and have about 23 Gb left.  Doesn't sound like a lot, but I was constantly managing the space on my original Kindle Fire and would have never downloaded music or audiobooks, it just took too much space.  The gmail integration is much improved.  I can move e-mails to my gmail folders with the native app and it also syncs to my contacts and gmail calendar.  Ahh, so much nicer.  There is more customization available such as the ability to set the brightness to auto, turn off the last web page showing on the carousel, turn on notifications for applications, and turn off Amazon Home recommendations.  Amazon has learned there lesson well.  Give us an interface that is easy to use, but give us some customization to make it pretty.  The HD screen is very nice.  I plugged the device into my flat screen and the picture and sound were good.  Bluetooth was easy to use and worked with my bluetooth headphones, including forwarding through songs.In fact, I would have rated this five stars if not for the Silk browser.  Don't get me wrong, it gets the job done, but it crashes on the more intesive websites (esp. Adobe).  Also, if Amazon is driving us to the cloud, why can I not store my bookmarks there?  I have every confidence Amazon will get it right with Silk, but I can't give it five stars since one of the main reason I have a tablet is a bit buggy.

Reviews.Title: Sorely disappointed
Reviews.Author: Donald Atkinson
Reviews.Content: I love Amazon, and I love my e-Ink Kindles so I had high hopes for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" and honestly I didn't think it was that bad for the first couple of weeks.  I've had it for about 2 months now and the only way to describe my feeling toward it at this point is buyer's remorse.  I had bought this as a replacement for my original iPad which is no longer supported and it has gotten quite sluggish at pretty much everything.  Initial impressions were good--but it is no iPad--it was also half the cost.
