There were annoyances like it just freezing up completely for 30 seconds at a time before resuming what it was doing like nothing happened, but I figured I could live with it for at least a year despite those and it wouldn't have cost me any more than my iPad cost me since I got less than three years worth of useful life out of it.  BUT, two months in I am now getting about 10 minutes worth of use out of a complete charge!  Let me say that again in case you weren't paying attention...10 MINUTES USE FROM A COMPLETE CHARGE!!!  With a full charge I play about 10-20 minutes of Simpsons Tapped out on it (which doesn't take the battery meter down very much) and then leave it until the next day when I get home from work and it ALWAYS says that the battery is dead.  I don't have any notifications turned on so I don't know what it is doing all day that drains the battery--but at this point it is nothing more than a $400 paperweight--yes, I bought the ridiculously expensive cover too.I will unequivocally state that I'd pay twice as much for an iPad.EDIT:So after letting this sit for a day I realized that it wasn't much more than venting and didn't really provide much useful information.  So, here is something a little more useful to add.The display is excellent, though the touch sensor is not the greatest--does not seem to be very accurate or sensitive and suffers from the general lag of the system.  The system is a bit slow to respond to input, but seems to run most things pretty quickly.  I'm not sure what might cause this other than the overhead of Android.Many complain about the lack of the Google Play store, but I don't really see this as that big an issue.  You can side load anything that you download from Google Play on another Android device--it is just not nearly as convenient.The placement of the power button is annoying--I'm constantly accidentally turning it on or turning it off.  (Or at least I did when I was using it more.)Web browsing is one of the major things I had planned on using it for.  Web browsing is not a joy.  I don't remember specifics but after about a week I gave up on it for that purpose and went back to my iPad.One thing that I found extremely annoying is when I had the notifications turned on it would take me to the Amazon App Store when I told it to clear the notifications.  I'd think that would only happen if I tapped on a specific notification that was an advertisement.I also purchased the HDMI cable for it and was disappointed in the output of it.  It wasn't horrible, but not something I would use without a specific need to.The micro-USB charging port is HORRIBLE!  If you don't get the cable plugged in just right it will not charge at all--and it makes the device extremely hot to boot.  Always check to make sure you have a charging indicator when you plug in the cable.The extremely expensive case also disappointed me.  It does not fit tight enough and I've accidentally pulled it off several times when I've picked it up by the corner.  It also exacerbates the issue with the placement of the power button.I don't use my tablets to watch movies but when I tried that it seemed to work without problems.  I also don't use them to listen to music and I'm pretty sure I didn't even try that so while the sound is pretty good on the things I've used it for I can't really say how it might be for things that are more sound demanding.  Another thing I don't use it for is reading books--I have an e-Ink Kindle for that.  And I've never used the camera on it.One thing that I find annoying about Android in general is the lack of quality apps available.  Sure, the big name apps from the big companies all work well and I don't have complaints about them, but for some things it is really hard finding a decent app.  Luckily the Kindle Fire versions of apps are usually well done so given the choice I select those.Still, the negatives outweigh the positives and I would still be willing to pay twice as much for an iPad.  Were this a $100 device I'd give it a qualified recommendation, but Amazon markets it as an iPad killer, and that it ain't.

Reviews.Title: changed rating...and sad about that!!
Reviews.Author: AmazonFan
Reviews.Content: This is my fouth Kindle...yes, you read that right.  I had gotten the original Fire but found it bulky, heavy and the screen gave off too much glare.  I keep it charged, but seldom use and found myself going back to the prior generation for my reading (which is voracious).  This one "fits" me great.  Love the larger screen, but the device is very slender and easy to hold & store.  The display is simply spectacular and the streaming videos are spoiling me!  The speakers are really incredible for such a small gadget.  Easy to set up and I find the keyboard just fine and no inconvenience to check for battery.  To keep the cost lower I am happy to trade off a few things and for me, Amazon put the money where the bang is - speakers, display.  One thing is that I am not able to read my books as comfortably as one of the older Kindles with the non-glare surface.  In fairness, though, I have had cataract surgery so my eyes are rather sensistive doing close up things.  Love the case and the fact I can just close it and I'm done!Well done, Amazon.  It was worth the wait for me.UPDATE - Sadly, after awhile the browser kept shutting down and automatically putting the device in sleep mode when using WIFI.  This started pretty much right after I got it and thought I must have kept hitting the power button to put it in sleep. It got continually worse until I had to return it.

Reviews.Title: First tablet for me
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Got this today and it is lovely.  Does not feel cheap and set-up was lightning fast.Things I like a lot:It gets better wi-fi reception than any other device in my place.The screen is lovely and the aspect ration is fantastic for watching HD videos.  There is barely any of the screen blocked out.Downton Abbey is free for Amazon Prime!  I have been happily watching episodes for the past 2 hours.App purchases are easy and so far everything I use is available in the app store.Games play wellThe sound is FANTASTIC.  My smartphone and laptop have Beats audio and the fire is actually better sounding over the speakers.Things I am still figuring out:Syncing of some things here and there.  I got the Epicurious app and cannot figure out how to send ingredient lists to my phone so I can pick up stuff while shopping.Some of my video files from my computer are not supported file formats.  Not the end of the world...but now I have to convert them.I still prefer the look of e-ink for books.  Kindle keyboard, you are still needed.The battery icon does not change when the device is charging and since I have cats that can turn off powerstrips it would be good if it let me know that is was charging successfully.

Reviews.Title: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
Reviews.Author: Christine in Long Beach
Reviews.Content: I just got my Kindle Fire 8.9 HD yesterday, so I plan to update the review as I get to know it better.It's my first tablet device and I am, so far, feeling pretty lukewarm.  Initially, I was reluctant to get an iPad because they are more expensive, can't use Flash, and I'm aready familiar with the MS and Android operating systems.  Of course, now Adobe that won't support flash for any tablets, that's a moot point.Visually, this Kindle is fantastic.  Good resolution, readable in different light and from different angles.  I give it high marks for that.  The battery life seems pretty good, but I've been spoiled by my Droid Razr Maxx and now have high standards.The one application I was really looking forward to, to be able to read the New Yorker on my Kindle, is completely buggy.  I spoke with a nice man at Amazon App customer service, and he told me that it's a known problem and the developer (Conde Nast) will need to fix it.  Bummer on that, but I'm hoping for a fix shortly.My biggest complaint is the location of the USB connection - bottom center if you're holding this in "landscape" mode.  I bought the leather cover, which works as a stand, so that we can watch movies, but with the Kindle plugged in, you can't use the stand!  That's CRAZY!  Who among us wouldn't want to keep it plugged in (unless you're in a plane) while watching a movie?  Otherwise, you've drained it completely.  The Kindle Fires from last year have the USB access on the short side - wayyyy more practical.The leather cover has its own issues, and I'll review those on the appropriate page.Interim verdict:  3 out of 5.  Good but not as great as I had hoped for.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Freezes
Reviews.Author: David White
Reviews.Content: I bought my Dad the Kindle Fire for his birthday and it froze constantly.  The replacement has been no better and freezes constantly, also.  If you google kindle freeze on the internet, this problem is all over the place and seems to be a common ailment.

Reviews.Title: Excellent!
Reviews.Author: lloyd a. pulliam
Reviews.Content: Bought this to replace the smaller Kindle my wife has. This is her Christmas present and need I say she couldn't wait till Christmas to start using it! She loves it!!! P.S. three weeks after I bought it Amazon came out with a $50 promotional discount on it. I called them yesterday and asked if they would give the discount to me even though I bought it before they offered it. No problem, they credited my Visa! Amazon you people are AWESOME!!!!!

Reviews.Title: Exactly what was advertised - very satisfied
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Stanton
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" from Amazon, along with some accessories, and all I can say, well done Amazon. Everything was delivered on time, well packaged and does exactly what it's suppose to do. This is a Christmas gift for my wife and I couldn't wait until Christmas, so I gave it to her today, the same day I received it. The Kindle Fire HD 8.9 was my choice after doing weeks worth of researching reviews and talking to friends. She absolutely loves it and that means everything to me. Just to see how excited she is as she learns about it is priceless. I have ordered other products from Amazon and have always been satisfied with the product and their service. I am so pleased and impressed with this Kindle and with Amazon. I would recommend both to everyone. Thank you again.

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: E. Henry "Crafty Jean"
Reviews.Content: Although I have a Nook basic book reader, I decided to purchase the Kindle Fire. The HD screen is awesome! It is easy to use by an older semi-techie like myself. I like the carousel of your current/favorite choices. Most of the time it will be used for books or games, but the ability to access other things is great!

Reviews.Title: It All Depends What You Need
Reviews.Author: A. Anderson "ann0314"
Reviews.Content: I have tried out a LOT of different services now , we have iPods (4) and a father with the upper end iPad, we have a cellphone and had a tablet that was Google/Android based, we own a Surface and now we own Kindles (3). Yes I know we jump around a lot LOL. That is because we are trying to find that good balance between features, affordability, longevity, customer service, and ease that meets our needs with the stress on affordability because we are a family of 4 and this technology moves so fast that by the time you buy xyz 3, the new 6 is coming out LOL and keeping up can get VERY pricey on a family budget. My review is about contrasting the differences from my perspective:Customer Service (10/10):In this category for me, Amazon and the Kindle win, hands down. EXCELLENT customer service and I don't mean or take that word lightly at all. I've had to call all 4 companies for things and by FAR Amazon has been the best to deal with. I truly commend them for that in a time where it seems that area lacks more and more.Stability and Speed (7/10):Here I think the iPad/iPods/iPhones win it. Having used all the varying systems by far I think the iPads are the most stable and quick. That said, since the other companies are playing catchup, I would expect that to be so. The Kindle to me falls not terribly behind though. It does freeze here and there and I have had to do a shutdown/restart on occasion, more then with the iPods/iPad, but it isn't to the frequency that I have had to with other products so for me it isn't far off pace.Ease of Use/Base System Features (6.5/10):If you are coming from an iWhatever, you are probably going to come up a bit irritated and possibly baffled and very well may not initially like the Kindle. I know initially when we got ours I was "underwhelmed" especially with how things are setup. In this aspect I think iPads and Android systems have a leg up especially if you are like me and are a bit of an organizational freak. There are NO folders here, no way to move around or order things "your way". To me this was probably the BIGGEST issue I had with the Kindle. If you are someone new to tablets and this is your first, I think the Kindle is pretty straight forward and easy enough to figure out quickly. I know my 11 year old was off and running with it almost instantly."Fun" Applications (9/10):In this area the Kindle is right in line with the rest. For a kid actually BETTER then the other three in terms of Parental Controls and services geared to keep your kids happy without the worry of your child using your credit card accidentally purchase to purchase something (though I will say I have less experience with this feature in the iPads so am speaking more about the Google and Microsoft systems for handling this which are both not so hot especially if you are a family with kids and adults using the same account or wishing to. On the application front, the worst of the bunch is the Surface which has a lot of NOTHING at the moment :( It is new so somewhat expected but I wasn't prepared for quite how anemic their selection really is. Probably one of the largest areas where the Surface falls very flat.Productivity (7/10):If you are looking for a tablet to Browse the net, I think iPad wins it. The Kindles and Android based tablets do well though for the casual user but for a power user you may find the Kindle a bit laggy. If you are looking for something to check e-mail the iPad, Androids, and Kindle all do well. The Surface though has a HUGE issue there. You have to use internet apps to check your e-mail if you have pop3 accounts...REALLY? O.o LOL If you are wanting to use MS Office products the the Surface wins. The rest do have apps that "work" but they do fall short in some areas so you wanna research if you choose this or one of the others to be sure there is something that does what you need. I will say if looking for something more for "school" for a child, the Surface, iPad, or Android tablets that run higher may be better. This system is good for general things listed above but not necessarily strong if you are looking for it to be a laptop replacement for heavy typing and taking notes etc. Great though for browsing forums, getting e-mail, internet, and light work.Reading (10/10):This is handled pretty well across the board with the availability of the Kindle app on most everything these days, though being able to borrow books if you are a Prime Member once a month or being able to restrict what your kids are reading is handled best by using the Physical Kindle.Movies, Music, and Sound (10/10):Strangely enough, the Kindle won on this level for me for a couple reasons (the Surface takes a good second because of the ability to add SD and flash cards to expand its size as do some of the Android systems) Amazon, unknown to me, has "tablet" editions of their movies...I LOVE THIS. If I buy a movie, Amazon gives you a full res version and a mobile version. If you DL the mobile version and put it on the tablet it takes up about 1/2 the space as the same movie on the other systems which means you can put double the movies on it. You do lose some resolution but if it's to keep kids busy on a long car ride its WONDERFUL. If you are more into the quality and want the HD etc though that is there still as an option as well. I also liked the Amazon Prime aspect in this area as well, giving access to lots of movies with your membership. Granted on this Kindle remember you have to have wifi to use Prime. On the music and sound side, I found the speakers on my Kindle to be by FAR the best of the group. The sound is actually REALLY nice. I have to admit I was impressed.Affordability (10/10):Definitely between the Kindles and the Google/Android units I think. For what you are getting for the price I think both these systems are doing a nice job. The iPad is great but not necessarily affordable for the average person especially when you consider what you have now will be outdated in a year or so (if you are lucky) if money is an issue, I would definitely consider these two systems though I won't say the Surface or iPads are unreasonable for what they do, just with their added features etc also have added cost. What that is worth to you really is a personal thing though :)To close (thank heavens right) after getting past the initial shock of how different this system was to the other 3 (especially the Apple system which OS wise I personally like most), I have really enjoyed it and would most definitely recommend it though whether it is best for you really does depend (as you can see above) what it is you are looking for. Fun, Affordability, For a Child, Productivity, Work etc. But for a general use Tablet for a child, reading, browsing the net without a laptop in your lap, I think this tablet definitely does it's job and very very nicely :) My whole family was happy with this purchase and I have recommended it to quite a few friends etc now especially those with kids or looking for an inexpensive solution to the Tablet quest.

Reviews.Title: I love my Kindle
Reviews.Author: Krystal
Reviews.Content: I'll be truthful, I love my Kindle.  I'm new to the tablet world and find it so easy to walk around and do anything i want with my Kindle in hand.  It gives me a whole new view on apps, reading books, watching movies (especially since i have Prime!) and looking at images.As I said, in love, however there are a few things that make me wonder why they didn't catch some bugs before shipping these out to customers.  They are the following:* The Web seems to never be able to successfully open a Webpage the first time when clicking through from an app.  It never fails to ask if i want to reopen my tab because the Web failed at opening it the first time.* My "Photo" option to take photos seems to always freeze.  It will then disable me from taking a photo.* I seem to have to "touch" on something more than once for it to decide to open.I have had my kindle for only 10 days, I think its a great tablet, but think it also could be improved.

Reviews.Title: The Kindle Audio Book Experience
Reviews.Author: Mylrea Estell "Lush Vineyard"
Reviews.Content: I received my Kindle Fire HD 8.9", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 32 GB - Includes Special Offers about two weeks ago. There are plenty of reviews about the overall conformation and performance of the Kindle tablets, but very little about the audio book and Whispersync experience.  Amazon has a selection of free classic books for Kindle, each of which has a companion narration, also free, available from Audible. These are an excellent selection of performances by well know narrators, three of which I had previously purchased myself. I highly recommend new Kindle owners "buy" these free titles and their companion audios.  Whispersync works in multiple ways across multiple devises. I can read or listen to a book on my Kindle, then pick up where I left off, reading or listening using the Kindle app on my Android phone. I especially like the immersive reading function, where the text on the screen is subtly highlighted and "turns the page" following the simultaneous narration.  The immersive reading does not work with books borrowed from The Amazon Prime lending library or with Audible narrations and Kindle books borrowed from the public library, but is very effective when using purchased Kindle books. Audible titles are often deeply discounted when the Kindle book is purchased FIRST. Unfortunately if I want Kindle books to mate to my hundreds of previously purchased audio books, they must be bought at full price. Not a big deal for me as I mostly listen on the go, but no early-adopter wants to feel that they have missed out due to their patronage.  My sole disappointment in the devise has been with the speaker volume, particularly with regard to audio books. I find the maximum volume to be adequate for steaming video from Netflix or Amazon Prime video, but for some reason the audio books are much lower in volume, too quiet for my middle aged ears, even when the Kindle is set on full volume. The speaker capacity is clearly there, and the audiobook volume is fine when I use earphones with my MP3 player, phone or the Kindle, but I can barely hear audio books on the external speakers when holding my Kindle while alone in a quiet room.  My mother has macular degeneration, and audio books are important to her. I had hoped that she could use my Kindle, and the clear controls on its bright screen to access the library of Audible titles I have acquired. She simply could not hear the narrations. Of course she could use headphones, and I am considering Bluetooth speakers, but these extraneous devises are needlessly complex for an elderly person.  I wonder if a software update might allow higher volume audio book playback?  I would also like to see an Overdrive app for the Kindle so that I can use audio books from my state library system. I listen to about 100 audio books a year, most of them free from the library. That does not keep me from being a good Amazon/Audible customer. I have subscribed to Audible's one or two book credits per month program for nearly four years, and have bought more books at the reduced member rate. As long as I'm unable to use my Kindle to download library audio books, I need to use a parallel set of devises for most of my listening. I look forward to software which would allow me to integrate all of my reading and listening.  Since Amazon has purchased Audible and has made great strides to integrate the Kindle reading and listening experience, it is clear that they have identified this as part of the future of reading. Please Amazon programmers do something so that I can set my Kindle down in a room and listen to an audio book as I go about my business.

Reviews.Title: Major bugs never get resolved, quickly loses product software support (no updates).
Reviews.Author: Digitalmaster
Reviews.Content: I can't recommend this product because of the issues that I have had with it the past 4 months that I have owned it.First, when it comes to hardware, I would rate it 3/5. It loses two stars because the power button is on the side, right where the average user holds it to browse the web and play games. Because of the location of the button, it is constantly being depressed, putting it in sleep mode, and having to repeatedly unlock it during a game, or while browsing.The Silk browser is buggy, and I regularly have problems with it crashing. In all fairness, it could be the onscreen keyboard, as most all of my problems happen when the keyboard dialog comes up. Regardless, it makes this unusable for most things that I actually use this for.It is good for videos, and as an Amazon Prime subscriber, it is a great unit, but it spends more time on my shelf due to the issues mentioned above.It's a shame, because I really wanted to love this unit, and less than a month after purchasing, it was replaced with a new unit addressing some of the physical button problems that I mentioned above; problems Amazon told me that they had not heard from other customers... Despite the fact that they addressed the problem in the new version.As a regular Amazon customer, that is using their cloud service, prime, and owns a few Kindle's, this was my most disappointing purchase.

Reviews.Title: Not perfect, but still a great device
Reviews.Author: A. Rosario
Reviews.Content: I was debating between a Nexus 10 and the Kindle Fire HD.  Both devices have their advantages and disadvantages.The Nexus has the Google Play Store along with all of its apps, but you cannot access things such as Amazon Prime without using the browser.  Also, getting a Nexus 10 requires you to work with Google Play Store support which is not always the greatest as I have had to deal with and still am on an issue regarding a music purchase.The Kindle does not have access to the Google Play Store, but it does have the Amazon Appstore as well as Amazon Prime access.  The Amazon Appstore has most of the apps the Google Play Store has including Netflix and many of the games.  The biggest gripe I have with the Kindle is that for some reason Amazon does not offer any of the official Google apps such as Gmail, GTalk, Google Maps and Google Music.  There is a work around to get these apps on the device as I have installed them myself.  You have to authorize installation of 3rd party apps on the device and download the .apk file from a trusted website.  There are numerous websites out there that have official Google apps all you have to do is search for the .apk for the specific app.  Unfortunately, there is no support for the apps this way so you do not get updates and many times the icon looks blurry and not HD on the Kindle carousel.  Other than that, the Kindle is a great device especially when combined with Amazon Prime.  I am using a stylus with it now and find it works better with it.  The WIFI antennas are very good for the device and can connect to very weak signals with ease, would not recommend connecting to just any network as there are hackers out there looking to phish for anything.Amazon Prime is great as it not only grants you access to the numerous TV shows and movies Amazon has under contract, but it allows to borrow books for free from Amazon.As far as the price with the offers goes, I opted to include the offers as it knocked $15 off the price and the offers are only on the device when it is locked.  Upon waking the device (pressing the power button) an offer is displayed.  You swipe to unlock the device and the offer is gone, not to be seen again until you press the power button again once the device is off.  It is not bothersome at all.  I have not had any problems with the offers thing and at times I have been interested by the offers.I opted for the Kindle, purchased December of 2012, as it was cheaper and it allowed me to access Amazon Prime shows with no problem.  I also liked the Kindle reading aspect of it.  The device does have a setting under reading font, Sepia, which makes it so much easier to read than a regular white screen.  This is actually on any device that you download the Kindle app for including cell phones.I would recommend this device to anyone looking for a tablet that allows for a lot of media consumption as it has access to Amazon Prime with ease as well as Netflix.  In addition, it would be a better device for families as it allows parents to lock parts of the device to prevent children from purchasing or accessing things they are not supposed to.

Reviews.Title: This is by far the best tablet out there for the price!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Kevin Hearn"
Reviews.Content: Let me just start off by saying that I am not an apple fanboy, so I have never truly been impressed with iPads or any other Apple product after 2000. I don't feel like the value is there, and as someone who doesn't have a ton of cash to drop on something like a tablet, I just can't justify spending minimum $500-800 on one.I have had my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet (32 GB) since they first came out in November and all I can say is: WOW! These tablets are amazing! I can tell you that it has literally changed my life (in a good way). :) I am going to list my comments individually in sections so y'all can see the parts that are most applicable to you.Build quality:I like the very solid, ergonomic feel of this Kindle. It is light enough to hold in one hand comfortably, yet I never feel like I'm going to drop it due to its weight (unlike my Galaxy S2 Smartphone). I do not, however, like the buttons on the top that control volume and the on/off. These buttons are almost completely flush to the device and it can be very difficult to press them. I also continually press the wrong button on the volume rocker to change the volume on the device because it feels backwards to me. I also wish the device could know when I changed it from landscape to portrait and adjust the volume knob to be a little more intuitive that way. That may sound like nitpicking, but it can be an annoyance.Screen:On that note, the screen on this thing is just gorgeous. I have used it outside, inside, full light, no light, everywhere you can imagine and I have never had a problem seeing anything on the device anywhere. I live in South Texas and it can be quite bright here in the daytime (especially around noon-2pm) and I have spent many Saturdays outside reading my Kindle without any problems. It does require more brightness out of the screen which reduces battery life, but I never read outside for more than two or three hours so I have never had an issue with running out of power. I cannot say enough positive things about this screen!User Interface:I love the Amazon Silk browser, it is great and works seamless with almost everything. I did the infamous flash workaround with the dolphin browser (google it) and that works great as well. The only complaint I have about the apps is...sometimes I don't want apps to come onto the carousel after I use them. I am major OCD and I like to have my carousel totally empty besides the book that I am reading. I like the apps and I use them often, but I have to remove them from the carousel periodically. I wish there was an option that said "do not put apps on carousel", or even a list of apps you could put on the device that would do the same. Again, nitpicky....but a tad bit annoying.Reading:What can I say about the reading on this device? It is superb. From magazines, to books, to newspapers...everything is great. I have never had a problem with any of this and it works great. I love getting my Men's Fitness and my fiance loves getting Cosmo as well. They are always crisp and clear (gotta love that HD screen) and are never glitchy or freezing. This is really where this Kindle has changed my life. I am a teacher and it is very difficult for me to fit certain books into my backpack for school...but it is easy to fit my Kindle in there. I have read more books in the past five months of owning this thing than I had in a year.Ordering:Part of the reason I have had so much success with my reading is that it is very easy to order books from the device. I have bought books and had family members buy me books for my birthday and never had a problem. It is almost TOO easy to buy things for this device...because I spend a lot of money on books to read every month. Again, no complaints. It is far easier to make a buy on my device (which I keep with me perpetually) instead of having to remember to hit up a bookstore on the way home. And, let me add, cheaper to buy on the Kindle.Videos:I bought extra storage space to put my DVR shows on my Kindle for watching at various points when I am not home. Besides the fact that the only content it plays is .MP4 (a tad annoying) but the videos are always crisp and clear and never have to buffer or queue. I have absolutely zero complaints about video or playback on the device.Overall I would say that I have absolutely zero regrets with my Kindle. I have nitpicky concerns, but they are far outweighed by the benefits of this device. If you are like me and looking for something to make reading books and magazines easier-or even watching videos or movies, this is definitely the Kindle for you. I hope this review helps any of you that are on the fence about buying a Kindle Fire HD 8.9". I love it so much, in fact, my fiance is getting one for her birthday, so she stops stealing mine. :)

Reviews.Title: My third version of the kindle
Reviews.Author: W. Dietrich "WD"
Reviews.Content: I have had all 3 versions of the kindle from the original which was just a reader with no color ink (which i really enjoyed) to the 2011 kindle fire to the new Kindle Fird HD 8.9.I am giving the 8.9 4 stars for one reason when I flip the kindle sideways when reading a book I get two pages at once instead of one page which is what I get if I am holding the kindle up right.  There may be a way to fix this but I am not sure how.  They say the new Kindle Fire HD has a sharper picture than the original Kindle Fire but for my eyesight I can not tell the difference.  What I do like is the size is awsome and makes playing games like angry birds or fruit ninja even better.  The backlight for reading makes reading with the lights off a breeze (does not hurt my eyes at all).  I love that amzon imported my music onto my kindle / cloud and the sound is very crisp when I use my earphones its like listiening to my MP3.  I also thought it was easy to bring over my photos from facebook to my kindle so I can share them with friends. However there are times when I am using my kindle that my hand will accedintaly hit the off button and I need to restart the kindle which is easy but still a drag this happens to me at least twice a day (i use the kindle for several hours daily).  Also, for what you pay it would nice to be receive a wall charger instead of the usb plug.  I paid extra for the rapid charger and did not notice much of a difference in charging time from my normal phone charger that has the same size charger.  All in all I love the kindel the ease it provides in shopping amazon, the ability to play my music, the importing of photos and most of all the ability to read with the lights off.  I dont like the fact that I often shut down the kindle by accident, the fact it did not have a wall charger and that when you hold sideways you get two pages instead of one.

Reviews.Title: Best kindle yet!
Reviews.Author: Staci B
Reviews.Content: I have had 3 different Kindles (the 6inch wireless reading device, the Kindle fire and now the Fire HD 8.9inch) and they get better each time! I have not had any problems with them each time I have had to replace them it has been due to theft or one got broken in a car accident. So happy to have a new one with the bigger screen and such high quality speakers. The images on the screen are so colorful and bright. Thought about getting an iPad but glad that I stayed with the Kindle brand! I love the Prime membership and being able to borrow books and movies! That is so wonderful. I do wish you could play games without being on wifi, but I understand that most of them have ads that make it able to be free apps and they need wifi to be able to run those ads. That is really my only complaint, for the most part I read so it works wonderfully.

Reviews.Title: LOVE
Reviews.Author: Carissa Alexander
Reviews.Content: I don't even have the words as to how amazing my Kindle Fire is.  This is my first kindle and I am amazed at all it can do.  Why get an expensive IPAD, when you can get this kindle.  Also, I love how easy it is to load stuff onto from Amazon.  While my kindle was still in the mail being shipped to me, I had a free book downloaded onto it.  As soon as I turned on my new kindle, the free book was there.  Amazing.  I have also watched a few movies on it from Amazon Prime. Great picture and great sound.  ZERO complaints!

Reviews.Title: I like it!
Reviews.Author: Leonora M. "Leonora M."
Reviews.Content: I've had my Kindle Fire HD for about a week now. I wasn't loving it when I first received it and thought about returning it and purchasing an Ipad or other tablet. The more that I'm using it, the more I like it. I'm not a techie and this is my first tablet. I mainly use this for internet browsing, checking emails, watching movies, and playing a few games. I have not had any crashes or errors. I have been able to side load a couple of apps not available through Amazon and they work fine. I am also able to watch Youtube videos with no problem. I am an Amazon Prime member and also have a subscription to Audible so the easy access for their content is great for me. That was really the reason that I chose this tablet over others. So far, I think I made the right decision.

Reviews.Title: Does everything I want it to do!!
Reviews.Author: jade
Reviews.Content: I researched various tablets for a long time before I decided to buy the HD 8.9.  Why did I settle on this one over all the rest?  Because during my research I kept coming back to one fundamental question...what will I use the tablet for?  I'm already an Amazon Prime member and ultimately I decided I wasn’t looking for a work horse tablet to run productivity software; I wanted a right sized media device that also lets me surf the web, check e-mail, run apps and watch YouTube videos.  And I didn’t want to pay a fortune for it.  The HD 8.9 fits that bill nicely.  I travel a lot so I sprung for the 32 Gb version which I highly recommend.A lot has been commented on about the location of the power plug port and design of the power and volume buttons but I found once I got used to the buttons it was pretty easy to find them.  Even though the volume buttons don’t show which increases or lowers the sound it’s actually easy to figure out; up is for louder and down is for lower. But I think the power port would have been better placed at the opposite end of the on/off switch because as it is now you can’t use the case as a stand unless you do what I did and turn the kindle upside down in the case.  That way the power can be plugged into the top allowing use of the case as a stand.As for web browsing I am very satisfied in how the browser works for me.  It’s not the smoothest and fastest browser but it works well enough.  Overall I really like the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 because it fits what I want to use it for.  I use my laptop and desktop for productivity…I use my Kindle for entertainment (video, books, games, surfing the Web).

Reviews.Title: My opinion as it is.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have only owned two tablets The fire 1st gen and now this. I use Amazon alot for shopping as well as my media needs. So when looking into a tablet (and I did compare alot of them) I found that I just wanted to stick with Amazon.My take on the fire HD....The ADS. for me not a problem its only on screen saver(at this time no plans to remove them)Recommendations that appear. Not a problem I happen to like them there. I use on Amazon when looking for new items anyway so them being on home screen to me seems a plus.Silk. It has no adobe flash plug-in. Not a problem with as yet was able to watch youtube mobile and visit all my normal web sites.Reading. I have to say I find reading on it as easy as first Fire even better, It has text-to-speech, and some books can be read by a real person if you also have the audible book. Which is actual kinda of cool. Gave it a try with Acheron by Kenyon which I happen to own in both formats (kindle and audible). It adds a new depth to the story. The x-ray for books is nice as well, was able to get info on the characters on the page and thier role in book.Video. Nice picture and sound has happy with it.Apps. Now apps are a problem seems alot of apps that work on Fire 1st gen do not work on HD. Don't know if its Amazon or developer issue (hope fix is just an update away). That being said there are apps I wanted on Fire 1st gen that do work for the HD which is a plus.Over all Im happy to have updated to the new HD model of the fire (which I owned for a year and was very happy with).Difference I like the bigger screen, more memory, and speakers and the bluetooth is nice. Paired with my Jabbra Steet 2 I was able to leave fire in room and go next door. FYI the control buttons on the Jabbra do work to control music on fire was able to skip song and replay remotly. For me this will allow me to use the music player on Fire more easly while walking vs the 1st gen where I had to do all from screen in bright sun light (not fun). In closing I love my Fire it was great buy if you use Amazon alot for media even if you dont at price and with Amazon's nice customer service give it try, I think you will be happy. I am :)

Reviews.Title: An early Christmas present
Reviews.Author: Ordinary guy
Reviews.Content: I bought  this Kindle for my wife because she really wanted a I-pad type tablet. The affordable price of this high end Kindle made the choice easy. I took advantage of the AT&T; 4G special offer but will only use this connection occasionally since you go through the included monthly usage quickly.  The Wi-Fi works great off my wireless router and gets better reception throughout my home than other Wi-Fi devices I own.The picture quality is fantastic and the sound is good for such tiny speakers. Hi-def movies really bring out the best of this Kindle.  Lots of useful and fun apps available. NetFlix, Facebook and E-Mail work great. Angry birds fly in HD.We're still on a learning curve but the learning is fun and easy.BTW.  I had to use Amazon's excellent customer service/support because of a Wi-Fi issue.  The service rep solved the problem on the phone quickly and to my complete satisfaction.Very impressive piece of equipment. And, like most electronic devices it doesn't come with an instruction book (setup is easy) AND you have to buy the A/C charger seperately or charge it through your computers USB port (it does come with a USB cable).

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: aggie93
Reviews.Content: The more I play with the Kindle Fire HD, the more I love it! It takes a little getting used to after the iPad, but the price difference totally makes it worth it.  I don't do anything fancy on it - Facebook, Pinterest, email - so it suits my needs just great. And the movie quality is great! So pleased with my early Christmas present.

Reviews.Title: New Kindle is awesome
Reviews.Author: bluebell
Reviews.Content: Just received mine and love it! Picture quality is great and sound is really good. Worth every penny.  This is my 2nd Kindle. I also have the Asus tf300 and this beats it hands down. You cant go wrong shopping Amazon. UPDATE-Everyone is complaining about ads on this new kindle fire hd but that is garbage. None on mine. If you want to get rid if those annoying "customers also bought this" ads just go to applications, Amazon home recommendations and select hide.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G LTE Wireless Tablet
Reviews.Author: Jack
Reviews.Content: We have only had this unit for three days and haven't spent a lot of time with it yet. Also, this is our first tablet, so we are learning the tricks of the trade, so to speak. I am pleased with the build quality; a solid unit and the screen resolution is fantastic. Wi-fi is fast and the device responds to input as expected. Not thrilled with the ads, but I suppose that is life in today's world. It is a little early for me to give a full review because we need more time with it, so I am rating four stars until we gain some expertice and experience with it.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9"...more perfect than Glock "perfection"
Reviews.Author: Hojo
Reviews.Content: This Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is incredibly light and thin, I can't believe it!  It operates MUCH faster than the original Kindle Fire and the screen is beautiful, my wife saw a picture of me on it and said "it looks so real like I could just touch you" and it was very easy to download all the programs off of the Cloud onto my the new Kindle.  How did I live life pre-Kindle Fire?  A full entertainment center all in the palm of my hand!

Reviews.Title: The inconvenience is not worth it.
Reviews.Author: Houstonian
Reviews.Content: I have had to replace this Kindle three time between my two kids in the last four months. With one the original kindle lasted just over one year. With the other the kindle HD Fire only last eight months. In both bases it was the kindle stopped charging and responding. Amazon needs to do something about this. It is just too much of a coincidence.To add insult to injury the replacement for the second was defective as there were lines coming across the screen. thus had to order a third kindle. Amazon what are you doing about these defects.

Reviews.Title: Wow
Reviews.Author: david
Reviews.Content: I'm not sure how people can put less than 5 stars on this product, especially if you look at the price.The screen: beautifulThe sound: not as loud as I thought it would be, but the quality is very good. When you watch a movie, you feel the sound comes from everywhere: left, right, behind that's a very good experience.The OS: Perfect for Amazon content, perfect for Netflix and the mp4 I downloaded on the device. There are several apps available for free or purchase and there will be loads to come.The internet browser: I don't like it, I'm going to sideload a better one.Magazines: They look great, but I believe the device is too small for a real good experience (you need to zoom).Oh.. I forgot, I don't get annoyed by the ads, I just got a $2 free voucher for renting video on demand. And the recommendations, I like them, I can see other movies that are prime eligible, that I can watch for free. Recommendations are not ads, and they can be disabled in the settings, for free.

Reviews.Title: 8.9' Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Sherri Leasum "Sherri Leasum forestwolf"
Reviews.Content: I just got my 8.9" HD 32g, wifi only ... I LOVE IT. I was amazed at the difference in screen quality between it and the 7" HD i also have. I bought the 8.9" to be my bedside streaming device, and i can already say that it was an EXCELLENT choice. The 7" works well for taking to work etc. But the clarity of the screen on the 8.9" HD make it a wonderful bedside companion for watching shows etc without having to bother anyone else around you. I have arthritis in my hands so I bought a Levlo clamp on stand for my bedside which allows me to support it and whatever viewing angle is the most comfortable and also move it back out of the way while using it as my alarm clock, My 8.9" HD beats the heck out of the Ipad mini's screen and i have twice the storage as he does for the same price points.I love Amazon and the Kindle Line of products.. i also have the new Paperwhite which i love as well. My only complaint is that we do not YET have the same resource for apps that Apple and Google have.. but i am trusting that Amazon is working to get us there.DOLBY SPEAKERS ARE FABULOUS and again BEAT THE IPAD MINI'S ALL TO PIECES.

Reviews.Title: kindle fire HD 8.9 "
Reviews.Author: sharon marshall
Reviews.Content: I'm really loving my kindle HD 8.9 just that few inches in screen size makes an amazing difference in watching a movies or video. For me much less tiring on the eyes and HD quality i enjoy. Amazon should have provided a charger I thought that was rather cheap

Reviews.Title: Low vision reader liking accessibility features
Reviews.Author: Ohio Reader "Elderly, bookish person, omnivor...
Reviews.Content: I was delighted with my Kindle Fire 7" which offered a text size that I could read easily. Then Kindle Fire HD 8.9 came out offering, in addition to the features of KF 7", text-to-speech for e-books and improved sound for Audible books. So glad I switched. The text-to-speech engine is very good with few annoying mispronunciations and a convenient speed control. And Audibile books do sound SO much better. Music and video soundtracks are also much improved with the new audio system. KF HD has a helpful, relevant accessibility setting that adds voice to the control buttons so the tablet is much easier to use for the vision impaired, especially since there is no text-size choice for control buttons. I suspect that if the 7" KF HD has the same accessibility features, it would be just as easy to use and a bit less cumbersome. Time now to explore KF HD's non-bookish features, so I just bought an e-manual to point me to the other cool features. More later......

Reviews.Title: Amazon finally has accessibility options.  THANKS!!!!!
Reviews.Author: okiedan "Pro Bono Publico"
Reviews.Content: The reviews are in...and they all look good.  Thanks to all the other reviewers for taking the time to help us all out.  I want to post a short review that may outline a few things others have missed or glossed over.A VERY sincere thank you to Amazon!  After years of back and forth between Amazon and various advocacy groups Amazon has surprised THIS user with a wonderful gift.  I did not expect it and frankly had heard that Amazon once again was going to forget about their visually challenged users.  Not  so!After years of waiting for Amazon..... they finally have accessibility options on the Fire.You can have voice over turned on with explore by touch.  FINALLY.  It also offers a voice guide and an orientation lock.For those of us with vision issues this is a BIG deal.  If I did not have the free accessibility programs that come free on every Apple device I would be lost.  I am heavily invested in the Amazon eco system and read often using the kindle for mac application and activate my voice over and listen to my books.  Conversely I am also heavily invested in the Apple ecosystem.  I chose Apple because of the totally free accessibility features.  If I used a PC I would have to buy a program that cost almost $700.00 just to do the same things I now do for free on my iMac.  No I am not saying apple is better....this is about accessibility for all people.  It is about preserving and protecting the rights of the millions of people who are different in some way than the so called normal person.I have both the 4G LTE 64gb and the WiFi only 32gb.As expected their is no real difference between the two.If you need more storage ,I do, and if you want to be able to do basic Internet activity while mobile ,I do, then the larger capacity 4G is a good choice.Setup on the ATT network was fast and easy.Out of the box the initial startup on both was very easy.  Once joined to my network it downloaded the latest OS and rebooted.The WiFi signal is in fact very good...or I should say the WiFi reception is very good.  I can travel from the front of my house to the far reaches of my backyard and still get a fair signal.  In the house the 5.0ghz signal is strong and consistent.The screen is magnificent.  The clarity and smooth operation are a real joy.  Sometimes if I have too many things happening with it..... i.e...... downloading an Audible book.... downloading some music.... and still attempting to use an app or read a book the device will have a little hiccup.  That however is very rare and easily managed by not trying to do everything at one time.My wife uses Medscape at the hospital and it looks great on the 8.9 screen.  It only took 15 minutes to download all of the required content for this app to work.I am amazed at how fast my content downloads over the WiFi.  I was able to add 30 audible books and 300+ books in a matter of a few hours.  The audible books took the longest.  I found that if I left my devices plugged in to ac and turned off the auto sleep function....my content downloaded a lot faster.If you are using the text to speech application you will be pleased to know it sounds great..... over the Dolby speakers.I also have found that if I turn the brightness down to a minimal level.... using Sepia mode with font at largest I can top light my Fire with mighty bright light to simulate a more Pearl Ink display.  I so this due to the extreme eye strain I suffer when looking at a bright light.......  I was amazed to find this works.  It might look a little strange but who cares!I mount my Fire on a Bookholder stand and use high powered glasses to be able to read the larger print on the Fire.  I do wish they made a couple of larger fonts... maybe later???So to sum it up.  Thanks to Amazon.  I truly thought you did not care about us.  I have been reading on blogs for months about how you would not do anything for special needs folks.  Now you have proved them to be wrong.UPDATE:  Using full accessibility options I have found the tablet easy to use.  The voice clearly tells me where I am on the screen. To open a book I move my finger over the menu to find the word book.  I hear it say book..... then I double click and the book opens.  To open the menu I use three finger swipe up to open and down to close.  Two fingers to change page.  Text to speech is at the bottom..and will open if I tap at the bottom of the screen.  I think I will try some bumps to see if they first will stick and second will not effect the display.  I have one good eye at 20/400 so I can use that to find a lot of things...but I want to know more..... could a totally blind person use bumps on a touch screen.  Will give it a try.  Wish I could get my hands on a few of the textbooks amazon is wanting to sell to schools....would like to see if they are accessible.When using Explore by Touch, use the following gestures to navigate:Unlock your KindleWith two fingers, swipe from right to left near the bottom of the screen.Open the Quick Settings menuWith two fingers, swipe down from the top of the screen.Scroll through items in the carousel and content libraries on the Home screenWith two fingers, swipe to the left or rightTurn pages in a bookWith two fingers, swipe to the left or rightDownload or open an itemDouble-tapMake menu selections onscreenDouble-tapThe Explore by touch also works with your music.  It will state where you are and also give you the artist...then the track name etc...IF you are blind or visually challenged like myself...and would like to discuss this NEW change please feel free to email me.  You can find my Amazon email address on my profile.  Just click on okiedan.

Reviews.Title: Fire HD with 4G LTE
Reviews.Author: Onegar
Reviews.Content: Bought the 8.9 Fire with the 4G LTE AT&T; service. After no direction at all on how to set up the AT&T; service we finally managed to find out how to make the payment for the service, only to find out it is $50 per month instead of $50 per year as advertised. We decided to go ahead and sign up and after Christmas we would deal with the difference in the cost. Got payment made,after (5) tries. We then tried to use the AT&T;,showing 3 bars of service strength, we would click on a link and all we would get was the little orange circle going around and around and nothing ever came up. Never one time did we get one website to open while hooked up to AT&T.; We got a notice this morning we had used up our monthly allotted data and that they needed another $50.I have canceled the AT&T; service and am returning the Kindle. The Kindle is probably a great tablet, but you need to stay away from the this one that claims it has 4G LTE AT&T;  service or you will waste $250 of your money like I did. I truly expected better from both of these companies.

Reviews.Title: Just wasn't impressed
Reviews.Author: adam3290
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 after a LOT of research into all the different tablet options. This seemed like the best bang for the buck, so I went ahead and purchased this item from Best Buy. I let it charge for a few hours before using it. Here is my unbiased, concise review so that it may help you in choosing a tablet.Display: Looks great. Text is crisp and clear, and video playback from the internet was very fast (almost instant) and looked very crisp. Amazon advertises the nice HD screen, and it definitely does deliver. Impressive.Sound: As advertised, this is the best sound available on a tablet. Music sounded awesome. I also watched a few HD movie previews from flixter that looked and sounded spectacular.Ease of Use: I am very used to android-based items, so it was very easy to jump into. Even for an apple user, I think the transition would be pretty much instant. The people giving this product negative reviews because it doesn't include an instruction booklet really need to get with the times. If you can't figure this thing out in 15-20 minutes, you have no business with a tablet.Build Quality: Device feels very solid and high quality. My issue is the buttons and the placement of the buttons. They are very flat and somewhat difficult to find. There is a volume button, and a button to shut off the screen (which also shuts off the device when held down). There were many times where I wanted to turn something up, but accidentally turned it down or shut the screen off. Kind of annoying.Web Browsing/Typing: Web browsing is fun and very smooth with this device over Wi-Fi. Pages load quickly and video playback is instant without any buffering or image quality issues. I walked around the house playing YouTube videos and got pretty far away from my Wi-Fi router without any changes in video playback. If you are just looking for a device that is small and able to surf the net with ease, you will definitely enjoy this despite a few issues noted below:- No flash. I knew this ahead of time, but you do not get flash on this device in case you didnt know. I found this to be slightly annoying, but not too bad. A lot of flash-based websites will simply direct the tablet to the mobile version which makes a big difference for some websites while remaining mostly the same for others.- Typing is SLOW. It is a major pain to type something long like an amazon review. SWYPE is AWFUL on this device. This is the major, major flaw. There is no auto-capitalizing, and no auto-spacing. I figured I would be able to swype a paragraph rather quickly, but since you have to hit the space button every time you swype a word, it gets to be very annoying and time consuming. What is the point of swype when you have to stop and hit space every time? For a end of 2012 android device, I thought this was a major mistake by Amazon.Apps: By far the biggest issue with this tablet. App selection is awful, as are the quality of some of the most popular apps. Most people know that Amazon runs a modified version of Android and does not have access to the Google Play Store. I knew this when I purchased the item, but figured it wouldn't be THAT different. I was wrong. App selection is extremely small, and most of the apps are dumb things like chess or puzzle games (not very useful). Popular apps are less functional and seem hastily made for the Kindle Fire. Facebook is among the worst apps for this device. The layout isn't user-friendly, and it has less functionality than a typical Android Facebook App. If you are used to Facebook functionality on a computer or Android phone, you will be disappointed with Facebook on the Kindle Fire HD.Most of the functional and popular apps you probably have on you Android phone are not available for the Kindle either.Ultimately, this lack of apps made me decide not to keep the Kindle.Overall:If you just want to use the internet, watch videos with fantastic image quality/sound, and buy things from Amazon then this tablet will be an excellent choice for you at an excellent price. If you enjoy flash-based websites, full Android functionality, access to Google Playstore, or want a computer-like tablet experience then you will surely be disappointed. You can purchase movies, albums, and typical Amazon items very easily with this device. Amazon lets you have unlimited cloud-based storage for all of the media you purchase from them which is a nice feature. The Kindle Fire HD came off to me as a very smart way for Amazon to sell more merchandise rather than being a fully functional tablet.Pros: Display, Sound, Web-Surfing, Media-Consumption capabilitiesCons: No flash, no expandable storage (even though you do have unlimited cloud storage for Amazon purchases), typing is awful, small selection of available apps, some of the most popular apps are non-existent or poorly madeAfter returning this item, I am continuing my research into a new tablet and am beginning to lean toward the Nexus 10 for an extra $100.00

Reviews.Title: Glitchy, unresponsive, battery killer.
Reviews.Author: Dean H Ravin
Reviews.Content: My  Kindle HD8.9  has  very short battery life, even in sleep mode it rapidly discharges it's battery. The touch screen is both inconsistent and un-responsive, frequently requiring several presses to input a single keystroke.Kindle's  operating system suffers frequent seizures,"SILK" web  browser locks up 2 or 3 times per hour. Overall, I was not satisfied with the Kindle HD 8.9

Reviews.Title: Doesnt Last Very Long
Reviews.Author: L. Williams
Reviews.Content: I have now purchase 7 Kindles, 6 of the 7" version, and 1 8.9" version. I loved them while they worked. The first one last 3 weeks before it would over heat and then not turn on. Amazon replaced it since it was within 30 days of purchasing. The charger only last 2-3 months tops before they stop working. And not one of my Kindles has lasted over a year before they either stop taking a charge, or they over heat and won't turn on.My other issue with the previous model was my children were able to purchase movies and make purchases even with the password protection on it. Amazon says it isn't possible, but some how my 3 year old was able to purchase a couple hundred dollars in movies and merchandise while I was in the hospital giving birth to his brother. Amazon refused to credit back the money for the movies my son purchased, and if I returned the merchandise I had to pay the shipping for the return. I also ordered a season pass for Teen Wolf II for my daughter, and it kept deleting off my account for almost 4 months, and I had to purchase the season through ITunes so my daughter could watch them as they released. Amazon would not credit the season pass when it wouldn't work either. So I no longer purchase season passes or movies through Amazon, and I don't leave an active credit card on my account either. I now purchase movies, TV series, Books, and Games through ITunes to play on my IPad and ITouch. So far I have not had an issue with my purchases from ITunes or being overcharged.I use to buy everything through Amazon, but their lack of customer service or quality has gone down hill the past year. While the Kindles worked they were great, but for the cost I have spent replacing them, I could have purchased 2 more Ipads.

Reviews.Title: Falls a little short
Reviews.Author: Doug
Reviews.Content: I'm new to pads. Bought my wife an iPad mini about a month ago. Had the Kindle for a couple of weeks now. I would give a slight edge to the Kindle on picture and sound quality. Unfortunately, it doesn't fair as well in most other categories. Processing power appears to be about 50% of the iPad's. Battery life is good (not as good as the iPad's) but it seems to use much more in sleep mode. The biggest surprise was WiFi performance. It is much slower than the iPad. I also give the iPad the edge on device navigation (ease of use). I was streaming a video today and had a total device lockup. And I do mean total. Couldn't even turn it off! Had to just set it down and wait for the battery to die. It was ok after that. If I had it to do over again, I would definitely go with another iPad.

Reviews.Title: Still on fire!!!
Reviews.Author: BertG007
Reviews.Content: I received my new Kindle Fire last week and it's exactly what I expected - awesome!The 8.9" is perfectly sized and the HD screen is razor sharp. I purchased the 7" Kindle last year and while a nice unit, here size matters and this Kindle rocks.

Reviews.Title: "Getting To Know You"
Reviews.Author: gagbit "gagbit"
Reviews.Content: I'm a "techie junkie".  But I also want an item that is easy to use, reliable, fast helps (uploads and downloads), and provides a multitude of functions.  I've gone through the transition from PC to laptop to notebook to tablet.  Because I "don't leave home without it" (my tablet) I want it to function just as well as at home (connection reliability, functionality).I recently decided to "go for it", and purchase the Kindle Fire HD 8.9, originally to free up my BB Playbook so I could give it to my Grandson.  I LOVED my Playbook, and was skeptical about the KF meeting my high expectations.  OK, I give....it's everything it's proposed to be, and WELL worth the cost.  The only thing I lost was a massive amount of GB (Playbook = 68GB, Kindle Fire = 16GB).  That's ok.I wondered if ease of use would be there as soon as I unpacked it.  Yup! I have yet to indoctrinate the bookstore/usage, or the movies, but that will happen.Is it an iPad? Of course not.  That's not it's sole purpose. Would I recommend this for those who don't need all the apps and fluff of an iPad at a reasonable cost?  A resounding "YES"!  I did an extensive review and research of the KF HD, and it got high marks for what I wanted it to do, without being tied to a MAC, and feeling my comfort zone with a PC.

Reviews.Title: In a word, the new k-FireHD 8.9" is awesome.
Reviews.Author: Michael Bridges
Reviews.Content: My wife (who is NOT computer skilled) took to it like a fish in water.  I think mostly because she was already comfortable with her android phone.  Everything they said that was good about it is has turned out to be true.  I got the 32GB one without the ads and it really functions quite like a tablet computer because of access to all the available apps.  I am so glad i bought this for my wife as an early Christmas present!

Reviews.Title: Worth the wait.
Reviews.Author: Sandra L Wood
Reviews.Content: This is my first tablet. I had been waiting since June for an announcement for the new Kindle.. I wanted something comparable to my friend's Ipad2, & less expensive.The only issue I have is  that you cannot get the Adobe Flash Player.. so if you're looking to watch videos from your FB, or FB games.. forget it. There are some games from FB that can be downloaded and played separately. I really miss the player.The graphics are so clear.It's very thin, and easy to figure out.Only one thing I don't understand, is that the speakers are on the back instead of the front. So while watching a movie I turn the volume up to the max. You can cup your hands around the speakers, and about triple  the volume.All in all , I am thrilled with the Kindle.Update: So its been a couple weeks with my first Kindle.Still loving it..except I do have 2 small complaints.. I didn't think the ad's would bother me.. but I have noticed they are popping up twice as much now. Even playing Angry Birds..the screen will go blank and a small ad will appear.I understand I can pay $15.00 to have it removed..I think I might. The other thing is when its charging the plug is at the bottom, so when you're playing an app that won't rotate..you have to be careful not to bend the plug.These items are not bad enough to return this Kindle!!

Reviews.Title: So far, so excellent.
Reviews.Author: JAZZY62
Reviews.Content: I am a long time techie and IT professional. Pound for Pound considering cost to quality this is one of the best buys I have experienced in recent years.  The hardware is very responsive and the Amazon ECO system is of course a great bonus. I bought it for entertainment purposes and the occasional email-personal APP use and it delivers flawlessly so far. The video is smooth and the sound is clear and precise. In summary as not to write a book, you will be pleased if you read what the description is prior to purchasing.  It delivers.The tablet is not a replacement for a laptop and never claimed to be, it does what it proclaims to do and does it well.  This tablet will not disappoint; highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: I just cant put it down!!
Reviews.Author: SpikeysMommy
Reviews.Content: LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT!!!!!  This tablet is so easy to use,has a crystal clear screen,and when needed, the most incredible tech support available. My songs on Amazon's mp3 player download instantly,has millions of apps and games to choose from at the lowest prices imagineable,and as a Prime Member you can access movies and books, many of which are free!!  My Kindle provides me with hours of non-stop entertainment right at my fingertips. Now that I have purchased it, I can honestly say the only thing I want for Christmas are Amazon gift cards to add more games and songs to my Kindle Fire HD!!

Reviews.Title: Easy to travel with everywhere, excellent size viewing.
Reviews.Author: PAM
Reviews.Content: Love being able to share books and ability to tap into music suggestions.  Enjoy downloading games that I can have grandchildren enjoy with me on my tablet.  This is a new purchase so I'm still learning many neat areas of interest, but the screen size and speed are fantastic!  Strongly recommend the leather case with purchase; very secure.  At 70 years old, I have to admit - this allows me to enjoy reading, shopping and staying connected with family and friends. LOVE IT

Reviews.Title: First Impressions
Reviews.Author: John F. Kolacki
Reviews.Content: I'm coming over from a nook tablet so I have some experience using this type of device.First off it is very easy to setup,wi-fi,e-mail were quickly setup.I was up and running in about Five minutes.I can't figure out all the reviews that say this is difficult.No charger? who cares,most people already have something that works or they can buy one. Weight feels good,it feels like a solid device,nice design,it looks fantastic.Button placement and design is a little off-putting though,there could be some tactile feedback to improve them,I sometimes hit them when I don't want to,and can't find them when I need to,this will change with more use though I'm sure. Screen display is bloody amazing with video apps and pictures,and looks good web surfing and with E-books,although the screen is a fingerprint magnet. Sound is very good for this size of tablet,much better than my Nook. Web surfing works good so far,no crashes for me yet in 2 days of using.I was able to easily side load some apps and all work well including the nook app for my existing nook library(sorry Amazon). So far very happy with the Fire HD and not regretting the purchase.The One and Two star reviewers slamming the device for what it cannot do need a reality check.People,this is an entertainment device for movies,music,e-reading,web surfing,e-mail and game apps,it's not a laptop computer,do a little homework first and use some common sense,this is not rocket science.

Reviews.Title: I love it - Kindle Fire 8.9
Reviews.Author: B Jones "bookscover"
Reviews.Content: This Kindle is the real thing. Reading magazines and graphic novels in COLOR!! I have a first generation kindle. It's black + white and screen is not backlit. This Kindle fixed both and then went farther.I am still looking into the movies and tv series available using Amazon Prime.I can signin to Netflix too.I used Kindle Fire in the kitchen Thanksgiving making turkey dinner for hours,"watched" two movies.I am going to investigate audio books next.I discovered books with the Kindle I never would have read, and I didn't have to have a great bookstore nearby!

Reviews.Title: Sweet machine, but...
Reviews.Author: M. Joseph
Reviews.Content: This is a sweet little machine, but I had to return it after two weeks. I was very disappointed after having this item on back-order for over a month, then to receive it and having to return it because of a fundamental weakness in the power input jack. AMAZON was aware of this weakness in the architecture as many of the Kindle Fire 1st. Gen. were returned due to this same problem - no effort was made on the KF HD to correct this problem.

Reviews.Title: My fourth Kindle...
Reviews.Author: sjpatrick
Reviews.Content: Fourth Kindle, third Fire, second HD. All of my Kindles have given me great gadget joy, but the HD models came with one great flaw in hardware design: the placement of the charging port.These latter devices -- heck, the whole Fire line -- have been designed for media far beyond books. Specifically, video, which they all handle beautifully. The HD models, spectacularly. And take note of all, ALL of the covers that they sell for these models: they are all designed to allow the device to stand in landscape mode to avail themselves to the strength.My original Kindle Fire (first generation) looks a little it silly with the power plug coming out of its "side", but it functions perfectly that way. It stands in its pretty little (extra purchase) case and shows me video. Or plays music or games or even lets me read, but it stands naturally on its broad edge doing so.The HD models in their specifically designed cases though are awkward at best because the charging cable impedes resting the devices on their long edge: they "lean" on the cables instead. This causes imbalance and clumsiness and can cause undo wear on the charging connectors themselves.Fortunately, a ready solution presents itself in a different design for the charging cables. Make them with bent or hinged connectors so they don't simply jut out stupidly from the device and the device can then stand much more normally and the world will be perfect again.That one flaw is the only one that the Fire HD has to contend with, as far as I'm concerned.I ordered mine even before the whole ad-supported thing was an issue, the day it was announced in fact. I left that order intact as to not lose my place in line. I figured I'd deal with the $15 later. Having seen what all the fuss is about, it's mostly trivia. I'll be paying the $15 within a few days I'm sure, but it has largely been a on-issue.As for the device itself, with the aforementioned flaw aside, it is nothing short of spectacular.The display is stunning, the sound is surprisingly great, the networking is solid and the bluetooth range is exceptional. The touch screen is notably more responsive than the original Kindle Fire. Despite what I noticed in another review, setting up the AT&T; mobile service was a no-brainer.I had the presence of mind when I ordered this machine to go ahead and buy a wall socket charger, so charging it is nowhere near the headache that others have expressed. In fairness, this is one area where Amazon might have been a little more proactive and these models might have been better served by including this accessory, but I won't belabor this point.Overall, I am as delighted with both of my Fire HD purchases as I was with my first Kindle (keyboard model) and my first Kindle Fire. They all serve me books and music, but the Fires serve me video, which is what I am usually most hungry for. And they do it extremely well.The whole charge plug thing however does merit the docking of an entire star from this review.

Reviews.Title: As great as I thought it would be.
Reviews.Author: James Ganley
Reviews.Content: This is the 4th Kindle that I have bought for myself and I have bought a couple more as gifts. This Kindle is just what I expected to be and I am extremely happy with it so far. I cannot understand some of the 1 and 2 star reviews that people are giving it. It seems like most of the low reviews are based on the fact that the purchaser did not review the specs on the Kindle to know what they were getting. I know that every now and again someone is going to get a dud but with amazons awesome customer service they will have a new one at the door the next day. I have a hard time believing the reviews that say customer support did not help them in any way.I have the 7 inch Kindle fire and I thought that one was great but needed a few tweaks. I did not like the speakers, but I would wear headphones most of the time anyway. The speakers on the new Kindle Fire 8.9 are great, no trouble at all while watching a show. I thought that the WIFI was a bit slow on the fire, but i am really happy so far with this one. I have not done any browsing online yet but I did download a few TV episodes in HD today and I was pleased at how fast they were done. The screen is just awesome, great picture and very quick response on the touchscreen. I will be testing it in bright sunlight soon but if the specs are correct that should be ok, one thing I could not do on my first Fire.I am not going to get all technical and go through all the specs, but the bottom line is as long as you research this and are aware that this is mainly used for entertainment and your not planning on running your home based business from your Fire HD you should be ok.

Reviews.Title: Great for Movies/TV, Books, Games & Magazines (not good for web browsing)
Reviews.Author: Cliff Hays "Cliff Hays"
Reviews.Content: The Good:In terms of hardware this is an excellent upgrade to the original Fire. The sound is better, the display is stunning by comparison, and it has eight times the storage capacity! As a result movies/TV and games look and sound awesome. Magazines - which I could not even stomach on the original Fire - are spectacular on this device. The pictures are clear and crisp, and the user interface can behave like a real magazine or a Kindle eBook. PDFs are also far more readable. The favorites have been moved to a star icon at the screen's bottom right (very convenient) to make room for a new feature of the carousel: as each new item moves to the fore, beneath it appears a scrollable shelfful of recommended items based on that item. So say you finish reading a really good book and want to find others like it, all you have to do is go to the home screen, bring that book to the fore on the carousel, and like magic you have a whole slew of recommendations to browse. This feature works on all types of items: mp3s, videos, games, etc. Another improvement is that there are external volume controls (unlike the original Fire where you would have to exit most apps to change the volume). In addition to magazines and PDFs looking great, ordinary kindle books look great as well (and the onboard ebook reader app is excellent as always).The Bad:The major flaw of this device is Silk (Amazon's own in-house made-for-kindle web browser). For users of the original Fire, Silk's bad name is nothing new. Only this time around I had an even worse experience with it! Basically, in two stints of web browsing (probably about 5 minutes each) the Silk browser froze multiple times for no apparent reason (usually about 20 to 30 seconds a freeze) and at the end of three of those freezes the browser not only crashed but caused the entire device to restart. Funnily enough, when Silk seemed to actually be working correctly it was extraordinarily slow. Unfortunately for the HD 8.9" there are no other browsers in the app store at this time to use in place of Silk. Another drawback of HD 8.9" is that several other apps that worked on the original Fire are not available: i.e. Art Authority, Treasures of Montezuma 2. For Kindle Fire users, I would check to see that your favorite apps will work on the 8.9" before ordering it, that way you are not disappointed after the fact.

Reviews.Title: Going to love toting this around with me!
Reviews.Author: J. Long "jrandjanet"
Reviews.Content: First, let me say that the only kindle I have owned was the original.  The HD is beautiful on the 8.9, ive been watching trailers on IMDB and they look awesome.  Setting this up was flawless for me and Im no techie.  I love that it automatically imported all my facebook photos to the cloud and on the device, will be nice to show friends on Thanksgiving.
