I'd love to hear the real reason why these apps don't make it on to the Amazon-approved list (got something to do with money? royalties, maybe?).The main screen design is okay, although it would be great to have more control over the items that appear in the carousel, so that I can tailor the items readily available on my main screen, kind of like every other Android device in existence.  Just give me the option - let people who like the automatic nature of the carousel the way it currently works keep it that way.With those two exceptions, I think it's a wonderful device, but if I had it to do over again, I'd buy one of the new Google Nexus devices.  7 inch screen, but functionality is more important to me than screen size.

Reviews.Title: Wow!!!
Reviews.Author: Heather Leach
Reviews.Content: As an original Kindle fire user, I thought it was pretty great. Then they came out with the 8.9 HD, I put off buying it until recently when my original fire bit the dust. I had this within  2 days of ordering it and I love it. I can do soo many things with it and I have big plans for it as I keep learning about different apps I can use. I was debating on whether to buy this, the IPad or the windows surface. The price on the the other 2 are soo expensive, and since I already have a great laptop I couldn't see spending all that money. This is at-least half the price of the IPad I was looking at and for what I am wanting to use it for I think it is the better investment. I know people with the IPad and all the functions they have with their IPad that I was wanting I have on this Kindle Fire 8.9 HD. I know I got the best deal for me and my needs and love it.

Reviews.Title: I am obsessed!!
Reviews.Author: Charlie
Reviews.Content: I am a huge kindle fan. I have owned pretty much every type of kindle and have loved them all. I had the original kindle fire and I preferred using it over my ipad. In fact, I always said that if Amazon brought out a slightly bigger version with a camera for skype and 4g, I would never use the ipad again. I got this for Christmas and have since given my ipad to my sis. I love that it has my entire reading collection, stunning hd display, and amazon prime! Love, love LOVE it!!!

Reviews.Title: Do You Enjoy Amazon's Unique Online "Ecosystem"...?  If So, You May Also Ejoy Using Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: HJW "o8Heather8o"
Reviews.Content: By this point in time, all that should be said about the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD has already been said by other reviewers, so I will comment on some of the unique aspects of my experience with it.First & foremost, if you're undecided about getting one, I would say, ask yourself this... "How much do you enjoy hanging out at Amazon's website?  How often do you visit their site, & what do you like to do when you're here?  Do you prefer visiting a different bookstore's site?"  I would recommend the Kindle Fire 8.9" HD to you if your answer runs along the lines of, "I log into Amazon almost every single day, usually at least several times a week...& I get lost online here...I lose hours just immersed in all of the different 'cool stuff' there is to see & read about here.  A huge percentage of the things I can't buy locally, I buy from Amazon...& I admit that I dig hanging out on their website, just checking things out & maybe commenting on them."I say this not because we're all going to shop ourselves into sweet oblivion on this tablet (although at times we may), but because if you like visiting Amazon.com & spending time in Amazon's unique "ecosystem" in general, & if you like what it "feels like" to be here - you will probably also enjoy the new Kindle Fire HD.  If you like the feel of hanging out in an ever-changing atmosphere & look forward to seeing what's new at this particular "virtual bookstore" - it's likely you may also like spending time on its tablet too.  It's easy to either like or dislike both Amazon & this tablet for the same reasons.  Because I very much like Amazon's site, I immediately liked this tablet - because it offers that familiar feeling of "cruising Amazon," & being able to take the entire contents of your digital account there with you, wherever you go.  My one wish that would make it perfect...is if it served fresh cappuccino lattes from a virtual espresso bar.  :) Ah well, I can dream.All of which leads to Amazon's excellent continuing tech support.  With many tablets, & the manufacturer will help you to set it up, & iron out any initial technical issues, then after that - you're on your own.  Which is Ok.  But if you have an issue with an item on your Kindle Fire HD, Amazon's Kindle Customer Service Dept. is just a phone call away, 24/7.  This has been quite handy, & they've stood behind their product with me so far.  As an example, for some reason I could not access over half of my music downloads, & they helped me to retrieve all of my purchases, so I can hear them as I read.  Help with malfunctioning apps ordered from Amazon is also a huge plus.  So far I am impressed, & I hope this does not change.I read some dour complaints about this Kindle Fire's limitations as a tablet, & really expected nothing more than a glorified eReader & a portable iHeart Radio & Netflix machine, & that was Ok with me.  I am graduating from the "Kindle 3G With Keys," & I chose it.  But what really surprised me, was how much I can actually DO on it...besides access all my books.  There's basic internet & email access, which is a must, & I also insisted on smooth, high-def video Netflix access.  But if you're a casual gamer & an e-gadget lover, there are SO many nifty & often free apps available to you, that you may forget to even open your books...  I have a nice collection really great books, but in the 5 weeks that I've owned this Kindle, I have actually have spent more time goofing off with my apps (like issuing howls of laughter at smashing things in "Let's Break Stuff!" Premium)...than I actually have reading.  And new & interesting apps are arriving each & every day.  In fact, Amazon offers Kindle Fire owners a "Free App Of The Day" daily for your consideration & enjoyment.  Some of the stuff you'll see featured there is creative & amazing...& some not.  But it's always fun to look forward to seeing what's next tomorrow.  If these ideas appeals to you (& you don't really just wish you could buy an iPad, but are settling for a Kindle)...you may really enjoy the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD.Also, I am impressed with the screen sensitivity.  I have tried tablets that I really had to *press* on hard, to get to respond.  In my experience, I find that the better the quality is of the tablet stylus I use, the better & faster the screen responds to it.  And the more cheaply made the stylus is, the more poorly it performs.  For me, using a different stylus (even though they may look almost identical) results in differing performance that is almost like using 2 different tablets.  When selecting a stylus, go with "what feels right in your hand".  Stylus reviews are hit & miss, & only you will know what's right for you.  It's cheap of them but probably just as well that Amazon does not include a stylus with this tablet, because half the people would probably hate it...although it would be nice for emergencies when your stylus of choice has wandered elsewhere.Those are the pros, now for the cons...I actually give this tablet 4 1/2 Stars primarily because it needs to use a little faster processing speed than what it comes with, for what it's trying to do.  It's good enough for most average functions, but if you're used to technology that really flies, you may feel a slight sense of lag with the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD.Also, the price gouging on the 32GB version of this tablet & the deliberate lack of an SD card port, is a major issue.  You can always keep most of your less frequently used books, music, & apps in your "Amazon Cloud"...but it's amazing how eerily fast the memory in that 16GB (part of which is taken up by the O/S) starts to fill up.  I never thought I'd use so much internal memory so fast, but after a few weeks, the increased memory usage is sneaking up on me like an evening shadow.  If you generally use up a lot of external memory in other areas of your life (eg. PC, phone, cameras, etc.)...you may want to bite the bullet & get the 32GB version of this tablet, just for the greater elbow room.  I wish I had, but I was too stubborn to pay for it.  That said, I actually would have paid the 32GB price if what it offered instead was an external SD memory card port capable of accessing cards up to 64GB.  That price I could live with.Furthermore, I give it 4 1/2 Stars due to its average battery life.  Like my cordless phone, my Kindle Fire HD always seems to be on the charger.  I would like a tablet that can do this much to hold a charge 30-50% longer than mine does.  Also, it came with a USB cable, but when I plug it into the PC to access it, it actually loses charge, instead of gaining it.  That's unfortunate, because after I use & unplug it at my PC, I still have to charge it from my wall outlet.  IMO...that's just wrong.  And the PC USB charging that occurs during "sleep mode" has been barely noticeable.Also, if you decide to purchase this tablet, I highly recommend also getting a supportive, well-constructed cover.  You will not "love" all of the covers out there (believe me...) but using this tablet "bare" feels very risky for a device of this value, & I highly recommend protecting your new investment with a Kindle cover that you can at least "like".  For this purpose, I prefer the over-priced bonded (Ok, barely) leather cover that Amazon makes Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9" Standing Leather Case, Royal Purple - even though the color actually arrived a murky "burgundy"...because I have tried equally expensive covers much worse.  Amazon's cover focuses on durability, surrounding & cradling their new Kindle HD with rubber bumpers on all 4 sides, to see it more safely see the bumps & clunks of life on the move.  Short of a "Nerf Cover," this magnetized cover will offer protection for your Kindle if you hope to toss it into your purse or tote bag, to take with you on the go.  It's also good if you tend to absent-mindledly bump things around while your mind races onto its next great idea, Kindle in hand.  For me, the sleep/wake cover feature really was its best selling point.  No matter what you do though, make sure you find this device a good cover that you can live with.  Because even though it's not flimsy, life will happen to it.Overall...  I give the 8.9" Kindle Fire HD tablet 4 1/2 Stars, because if Amazon were a real brick & mortar book store...I would probably live there...sipping lattes & eating scones in a wireless hot spot.  And because during my free time, this Kindle Fire has practically been my right hand since it arrived, & it's been hard to put down.  Also, the round the clock tech support has been great.  But I believe somewhat higher specs should have been offered for this device to match its capabilities, & at reasonable prices.

Reviews.Title: Better than the original
Reviews.Author: Noname
Reviews.Content: I have the original Kindle Fire.  When my husband asked me what I want for Christmas, I told him a Fire HD 8.9".  I got to play with my present early, and it is so worth it.SETUPSetup was a cinch.  It came registered to my account.  I just had to turn it on.  There was a short tour on screen, but I barely looked at it.  I can't even tell you what it said.  If you've had a Fire, this is just as easy.  Your favorites are at the bottom of the screen when you press the star.  Swipe from the top down to get at the settings.  Swipe back up to bring back your screen.BETTER THAN THE ORIGINALThe main reason I wanted the Fire HD is the larger screen.  I read a lot, and the larger screen size is so much kinder on the eyes.  Videos and photos are also much more vivid, and they stream smoothly.The new Fire HD has Bluetooth technology.  Finally, I can pair it with my Bluetooth keyboard and my Bluetooth speakers.  They make the tablet experience so much richer.Also included is a camera on the screen side facing the user.  I downloaded the free Photo Editor app to take advantage of it.  Too bad the camera isn't on the other side.  I'd find that more useful, but a front facing camera is better than no camera.Other advantages are external volume control buttons and a power button located on the *top* of the Fire.  No more accidentally turning the screen off.WiFi is very good.  While the WiFi signal on my old Fire keeps cutting out, the one on my Fire HD is constant and strong.SOME DRAWBACKSI don't care for the placement of the micro USB port along the longer side.  My cases and sleeves open at the top, so I can't charge the Fire HD while it's in the case because of the location of the power port.Also, although most of my apps that I use on my old Fire could be downloaded on the Fire HD, a few of them are not compatible.Flash is not supported.  This has not been a problem for me, but it may concern others.  I've run into a few instances where video wouldn't play, but I can live with that.  There are workarounds, but it's more work than I care for.Lastly, bigger means it won't fit in my purse.  We can't have it all.WITH SPECIAL OFFERSI got the Fire HD with special offers.  It gives me a beautiful ad at the startup screen.  No big deal.  I was hoping for coupons, but I'll take the ads.  So far, they have all been pleasing to the eye.CONCLUSIONI'm so happy I got a Fire HD.  It really is an upgrade from the original.  I use my Fire HD all the time now.

Reviews.Title: Way to Go Amazon
Reviews.Author: J. Fuller
Reviews.Content: My spouse quickly took possession of the newer,  larger Kindle and absolutely uses it everyday.  We are PRIME member so that makes this device worth the money.  How great of Amazon to also price match this when within a week or so of purchase they offered it $50 cheaper.  That is customer service when clearly they did not have to agree.  For this reason I am sticking with Amazon.This is a wonderful device for folks that love to consume media, and want a portable and easy to use product.  We have both a 7 and 8.9 HD versions now.  The extra screen size does mean a little more in size and weight but may be easier to read and view movies, etc.  I find that by double clicking the 7 inch I can easily increase  my text so this is not really an issue.I described my experience with the first 7 inch HD that I had to return and am monitoring the new one to see if the same problem develops.  However, I do not consider this issue to be a deal breaker.  Basically I have multiple email accounts and when I would check them from time to time, inevitably at least 1 would give me a connection error.  YES, I deleted and reinstalled the email settings and all would be fine until later I would return to find the same error.  I'm not sure what was causing that issue.If you are into Amazon, I mean if you're like me and pretty much buy a lot of items from them, then you need at least 1 of these devices in your household.  It you're a PRIME member, it is absolute in order to really enjoy the benefits with the simple touch of a few keys.Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: don't need anything else
Reviews.Author: matt meyers
Reviews.Content: I've had it for a little less than a month.  I LOVE this thing!!!  My one complaint is: the speakers have very clear sound, but if you want to hear a show, you have to have something behind it like a table or your hand to "direct" the sound forward since the speakers are on the back.My 3 year old daughters love it!  Everyone I've let try it loved it!  It has great parental controls so my little ones can't accidentally purchase something - I love FreeTime!  The free streaming videos with Prime account are the greatest thing on earth!  Wide variety of apps for free.  The battery lasts a long time, especially if you don't have the wireless turned on all the time.  The touch screen is just the right sensitivity for me, but my fingers are too fat for a few things that are small on the screen - but there might be a way to adjust the size of those that I haven't found yet.  It is so easy to use, understand and find things - I never read the instructions and don't think I'll need to.  I've seen some other tablets for similar price that are not nearly as easy to understand and navigate.A downside - I'm addicted!  The first couple weeks, housework and other responsibilities suffered, so I have used the FreeTime to restrict my time on it.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: dona
Reviews.Content: I've really enjoyed my new Kindle Fire HD.  I purchased the larger one after much thought and am really glad that I did.  The larger size makes viewing my streaming videos even better than I had hoped.  I no longer need the lamp on to read in bed.  The graphics for games are exceptional.  It was a great purchase.

Reviews.Title: better, bigger, faster
Reviews.Author: Marc Lauterbach
Reviews.Content: as a happy user of the first fire, all i have to say: better, bigger, faster. what's not to like!?Amazon proofed once again that they know well what the typical tablet using media consumer wants.I still use the "little fire" quite a bit though, due to its nice form factor. It is just easier to hold in one hand.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire 8.9" Review
Reviews.Author: dachsiedogs
Reviews.Content: I have progressed through the Kindle Fire products and was excited to receive my pre-order Kindle.  One thing I noticed right away was the power button was a little bit harder to find than in the previous version.  The volume button is right next to it and you really have to feel carefully for the power button.  I also had a few problems with applications failing because of the Silk.  Previous versions did not have silk on them, so was curious what this was.  I also notice that the games do not seem as quick to react as the previous version.  I am disappointed that the adaptor and other accessories are marked down, when I paid full price.  Still like the product and the bigger screen, but am debating whether I should keep the smaller or larger machine and gift one.

Reviews.Title: Long wait has been worth it
Reviews.Author: P. Johnson
Reviews.Content: I have been checking all the ultra portable tablets, net books and ever the high end phones and find that this with the additional purchase of a keyboard far the best price to feature choice.  Obviously some of the other products may do "some" more but this does all I need for home and travel at a much better price point.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9 a welcome addition
Reviews.Author: Dick Snell
Reviews.Content: Have had it a couple of weeks now. No problems whatsoever. Just used HDMI hookup to TV for a couple of :Prime Movies (Tin Tin & The Headhunters) and the picture on my 5+ year old 42" Panasonic Viera HD Plasma TV is easily as good as playing a DVD. Have watched 'North by Northwest' and much of first season of 'Buffy Vampire Slayer' on device itself and very pleased with the screen quality. I don't think the speakers are overly loud, but I'm a little hard of hearing. Use of some inexpensive ear but headphones solves that problem nicely. Battery life is very good and charges up rapidly when depleted. My only problem has nothing to do with  the KF HD, but may be of interest to this forum's readers. The CaseCrown case I bought simply reeks of chemicals and you may want to carefully weigh any possible purchase decision.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire 8.9
Reviews.Author: marge
Reviews.Content: This is a really comfortable size tablet for reading books or on the web.  Lightweight and good color.  The control buttons are really small and hard to see for older eyes, colored buttons would be easier to see.  There is also no charging light to let you know when the device is charged as there was on the older Kindles, a feature that would still be nice.  Sometimes tapping a item does not work and requires extra taps which can be annoying.A major turnoff is the apps that are preloaded by Amazon that I don't want and can't get rid of. For this price the tablet should allow you not Amazon to control the content loaded on the device.  When you pay extra to avoid the ads it would indicate you could also control the preloaded ads.Overall I would buy it again but it could certainly use a few improvements in the above areas.

Reviews.Title: Great Quality
Reviews.Author: Teresa A. Smith
Reviews.Content: I had purchased a cheaper Android tablet for my daughter but had many problems with it. So I wanted something reliable and made to last. I'm very pleased with the Kindle Fire, the images are vivid and crisp. The sound quality is superb and have no problems loading and managing content.

Reviews.Title: Great product
Reviews.Author: JDS
Reviews.Content: Have only had I my Kindle for a few days but I love it. The size is perfect-bigger than just a reader but smaller than a laptop.  It is very user friendly and easy to use.  The screen resolution is wonderful.  So far the battery life is exceptional.  I have had it on all evening using it and have not charged it yet.  My only concern is the weight of the unit.  It is a bit heavier than i expected.

Reviews.Title: HD 8.9 nicely survived a short drop onto tile floor
Reviews.Author: Eric
Reviews.Content: My 5 year old son borrowed the Kindle to play angry birds.  I told him to be very careful with it and NOT drop it because I don't even have the case for it yet.  Well I guess it's my fault..  The Kindle took a tumble from his arms crashing onto the hard tile floor.  To my complete suprise, it survived unscathed and I can't find a scratch or dent on it.  I have nothing anything negative to say...I believe pad prices will come down over time. The unit feels a bit incomplete without the Amazon case.  It's not easy to hold in the hands without a case.  I have the case for my smaller Kindle and they're very nice.  I especially like the way the Amazon case has a magnetic cover that turns the item on and puts it to sleep when you open and close the cover.

Reviews.Title: My third kindle
Reviews.Author: Ronna L Miller
Reviews.Content: This is my third kindle.  I have loved every one.  I was given the very first kindle that came out for my birthday.  I use that for reading only.  It is not back lit so I use an attached light but It's still great with a very big screen.  My second kindle was the first kindle fire given to me for Mothers Day.  I love it a have used it almost every day since I got it.  It is small enough to stick in my purse or pocket. I just received my Kindle 8.9 for my birthday this November.  I have not had a lot of time to use it yet but so far it my work out to be my favorite.  I love how easy it is to use.  I am far from being a computer whiz and I have not had any trouble being able to do what I wanted to do.  I downloaded music first and the sound was wonderful.  I choose the kindle 8.9 over the ipad and am very glad I did.

Reviews.Title: Love It! WITH AN UPDATE!
Reviews.Author: L. Bishop "The Felioness"
Reviews.Content: Update EditI've had the Kindle HD for several months now and my husband now has an iPad.  Time to compare and contrast. My Kindle is a reading device first and foremost for me. My husband's relationship with his iPad is much more "intimate." He does more with his iPad than I do with my Kindle and is his constant companion when he is on the road.  I watch the occasional movie or other video content on my Kindle via Hulu and Amazon Prime Instant video, check e-mail, and of course visit Facebook. Sadly Facebook does not look as good on the Kindle as it does on the iPad.  I know that's an app issue, but if you're a Facebook addict, that might be a factor for you to consider when deciding on what sort of tablet device to buy.  The "Silk" browser is a bit clunky compared to Chrome or Safari, but it's okay for the occasional search, but for "deep searches" I put down my Kindle and fire up my MacBook Pro and do serious work there.The Kindle HD is perfect for reading, video viewing, and light web browsing and of course......shopping on Amazon!Well, I finally got a tablet device.  Being a long time Apple computer owner currently with my fourth Mac, and owner of an iPhone, one would think I'd automatically go for an iPad.  Nope.  I decided to patiently wait for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" to come out. I pre-ordered mine in September and it arrived a week before Thanksgiving.....sooner than expected!I bought the Kindle because I like the Amazon "ecosystem" better than the iTunes "ecosystem" for purchasing and renting various media.  What music I have lives on my iPhone and it is music I've burned from CDs I already own. So music portability and storage is not that big a deal for me.  What is important is access to books, magazines, video, and movies and TV.  I like how Amazon presents its content better than the way iTunes does.Technically the Kindle Fire HD pulls in the wifi signal from the other side of our 1800 square foot house better than my iPhone and Macbook Pro do.  Perhaps its the dual antennae in the Kindle. I'm no tech geek, so I'm just guessing there.  The HD picture quality is spectacular.  I rented and viewed Tim Burton-Johnny Depp's "Dark Shadows" on my Kindle.  The clarity of the image and the colors popped right out as I watched from the cozy comfort of  my bed! I used basic headphones for listening and the audio was also very good.  I've also got a Pandora radio station streaming some of my favorite "progressive" rock music from the seventies and eighties. I've also downloaded a couple of free, public domain books to my Kindle and also purchased a Kindle edition of an interesting murder mystery novel.  It does not replace my Macbook Pro, but will be a wonderful traveling companion for portable communications when I don't want to dig out my regular computer.

Reviews.Title: Very Happy With the Kindle Fire 8.9"!
Reviews.Author: christine
Reviews.Content: Leaps and bounds over the earlier Kindle Fire.The perfect size screen, smooth performance and comfortable to hold.It's so good I sold my iPad....The new Kindle Fire 8.9 does everything I need.

Reviews.Title: Satisfaction
Reviews.Author: thekfchero
Reviews.Content: I'm typing this from my new kindle and I've got to say, I'm thoroughly impressed. This feels like a premium tablet. The screen is vivid and crisp, on par with the iPad. The sound is out of this world. It's actually hard to describe how good the sound is. It's super loud and it really mimics surround sound beautifully. I would also say this tablet is super comfy to hold, even with one hand. It's not too heavy but also carries enough weight so that it doesn't feel like a toy.Of course, there are some caveats. The browser is *slightly* slower than the iPad's but its still a massive improvement over the original Kindle Fire. There is no Flash but no mobile device currently under production runs Flash anymore. Personally, the lock screen ads don't bother me but the "customers also bought" on the home screen does piss me off. Fortunately, you can turn this off in the settings. Finally, the app selection leaves something to be desired, but for the most part, there is usually an "app for that".Overall, this is an amazing tablet for the price it and goes toe to toe with the iPad 4. If you are willing to forego apps selection for the ultimate tablet media experience, I would totally recommend this tablet over the iPad, the iPad mini, and the Nexus 10.EDITAfter tinkering around with it, I managed to install Chrome onto the device. This browser is amazing and I recommend using it over Silk. Here is the guide on sideloading apps. It's very straight forward and unlocks the potential of your Kindle. Simply search "sideload guide kindle fire hd" on google and click the first link.

Reviews.Title: Liking it so far
Reviews.Author: Kathleen Sanford
Reviews.Content: Have had mine for only two days but am really impressed. After I figured out how to get into the thing :), everything else went smoothly. The features that I have explored so far are great.  It is fast, easy to use and I am surprised at all you can do with it.  I had ordered the case at the same time, but has not shipped yet.  Kind of disappointed because I will carry it with me everywhere and will want the added protection of the case.  But other than that I think I'm going to love the Kindle Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: Not for middle aged eyes.  On the way back after 6 hours.
Reviews.Author: M. Phillips "tx.parrothead"
Reviews.Content: Six hours after I received my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9 it was packed up and ready to return to Amazon.  Read on and I'll tell you why.  I bought this tablet because my 2+ year old Pantech Element suddenly died one day a few weeks ago.  It simply would not power up.  I tried for a week, doing everything I knew and could find out to get it to work, but I concluded after a week it was a lost cause - I'll tell you more about this in a moment.  So I went tablet shopping.  I had a list or requirements:1)  NOT AN IPAD - I will not be a slave of Apple and iTunes.  Before you label me an Apple basher, let me point out we have a Macbook Pro, an iPad Mini and iPhone 4 in our household.  I am not a fanatic, I just feel Android offers much more potential than Apple does.2)  4G capable.3)  External SD card support.4)  An 8"-9" screen  -  7" is too small and the 10+" are too big.I am a technically able person and this list of requirements didn't seem like it would be too hard to fill.  It turns out it is.  There is virtually nothing out there that will meet every one of those requirements.  Interestingly my beloved Pantech Element does, but it has been discontinued.  After a few days of searching I decided I was going to have to compromise on one or more of my requirements.  I settled on the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 even though it did not support an external SD card.  I figured the 32G of internal memory would make up for it.  Maybe that would have worked out, I don't know.  There were other issues, one in particular, that would ultimately make that question moot.  Right out of the box, after an hour to update the software, I decided I did not care for the interface.  I realize this is a personal preference, others may love it.  I didn't. Being accustomed to the "normal" ICS interface, I found the "carousel" too busy/pushy/inflexible for me.  Couldn't change it either, can't even change the wallpaper.  Also the font seemed tiny, fine print on a medicine bottle tiny.  I thought, no problem, I'll go to settings and change it.  Guess what - you can't.  An hour of research on the internet indicated that this can't be changed and seems to be a common complaint.  Amazon customer support confirmed this can't be changed.  After two hours of playing with the tablet, my eyes literally ached.  At that point I decided this had to go back.  I can't enjoy this tablet and this was a deal breaker for me.  But there are some good points about this tablet.  I give my opinion of the good and bad below.  These are only my views and may differ from yours.  I offer them only as points for consideration:Pros:32G internal memory (almost makes up for the lack of SD card support).Nice screen size, 8.9".The $50, 12 month, 250M data plan is a great value.Cons:Not the most comfortable tablet to hold in one hand, at least for me.  I am used to holding my 8" Pantech with one hand while reading.  This tablet is more difficult to hold in one hand.  Why don't tablet makers make the back of their tablets with either a textured finish or some kind of non-slip material?No SD card support.  Why is this?  Should be a must for all tablets.Android version locked up tighter than Fort Knox.  I won't say I tried and can't say I didn't, but even rooting this is nearly impossible at this time.  It seems Amazon has gone to great lengths to stop this useful and sometimes necessary practice.Tied to the Amazon Kindle HD app store.  This is a sore spot for me because I don't want to be tied to their app store any more than I want to be held hostage by Apple and iTunes.  See requirement number 1 above.  BTW, Kindle HD app store is sorely lacking in some of the apps I use regularly.  For example, Tom-Tom is not there, Cool Reader (the BEST free e-reading app, bar none, IMO) is not available and many others I use all the time.  And you can't download them as a regular app either, Amazon won't let you, see lock-down comment above.Limited ability to configure the system .  My Pantech was running ICS, 4.0.4, which allowed quite a bit of user control.  Whatever version of Android this device is running (I couldn't tell) will not allow you access to some of the most basic settings.  I could not even change the system font size in the display menu, it's not there.  This leads me to my biggest complaint of all -System font is so small it hurt these middle-age eyes after a couple of hours trying to deal with it and cannot be increased.  This was the deal breaker for me. Yes, within some apps the font size can be changed, but these are generally limited to e-reading apps.  You can't change the font in file manager app, for example.  This applies to most other apps.In conclusion, although there are a number of good things about this tablet, the negatives far outweighed the positives for me.  I also do not believe this good choice for anyone with any kind of vision difficulties.  The text in many, if not most, apps can be difficult to read.  Finally, two days after I ordered the Kindle, my Pantech suddenly came back to life.  It has been working fine ever since.  I still don't know what happened, but I continue my quest for its eventual replacement.  Even at over two years old, consider it a better choice for me than the Kindle Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: KNOW WHAT YOU WANT
Reviews.Author: Edward G. Taylor "Nahum 1:7"
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" when Amazon had a $50.00 off one-day sale before Christmas.  It has proven well worth the money.  Being money conscious, but somewhat techie oriented, I wanted the quality hardware (high ppi, gorilla glass, fast) and up-to-date OS that this provided without an Apple price tag.The HD 8.9 has proven itself an excellent value.  My needs were pretty basic:  reading-including digital magazine(s),  web surfing, a few specific apps, possibly note taking, games, Amazon Prime Instant Movies.THE GOOD-- I have already read a library book on my HD.  I enjoyed the experience very much.  I ride public transportation (commuter train and bus) to & from work.  The HD has been very nice in all lighting conditions experienced so far.  Time will tell how it does in bright summer sunshine.-- I subscribed to Motorcyclist magazine and it is awesome.  Easy to read...pinch & zoom works great.  Easy to navigate.-- Surfing the web is easy.  I prefer my laptop, but I occasionally use the HD for convenience sake.  I wouldn't want to count on it as my primary web access tool.  I have not yet tried alternate browsers.-- The specific apps I have tried have been excellent quality.  I already knew what I wanted was available for the fire.  I had to sideload some of them, but without rooting the device.  I recommend researching your desired apps before buying to be sure they will work ok on the HD.-- Note taking is dependent on the app.  I find the on-board keyboard too small for my large hands.  I have yet to try out my flex keyboard, but am hoping that will work well. This is my lowest priority use for the HD, so not too important.  I will mention the app itself is excellent.  There are several available.-- The games I have tried are a lot of fun.  I am totally undemanding in this regard, so caveat emptor, however I have enjoyed free versions/clones of Bejeweled, Solitaire, Sudoku and Bubble Shoot.  All have played well and looked great.-- Viewing movies from Amazon Prime has been a treat.  The sound on my Bose headphones is excellent, the screen resolution/contrast/colors terrific.  I have a 15mbit/sec wifi (DSL) at home which is shared by the tablet, 3 computers (rarely running at the same time), and 3 roku boxes.  I've yet to experience buffering during a Prime movie.  I have once during a Netflix movie, but my internet provider has had problems now and then and I suspect them, not the HD or Netflix as the source of the problem.THE BAD-- I paid the extra $15 to avoid the advertisements.  When in Landscape mode, on the home screen, I don't get them.  If I turn to Portrait mode (some apps work in Portrait mode only), I get them anyway.  I'm rather disappointed about this, even though they are NOT all that annoying.  It's just that I feel I should have gotten what I paid for.  Be aware that a lot of free apps come with advertising as well.-- It is annoying that it does not work while charging.  I often lay in bed and surf or play or read on my 15.6" laptop, with it plugged in.  I cannot do the same with the MUCH lighter Fire HD 8.9".RECOMMENDATIONS:-- Got money?  Buy Apple.  But I have to say this Amazon Fire HD 8.9" is an excellent choice for me.-- I did not buy the fast power adapter, but I am going to get one.  It is slow charging on a plug in USB phone charger or on my $10 Big Lots universal Home/Car USB charger.-- I don't get it.  People argue over hundreds of thousands of iApps, at least a hundred thousand Android Apps, and 10's of thousands of Amazon Apps.  Except for the specific apps I needed, and verified in advance would sideload to the Fire, I have found more than enough variety of apps for common uses.  I downloaded "250+ Best Kindle Fire & Fire HD APPS For the New Kindle Fire Owner" by Tom and Jenna Edwards.  Their advise and research proved valuable in finding good Apps early on.-- KNOW THYSELF.  Don't buy a tablet until you know why you want it, how you expect to use it, and what is REALLY important to you.  I read a hundred reviews of the 8.9" before making the leap.  It was clear to me that the majority of nay sayers either thought the tablet would be a lightweight PC (capability wise), or were disappointed that yet another relatively inexpensive tablet failed to do everything the Apple product could exactly as well, and with as many software choices.  Give Amazon a break...they don't claim to be an iPad.  If that's what you want...work, save, beg, etc. until you can buy what you want.  But if you want do do basic things, this tablet has the capability, and is an excellent value for most people.One more thing.  When you go to Disneyland/Disneyworld, are you disappointed when you go into the Main Street stores and find a lot of MIckey Mouse ears, stuffed dolls, spoons, cups and other Disney fare?  NO...in fact, you buy some of it.  For crying out loud, don't get mad at Amazon, a for-profit business, for making it easy for you to buy STUFF from them on your Fire!  CONTROL YOURSELF.  You are getting a high quality piece of hardware for a very nice price.  If you don't like Disney stuff...don't go to Disneyland.  If you don't like Amazon stuff...

Reviews.Title: Almost exactly what I ordered
Reviews.Author: M. Cohn
Reviews.Content: I love this product. It beats the pants off my roommate's ipad. So much so he's actually considering selling it and buying himself one of these babies. I wont bore you with the specs, because everything in the product description is exactly right: the speakers are fantastic, the wifi is super fast, and the anti-glare screen is amazingly clear. There are two things I must point out to future buyers, though.1) This tablet talks about being Amazon Instant Video compatible, which it is. You can easily stream prime videos if you're a prime member, and can download previous Instant Video purchases. However, I've recently discovered that for some reason any videos bought using the tablet, for me at least, cannot be properly downloaded. It hits 99% and sends me an error message.2) Amazon Silk is no Chrome. It's not as slow as Internet Explorer, but do expect to wait a bit when loading websites, especially Youtube and Wikipedia. Also, the keyboard takes longer to show up when using the web.All in all, I love this product. I do hope they fix these two problems, but don't think they're big enough to hinder your tablet use. Five Stars all the way.

Reviews.Title: Love it, love it, LOVE IT!
Reviews.Author: GEM
Reviews.Content: Although I have only had my Kindle 8.9 tablet for a day, I absolutely love it! I am a research freak so I looked at several tablets, including the iPad and the Samsung, among others, before I finally settled on the Kindle and I have no regrets. It has everything I want and does everything I want it to do. Here are the things I especially like:1. I love the audio books feature!2. The resolution is terrific3. I was able to download a word processing software and, with the addition of the keyboard cover I bought (see here) CrazyOnDigital Ionic Bluetooth Keyboard Tablet Stand Leather Case for Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9 Kindle Fire HD Tablet -Black Brown, it turns into a portable laptop so I can write on the go.4. I like the fact that, even though it didn't come with a charger, I can use the same one I use on my Kindle Fire 7" ereader.5. It's lightweight and blazingly fast.6. I can tether it to my cell phone wherever I go so I don't have to purchase a separate data plan. (Yay!)Best of all, it's the perfect size--slightly smaller than the iPad, slightly larger than the Kindle Fire 7". Even with it's case I can easily fit it in my purse.

Reviews.Title: Wow!  Wow! Wow!
Reviews.Author: diva
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD 8" is AWESOME!!!!!  My kids bought me my first Kindle 3 years ago.  It was a Kindle 3G and I love it.  They then upgraded me to a Kindle Fire and I double loved it.This holiday my boyfriend and I decided on a gift.  I had been wanting an IPad because I already had 2 Kindles I would not give up for anything in this world.  Plus the IPad fever got me with the Retina thing and this and that.  My boyfriend however seeing how much I love my Kindles decided on the new Kindle Fire HD 8".Well, as promised my boyfriend got me my IPad and like a new kid I played with it endlessly and neglected my Kindles.  Then last night the new Kindle Fire HD 8" arrived earlier than expected.  OMG!!!!Sniff, Sniff, Sniff!  I'm sorry Kindle the IPad devil made me do it!!!!!  Does anyone know how to return this IPad monster and get my money back.  Please take me back Kindle I will never, never, never, ever leave you again for some hot thing - it meant nothing, it's you I love!!

Reviews.Title: 8.9 Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: Kathy Olinger
Reviews.Content: I just upgraded to the 8.9 Kindle Fire HD from the 7" Kindle Fire. I really like my NEW Kindle Fire.CONS:#1. ADS-I bought with the ads on (they call it Special Offers.. its special alright... especially irritating)...1st day I thought no big deal. but by the 2nd day I am SO irritated with them. Amazon is charging me $15 to take off. OMG !! I paid $299. and you are subjecting me to CRAP and charge me to fix it.#2. No lite indicating fully charged or charging.#3. charging ANOTHER $20. for the power cord.Don't get me wrong I do VERY much like my Kindle..does EVERYTHING I want it to do..I just don't appreciate them NOT thinking about their customersAll in all my grand daughter got my 7" Kindle and she thinks I am the best grandma ever.

Reviews.Title: Great product, but has WiFi issues
Reviews.Author: Glenn Robinson
Reviews.Content: I love the size and weight of the Kindle Fire HD.  The display is outstanding.The only real issue I have is that the WiFi seems to freeze for up to 30 seconds, especially on Facebook (both the app and web), as well as some of the news apps (CNN and USAToday).  With the CNN app, I get a "stopped responding" message, which then reloads the app.  I've tried disconnecting and reconnecting the wireless connection with no improvement.  I haven't been able to find anything online that addresses this issue.  This happens once or twice every 30 minutes or so.  If I could get this problem fixed, this product would get 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Seniors Beware!!!!
Reviews.Author: Spokane WA
Reviews.Content: My first ever tablet so thought I was buying the best for the money I had to spend. For all you guys used to electronics you are going to think I am sooooo dumb but I am going to be honest as maybe someone else out there has the same issues.Package arrived and I was so excited, I bought this mainly to skype with my family in Europe but also to have internet at home. Well turned it around and looked everywhere, could not find the on/off button! Nothing on this tablet is obvious if you have not experienced a tablet before.I do not have the luxury of young ones at home to help me I had to figure this out by myself. As I had paid with foreign currency, even thought the kindle was delivered to an American address, it was all set up for a British user. Really?One has to go through Amazon to get this sorted out and it did take almost 2 hours and 3 agents on the phone!OK, for starters I am thinking this is not a good idea!I had purchased a keyboard and charger after reading the reviews, thank you people. Using the screen is awful, as someone said it keeps typing wrong letters and no matter how careful you are it still does it when you are hitting the correct key, words and forgetting spaces!!!! This is not user error as I spend all my day on a keyboard and know it well.....I ended up bringing it in to work and let our techie look at it to try and help me out. To dumb it down, he regrets recommending this for me as he was not aware how proprietary the aps are. Meaning I cant get chat on facebook, other reviewers state the same thing, many of the aps are not available on the kindle.I have had it for almost a week and am no further forward than when I received it.Granted the screen and volume are excellent but so is my computer, it is very slow even with a great wireless signal, it freezes often and for a senior not user friendly.So, I have a professional computer guy arranged to help me set up the sites I need and skype. If this does not work to my satisfaction I will be returning it.

Reviews.Title: Excellent tablet for movies and reading books/magazines
Reviews.Author: gusdpr
Reviews.Content: I bought my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 in Best Buy more than one month ago and I definitely like it very much. Using Amazon prime to shop and watch videos is totally a pleasant experience. Using the micro hdmi cable plugged in your TV is an amazing feature to watch videos. Performance is OK, not the fastest tablet but for reading a book, watch movies and shop Amazon goods you don't really need a huge power house, and it is not expensive compared to other tablets. It has a vivid screen with excellent resolution ideal for reading books and magazines and watch photos and movies in full HD. I like the speakers a lot, they aren't very loud but sound quality is way superior to other tablets I have. So far this device has become my primary tablet, I use it every day to read the news, emails, books and browse the web instead of using my smartphone.The reason I'm giving 3 stars is because unfortunately the tablet is still plagued with bugs and crashes easily with the Silk browser. So far the bugs that I have caught are the following:+ The Silk browser delivers a very bad user experience. It crashes very often even if you just leave the tablet idle while reading a webpage, you will be asked many times to reload your tabs. In some cases, the whole tablet is unresponsive while using Silk, and it reboots after 2 or 3 minutes of being frozen. If you try to open more than two websites with the tabs, Silk slows down significantly and begins to shutdown your previously opened webpages (when you return to them it reloads everything again so you lose track of what where you doing) this is really bad if i.e. you are filling a form or making a payment (you need to enter all the information again), I would expect this behavior to happen when you open around 5 or 6 websites to prevent running out of memory perhaps, but not 3 tabs. You can side load Dolphin browser to mitigate these issues, however there is no excuse of why Silk performs so poorly.+ The keyboard input has a considerable lag, you can't write too fast since it will begin to miss key inputs, this forces you to write slowly (lag is less/more depending on the application you are using). Also something quite annoying I found is if I press the space key in the left/right edges while in landscape (just below, the 'x' and the 'b' keys respectively) it doesn't register any input even if you get the sound feedback you did press the key, to make it work you need to press around the center of the key.+ If I transfer 1080p videos from my smartphone they don't play properly. However 720p videos work fine.+ Sometimes the calendar app is shown as a gray empty rectangle in the carrousel instead of showing the correct date.+ It happened to me that while using the Shop application and the Silk browser sometimes I see black rectangles randomly in the screen (seems like a rendering issue from the graphics processor), most of the time going to the homescreen and returning to the app fixes the issue. In the case of Silk, reloading the webpage makes the trick.In summary, the tablet excels at watching movies, reading magazines, reading books, playing games and shopping amazon goods. Up to date it performs poorly as a web browser so if this is your priority task you may need to look for another tablet or wait until this is fixed by Amazon (I would rate 5 stars if the previous bugs where not present).Note: All the issues above have been reported already to Amazon, hopefully they create an update to fix them.

Reviews.Title: Great purchase
Reviews.Author: Nat
Reviews.Content: I thought this would be daunting, book to read, all kinds of technical stuff, nothing.....you just need to sit with it, play with it and in a couple of hours you're moving around like a pro...very simple for someone who is technically challanged like me.  Great gift.Voice is great, picture is great.  I can sit and read in the dark unlike my original Kindle...I love it.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9"
Reviews.Author: Greqo
Reviews.Content: I ordered two of these and they were delivered to my house on the 20th of November.  In my opinion, these tablets were best value compared to others I looked at while shopping for tablets.Screen operation is smooth and seamless. For the most part, things were pretty user friendly as the initial start-up of the units took us through a simple tutorial of the basic function.My only "con" to this product was the USB cable that was supplied with the unit which is the primary charging cord for the tablet. Neither unit would charge off the packaged USB cable. After 3 calls to Amazon Customer service I had come to the conclusion that if this was working as intended, I was going to re-package both units and send them back to Amazon for a full refund. If I couldn't charge the tablets with the supplied USB cables, there was no point in keeping them.As was always the case with Amazon, they were willing to supply us with the adapters that plugged into the walls at no cost to us. I am no expert but I have come to the conclusion the USB power stream is not enough to push power into the Kindle Fire 8.9" battery.  You may convince me of that if it were not for the fact that I had two brand new units, both with the same charging problems. This may be something Amazon will wish to address in the near future.As long as the outlet adaptor and cable they are sending me work in charging this device, I will gladly recommend it's purchase to anyone. I will give and update to this in the near future.***Update*** Change from 4 stars to 5 due to Amazon's Customer service and how great they were in resolving my issue.

Reviews.Title: I am in love!
Reviews.Author: Jill Genn
Reviews.Content: I received my new kindle on Friday (earlier than expected) and it has exceeded my expectations. I  was very happy with my 1st generation fire, but this is a huge upgrade! The picture and sound quality are amazing, the browser is lightening fast, and the reading experience is excellent with crystal clear print and images. Having done some research before purchase, the lack of an included charger was not a big deal. The ads are not intrusive and I enjoy browsing the recommended books and  apps as many of them are of interest to me.As with any new device, there are a few minor issues that could be addressed. The e mail app that is preloaded will not work with my verizon account, although tech support tried everything to help me. I was able to use another email app in the app store an  that worked well, so the  problem seems to be with the app, not the fire.

Reviews.Title: Happy,happy,happy.
Reviews.Author: Glenna Ernst
Reviews.Content: I have a 7" Kindle I purchased three years ago.  I didn't know what a tablet was,but thought it sounded like fun. I purchased it to be able to listen to the audible books as my sight is really bad.  Oh my what a wonderful purchase this was. This past fall I purchased the 8" , and I am happy,happy,happy!  I'm 79 years old and have had surgery on my right eye.  With the Kindle I am able to listen to books AND able to read them as well.  I am so "happy". Seriously, this tablet has opened the door to a world I thought was gone for me.  Not only do I read and listen to books, but use it for everything I would do on my PC.  Why? Because I can!  Love it, and my friends now have the Kindle fire.  We are learning new things all the time. I have looked at other tablets, but they do not come up to the standard of the Kindle. Would not purchase any other brand.

Reviews.Title: Still has issues
Reviews.Author: Mary Miintline
Reviews.Content: This is my third one, the first two were returned for multiple problems. So far, this one has fewer issues, but still,they are annoying. It locks up constantly and the keyboard is horrible. Not sure what I will do with this one. I have two earlier models and thay are fantastic,no problems at all.

Reviews.Title: Not that great
Reviews.Author: Charles E. Guess
Reviews.Content: Bought a new one as a Father's Day gift for my husband while he was going through chemo. We have had it for less than a year & for several months now Silk browser either freezes or shuts down.  When calling Amazon, they tell us to clear the data but it continues to freeze & shut down.  I have an Apple iPad & have had zero trouble.  Highly recommend the Apple iPad.

Reviews.Title: I like the 7" better
Reviews.Author: mlm22 "mlm22"
Reviews.Content: I own both the 7" fire HD and the 8.9" fire HD, and I have to say, I like the 7" better.  Of course, this is just my opinion, and it really depends on what you use it for, but I will point out a few of the contrasts between the two in my opinion.  First, obviously since the 8.9 has a bigger screen, I found it more difficult to use for games, because the screen is larger and to swipe or slide your finger around the screen requires you to cover more real estate, so to speak, and therefore it's a bit more tedious.  I also found it to be less responsive than the 7" version.  I found myself having to tap or slide sometimes more than once on the 8.9, which never happens on the 7.I understand the the screen resolution is higher on the 8.9, but quite honestly, I really can't tell the difference, even when watching high def movies or videos.  If there is a difference, to me it's not really noticeable.  One other downside is it really takes a long time to charge.  of course a bigger screen requires a bigger battery which explains the extended charge time, but for me, I am always on the go, so I don't always have 8 to 12 hours to wait for it to charge.  Also, the 7 fits in my pocket and I mostly can't even tell it's there most of the time.  The 8.9 is of course bigger and more cumbersome.So, my bottom line is that if you watch a lot of videos and a larger screen is a must, then go with the 8.9.  Otherwise, I prefer the 7 for everything else, including the price.  So for me, that's what I do with them.  Watch videos on the 8.9, and use the 7 on the go and for everything else.

Reviews.Title: Poor battery performance
Reviews.Author: Kflan61
Reviews.Content: Battery life was very poor. Did not last anywhere near 10 hours.  It also took forever to charge and would actually loose battery charge plugged in if you were streaming a movie!

Reviews.Title: A Real Tablet
Reviews.Author: W. T. Towles
Reviews.Content: I have had a Kindle Fire 7” tablet for about a year before buying the Fire HD 8.9”, and my comments here are aimed mostly at comparing the two tablets.1. I used the 7” just for reading and will do pretty much the same with the 8.9”. The 8.9” is much faster with a higher resolution screen, and in landscape orientation it allows for 2-column reading vs. a single column for the 7”. Text rendering of the 8.9” is very sharp. (For both tablets, I use white text on a black background to extend battery life.)2. Unlike the 7”, the speed and screen size (almost 75% bigger viewing area) of the 8.9” make web surfing a realistic possibility.3. While much bigger, the 8.9” seems no harder to handle or use for reading than the 7”, and it gives an overall higher sense of quality and good design.4. I never used the speakers on the 7”; sound quality from the 8.9” seems good enough.5. Advertising on the lock screen does not bother me—I never look at it. But the 8.9” seems to have many more hooks into the Amazon selling ecosystem. You may want to be more careful when you are clicking away that you don’t accidentally buy something.6. I bought a protective case with the Fire HD 8.9” but bought the wrong one; guess I assumed that the HD 8.9” and the HDX 8.9” are the same size. They are not; the HDX is apparently slightly smaller overall in both width and height. So for $9.99 I bought another case (CaseCrown Bold Trifold Case) that fits and well works in every way.7. In my book, the package of the HD 8.9” with the CaseCrown gets a solid five-star rating.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: DEBIRC
Reviews.Content: I LOVE the size and picture.  The only thing I DON'T like I how short my battery stays charged.  It feels like I just got on facebook and an hour later its telling me to connect the charger.

Reviews.Title: Amazon staff was incredibly helpful!
Reviews.Author: ann
Reviews.Content: I ordered a kindle fire for my husband last year. Two weeks after buying it (but not a protective case or warranty) I dropped it and shattered the screen.  I had followed the Dave Ramsey philosophy of no warranty, and I expected to have to buy an all new kindle fire full price.  After saving for 8 months, I called to buy a new kindle.  I asked if I could exchange or send in the old one and they said yes. I was offered a discount on a kindle the same model as my broken one, or I could upgrade and still get a discount.  I had noticed that on line they had refurbished models and I asked if I could get a refurbished upgrade.  They said yes and I still got a discount  on a refurbished 8.9 inch Hd.  My husband was thrilled, I was relieved, and my pocket book was not empty.  This time I did spend for a case to protect it and they offered me an amazing warranty deal.  We now are using our tablet with amazing picture and sound daily.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your money!
Reviews.Author: SarahBeth
Reviews.Content: My biggest complaint is the Silk browser. It can't handle anything! I can't go on news websites without getting a message that Silk browser is not responding and you can forget about loading any web page with pictures. I've had to do a factory reset to try and fix the glitch, I've cleared all my book marks, cache, old apps, and books to get this thing to work and it still does the same thing. It has an email app, but won't send any emails! I really wish I would have saved my money for something better.

Reviews.Title: Not what I expected
Reviews.Author: SQL, UNIX, Rams, Cavaliers "Mmm... Beer."
Reviews.Content: I received this as a holiday gift. The cool factor of having (another) tablet did not last more than a day for a few reasons. I love Android OS.The most frustrating feature of the Kindle is the on board web browser Silk. It is clumsy and does not offer advanced privacy options. This is my paramount desire. Alternating between the Amazon accelerated/encrypted browsing off and on, several of the websites I visit most are slow. I am looking at a very popular sport team's fan site, which was claimed to have been optimized for most modern browsers. The text forums take over a minute to load and scrolling is disjointed and clunky. Every time I exit silk, I must remember to delete all temporary files, settings, and passwords as I do not trust storing them, or the cookies and silk contains no setting to automatically browse "in private" (even though even with Firefox that is a misnomer, and other precautions should be taken).The Amazon app store is equally clumsy. Try searching for a specific item. I was looking for Final Fantasy games, and results ended up with items that obviously were not what I was searching for. There aren't enough controls or oversight on the content available, and it is hard to determine if the software (app) you are considering is what you actually desire. As much as I hate Apple, I do also have an IPad and, as much as I loathe DRM, Apple's presentation is much more polished. Both could stand slight updates in allowing additional advanced search options in regards to their respective digital store fronts. If I can't tell if the results from my search are a word document, a picture, a video, or a game then there is a very big problem.This introduces a criticism where these two issues merge: The app store does not currently offer any other reputable web browser options. Silk is terrrrrible, and Mozilla products are tagged as not currently available. After some quick internet searching, I figured out how to get on the beta releases for one of the more popular browser options that gives the end user more control. I have yet to be able to devote the time necessary to make it fully compatible with my needs; flash is not readily available and my web browsing is limited as a result. I still have to use Silk if I want to watch YouTube.What I actually want in a tablet is something that gives me control over my product, without challenging me to change it without voiding the warranty. I want to be able to change the wallpaper. I do not want to see an advertisement every time I pick it up; in all likelihood, I am probably not going to buy the junk you are trying to sell to me. I can't stand the carousel. Every time I finish with something I remove it from the home screen. If someone truly enjoys that type of file management assistance, they should go with an MS product. The constant monitoring Amazon does on the device limits the performance of the hardware, and robs resources that would otherwise enhance performance. Pass on this. I think the only way I will get what I want is if I build it myself, or root something with the hardware I need.Edit: I forgot to mention charging, which took 10 hours to go from 3% to 100%. I also managed to get to 14% from 100%, while being connected to the charger which came with the device.

Reviews.Title: Always freezing, super slow
Reviews.Author: Alan Numsuwan
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research before I purchased my tablet. I polled my friends, read numerous reviews, and apparently it wasn't enough. I thought with all things being equal between the kindle fire HD and the ipad, the lower cost would prevail, but i was surely mistaken. I've had my kindle since September and have tried to deal with it. But it is simply too slow and it is constantly crashing. My iphone is significantly faster and less troublesome. My kindle is now a paperweight. Every now and then i try to run Hulu on it but it just keeps freezing. I don't know what to do, I doubt I can return it. My advice is to purchase a different tablet. My loss/experience is your gain.

Reviews.Title: Frustrated with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: Marion Campbell
Reviews.Content: We purchased 2 Kindle Fire HD 8.9" for our children. One had to be replaced on day 2, because it would not turn on. There were no questions asked and Amazon sent us a new one.We have been completely frustrated with the Kindle. The apps seem slow to open. The charge doesn't hold for long and then it takes at least 10 hours to recharge.We should have spent the extra money and just purchased iPads. We have used multiple Apple products over the years and never once, have had an issue. Lesson learned.

Reviews.Title: Silk browser stinks, but I'm heavily invested in Amazon content
Reviews.Author: J. Lee
Reviews.Content: I'm on my fifth Kindle, 2 Kindle Fires and 3 Kindle Fire HD's 8.9. Customer service to replace faulty kindles has been excellent, which I've had to do twice. One stopped charging and one just locked up. I love the screen size and Prime membership features. Here is where it gets disappointing, the Silk browser constantly glitches and must force close. It takes FOREVER to load a web page and 9 times out of 10 I get a notification to wait or close. This is a pain since I use the Kindle mostly for internet browsing. Since all my content is through Amazon I'm kind of stuck.

Reviews.Title: Ummm Love it, but at the same time I'm Perplexed...
Reviews.Author: Fertacrit "Fertacrit"
Reviews.Content: Full disclosure: this is my first Tablet.  I am a prime member and it is pretty sweet for my needs. 95% entertainment and just a smidge of other stuff.  So far all the games and apps I want I have been able to get and all of them were free.  I use Flixter for my UV copies of movies I own so I can watch them while offline if I download them. Granted they are standard def, but they still help to pass the time when I am not on a wireless or want to play a game.  I have streamed The Avengers from Prime and it looked fantastic, not buffering no "in/out" of HD.  The dual antenna did it's job. The screen is fantastic compared to my wife's Kindle Fire 7" 1st Gen.  The speakers sound really good too. So for movies it is a fantastic device.  Silk is ok but I just go to google, using Silk and surf using Google and it works great.  It is a little heavy but, that honestly does not bother me, I kinda like the weight as it seems, in my head at least, like the lighter devices feel "cheaper" even though reality , tells me they are not.Now I agree a charger should have been included but it wasn't. So instead of paying the $20 for the "official" Kindle wall charger I did more digging and found a great one with fantastic reviews that is super fast. The RAVPower® RP-UC05 Dual USB Travel Wall Charger, it does the trick and has some built-in device protection, and is half the cost.  When I charge the Kindle I turn off the wireless so it charges faster, and it fully charges in @1 hr. (The lowest I have gotten the battery life before charging it is 15%).  For me the battery life is fine.  I think it is like my Galaxy media player where if I turn off the wireless, the battery lasts a lot longer.  So far I have done so and the Kindle last a lot longer.  So if you are not using the wireless, turn it off, because it will continually scan for networks and will make the Kindle work harder and thus drain the battery quicker.  Also dial back the brightness, mine is at about 75% and still plenty bright.  But both these suggestions should be common knowledge these days as far as prolonging charges.The part that confuses me, is a lot of the reviews.  It is as if the majority of negative reviewers did not spend one second reading other reviews or the product description and just made a blind buy.  First thing I noticed while reading other reviews esp the very first "Most Helpful Review" (Which is great) and the comments for that specific review, is that is said it does not come with a wall charger.  So I knew what to expect.  But for the people who were suprised about this...do you not read reviews????  If you also would have looked at "what is included in the box" you will not see a charger, again, do you research people.  There were reviews complaining about being surprised about lack of Flash Player...again, READ REVIEWS.  There are reviews that will state that it is not supported (not a kindle issue, it is Adobe that has made that decision).  So how can you be surprised?  There were some that gave it 1 star because the screen cracked when they dropped it.  Umm, how is that the devices fault that you cannot hang onto it?  Just dumb.  I don't get why for an expensive purchase like this, people seem to not do any research and then give negative reviews because they are "unaware" or "surprised" about a certain aspect of the device.  Or blame the device for not having something that is just not possible either due to the ecosystem or the particular programs' origin.  Duh, DO YOUR RESEARCH TO MAKE AN EDUCATED AND FAIR JUDGEMENT AND DECISION.Again, this is my first tablet.  AFTER DOING A BUNCH OF RESEARCH, I feel this matches my needs.  I could not justify spending almost twice as much for an Apple product.  I am glad I went with the bigger 8.9" HD vs the equally priced 7" HDX.  The faster processor interested me with the HDX but the bigger screen made more sense for what I wanted.  For reference, the 8.9" screen itself is as big as the entire 7" device.  My best suggestion, is go to Best Buy if you can, and give them a test drive.  Just cuz this is the "older" OS and "slower" processor does NOT necessarily make this the "red headed step child" of tablets.  Let's face it just 365 days ago this was THE Kindle to get.  I am glad I got the device I did, but it is ALL personal taste.  Do your research to find what will fit YOUR needs the best as every device will have its positives and it's drawbacks.  Happy shopping

Reviews.Title: Kindle HD 8.9, never worked properly
Reviews.Author: Barbara Dee
Reviews.Content: I had the "First Generation", Kindle, ..Loved it.  Had it for almost 2 years, but unfortunately, my husband dropped. So I bought the new Kindle HD 8.9 from Amazon, at a reduced price (new not refurbished !!!). I returned the broken one. The new one kept turning itself off while I was using it.I called Amazon,I was told that there was something wrong with the hard drive. I was sent another Kindle HD 8.9, now this one turns itself off and on. I called Amazon, and they told me they would get back to me, I am still waiting. Both of the 8.9 never worked properly. I never heard back from Amazon, it has been a few weeks. I had trouble with both from the very beginning !!!

Reviews.Title: It's Just Okay
Reviews.Author: Ms. S. Jeannie "Good or bad, my opinions are ...
Reviews.Content: Let me just start by saying that I absolutely ¢¾LOVE¢¾ the text-to-speech feature.  I love it so much that this, alone gets FIVE STARS from me.  However, it goes downhill from there.  One of the MOST annoying things about this device is that when browsing, it often FREEZES and I then have to shut down the device (restart) in order to accomplish anything.  The other thing that I don't like (which is totally not Amazon's fault) is that there is no Adobe Flash Player capability on this device.  So, any web site that requires Flash Player, is useless to me.  I have seen all of the "work-arounds", but am unwilling to compromise my warranty in any way.Now, back to what I like:  The large screen is delightful, the sound is devine and it has a camera...something that I did not have with my first-generation Kindle Fire.\Over all, it's just okay.  Glad I didn't have to pay full price.  I got it as a replacement for my 1st-generation Kindle Fire, which, by the way, I have had to replace EVERY YEAR.  First one just didn't work after a year and the second one had issues with the charging port (which is a common problem with that generation Kindle Fire).  Unfortunately, the second one was out of warranty...so they offered this one to me at a reduced rate.  I am hopeful that it will last me longer than one year.  If not, I will let you all know.

Reviews.Title: Upgraded from a Kindle Fire first generation
Reviews.Author: Jennifer Gibson
Reviews.Content: I decided it was time to upgrade since there are so many newer versions out there.  I upgraded from the Kindle Fire 7" first generation, I got it the week they were introduced.  If I had gotten the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" first, I might like it better but I have several things that I like better about the first generation.  I really would like for there to be a light that comes on when it is charging like on the first generation.  Twice now I have plugged it in only to come back hours later and still find the battery dead because the little light was not there telling me that it was indeed charging.  I like the favorites being displayed on the screen at all times also (as in the first generation), having to touch the star and then make my choice is just annoying when I'm used to it being on the screen all the time.  The screen quality is great (I wouldn't go so far as to say better than the original version though).  The sound quality is good.  I bought one with 32GB instead of 8GB which of course I love, but honestly I wish I had just stuck with my first one and not purchased this one.  I'm not giving it a bad review, like I said, I would like it if were my first Kindle purchase, but it's not and 9 times out of 10 I still grab my 7" over this one.

Reviews.Title: Really Like It!
Reviews.Author: Wendy Louise Boyle
Reviews.Content: I just received my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" as a replacement to my first edition Kindle Fire. So far, I really like it - the size, clarity, color is perfect, The only issue that I have is the Power button doesn't light up. It would have been nice to have this include an LED.

Reviews.Title: Nice but not perfect
Reviews.Author: Jay from Redmond
Reviews.Content: This is a nice tablet, but not perfect.Pros:**** reader:  very nice reader, including in the daytime.  Since it is a color display, it probably isn't best for reading in sunshine, but for me, reading in the shade on a sunny day is fine.***** video:  very nice.  I have Amazon Prime, so can watch movies.  Nice, fun!Cons:** speed:  sometimes okay, sometimes surprisingly slow.  Slow perf is usually when surfing the web.* Silk web browser:  silk frequently gets unresponsive, and offers to close itself** weight:  it is a bit heavy, at least for holding vertically to read booksOverall:Clearly it is  a compromise for being both a reader and a video machine and a web browsing tablet.In retrospect, I wish I had gotten the 7" just to be lighter weight, as I primarily use it as book reader

Reviews.Title: Great hardware, terrible software
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I bought this in January and returned it almost immediately, but am only now writing a review for it. The hardware is fine, but I hate the carousel "frequently used" interface (every album you play gets added to it, quickly cluttering it up and requiring manual removal) and locked-down app store (with like 1% of the google play store's app selection), and Silk is the most unstable web browser I've used since Netscape 4. I highly recommend going with a Nexus 7" or 10" instead.

Reviews.Title: Bad Kindle
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have spent hours and hours with Kindle Technicians trying to fix a bug in it that won't allow me to download or read books on it.  They keep promising me to fix the problem but they don't.  They keep promising that their technical division will soon be back with me but they never contact me.

Reviews.Title: Go with 8.9" HD for surround sound, HD videos and tv connectivity, but stick with 1st gen Kindle Fire for internet videos
Reviews.Author: nyc "nyc"
Reviews.Content: The new Kindle Fire 8.9" HD can't do Internet very well. They don't have Flash, so they cannot play videos on websites that have them.Plus videos from Amazon that are in standard formats don't look so good in HD.  Image size on 8.9 are not much bigger than the (1st gen) old 7"--only 1" more due to wide margins on the sides of the screen.  Definitely don't get the new (HD) 7" if you can get the old 7" because the screen on the old one is more proportional for movies or if you want to watch videos on websites.If people get the HD, then 8.9 is better if one can afford it. The good things about the HD version is that the sound is better as the surround sound is noticeable, HD video does look HD, and it can be connected to the television through a purchased HDMI cable (not an option on the old or HDX version).  Other than those few things, the functionality are similar on the old and the new HD Kindle Fires.On my HD Fire, it occasionally had problems downloading or streaming videos from my Amazon account. The cursor would spin and spin until I leave a few times from the video and return later to play it again. This could be because of a slower speed on my internet.  With HD, you do want higher memory storage and Internet speed to run 100% smoothly.I think if you never owned the 1st generation Kindle Fire, this 8.9" HD would seem like it is an amazing technology as it has a smooth look and feel. I would have probably given this a 4 or 5 stars if this was my first Kindle Fire.  However, for those of us who owned the 1st generation Kindle Fire, by comparison, we are not as impressed by the upgrades because though there were improvements, Amazon also took away some of the good stuff that the old version had in its system including physical components such as button locations and charging light, etc.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: candi
Reviews.Content: What can I say... I LOVE the Kindle Fire. I am a fan 100%. The Kindle Fire HD 8.9  is my second one. I started with the original 1st generation when it first came out. Since then, I've upgraded  to this one. It's fantastic, as usual,  the hd is beautiful, the graphics, colors, and clarity. There are quite a few different features. There's Skype; more speakers for better sound quality. And there's a different look here and there. Amazon keeps making them better and better.***UPDATE: Do not get discouraged and ditch this device or any new kindle fires, because there's no flash player. ALL TABLETS do not have it, including iPads. Adobe is to blame for this not Amazon or any other company. Adobe has pulled the plug on installing flash on all phones and all tablets. They are sticking only to computers. Now, the beauty of these tablets (the Kindle fires) is that they are ANDROID, people.:) There's a remedy for that. So, don't hate the Kindle Fire. Since, we are all one kindle fire family, here goes: (1). Go to settings, device, allow installation of outside applications select "yes". (2). Download from the Amazon Appstore Es File Explorer (3). Go to the web and search - download dolphin browser. (4). Then using dolphin browser search - download Adobe flash player 11. (5). If needed go to Es File Explorer, go to downloads and install from there. That's it. Now you should have flash player. However, to use the flash player you need to use the dolphin browser because it will not work on the Kindle fire's Silk browser. The Silk browser has an experimental video streamer but it does not work on all videos.Without flash the Kindle Fire is still a great tablet, so, either way enjoy.

Reviews.Title: Silk  Browser is Terrible!!
Reviews.Author: Mary Mathews
