Reviews.Content: Its everything that I hoped it would be, right size, easy to use and has a great HD picture. PERFECT!

Reviews.Title: I Think This is Great!
Reviews.Author: D. Knight "Dee Dee"
Reviews.Content: This replaces last year's Kindle Fire and I enjoy this one so much more. The main reason is the larger display - it's just easier for me to see. But it is also easier to use. I didn't realize that at first, it takes a little while to get used to the changes in the user interface even though they are minor. When you do get used to them you realize it really is easier to use.If you are getting this and are also looking for a great case, I recommend this one: Marware Revolve Portrait and Landscape Standing Case. This is the one I have and I think it is fantastic.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet
Reviews.Author: Neville T. Wilson
Reviews.Content: I love the Kindle Fire HD. my only problem is that I can not purchase anything from the Amazon Apps Store, when I am out of the USA. Apart from that. Great Tablet

Reviews.Title: kindle fire hd
Reviews.Author: RUBY BERRY
Reviews.Content: This is a nice tablet but the camera feature is too awkward to use. I like the size 8.9 makes it easy to view movies and web content.

Reviews.Title: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is nice for my wife
Reviews.Author: Wayne Bradbury
Reviews.Content: My wife likes the Kindle Fire HD, but she hasn't figured  out how to load music or most of her pictures to it since it is registered under my sign-on and my music and her music have different play lists and different favorite singers in them. The Amazon Cloud seems to be pretty trickie to upload songs onto because it can only be under my Amazon Account.She does like playing Scramble and Words with Friends on the Kindle Fire instead of on her Android phone because it is always freezing up in the middle of a game and the Kindle Fire doesn't do that.  She likes reading on it a little better than on her old 7" Kindle too.

Reviews.Title: just right for what I'm using it for
Reviews.Author: Avery L. Hasty
Reviews.Content: I use my kindle fire for emails and checking on amazon orders.I found it much easyer to carry and operate than my laptop.I can be done by the time the laptop fires up.It also works with my skype account.

Reviews.Title: love it
Reviews.Author: mel
Reviews.Content: i love the ease of use, screen quality, app choices, deals on books with Prime. i wish the drawing apps were a little better. Other than that the space bar is tricky when typing.

Reviews.Title: kindle HD 8.9 great
Reviews.Author: Patricia
Reviews.Content: This kindle HD it great, why spend more than  $600 $700 hundred dollars when you can have this kindle HD  it's very light very no like the IPAD 4.....I'm very happy with this table..

Reviews.Title: exceeded expectations
Reviews.Author: Luis Gussoni
Reviews.Content: great product, great features, USB is a plus, sound is decent, overall a very positive evaluation so far. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: very lmpressed
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: This kindle so easy to work.  L ended getting the 8.9 inch HD with 64 gigabits off memory.Love it.I would recommend this Kindle to everybody.

Reviews.Title: Absolutely LOVE it!
Reviews.Author: Windhoundfan
Reviews.Content: Last year when I bought my basic Kindle I never thought I would like it better then reading from a regular book, but I loved it so much that this year I bought the Kindle Fire HD 8.9.  I've had it for approximately one month and my husband is joking about how it is 'glued' to me.  Literally, I find it hard to part with it!  I have all my music at hand with Amazon's cloud, all my books, and can easily view almost any movie I wish by accessing my Netflix, HBO, or Amazon accounts.  How nice to have your whole digital library travel with you!Although I almost bought the smaller 7 inch, I'm glad I decided on this one.  It seems like the perfect compromise between the larger Ipad and the smaller tablets. Its more weighty, but I can appreciate the extra screen space and think I would have been frustrated with a smaller one.  Its nicely thin, its battery life is decent, and I've had no bugs surface yet. Getting used to the interface was very intuitive.  I do have 'Special Offers' version and don't find the ads to be a problem.I am amazed at the sound that comes from this little device-  especially pleased with the way Dolby digital can immerse you with  sound seeming to surround you.  The picture is also super-clear and I've had no problem connecting to WiFi and getting a decent signal.  Movies run great and smoothly.  As to Apps, I've found some great ones that are keeping me way too busy, and although the selection may not be as great as the Ipad has available, I'm sure the market will improve, increase, and blossom.The reason I went with the Kindle Fire HD was the good reviews its been getting and the attractive price... but Amazon's good customer service that I've enjoyed over the years definitely was a big deciding factor.  This Kindle has so far been problem-free, but I did have a small sound issue that was my fault in not understanding the controls fully.  In the Kindle's help files it gave me a choice to have Customer service call me to resolve my issue.  No sooner did I click on that then my home phone rang with a polite & helpful Amazon customer service representative asking if I needed help!  I didn't think I could be more of a fan of Amazon's customer service, but now I think I worship at their feet!!Areas that could improve on this Kindle (Nothing is ever perfect, mind you!):1) sometimes I find the 'touch' controls to be too sensitive when I am scrolling- especially albums in the music section.  Wish there was more of a border/neutral area to swipe so that I'm not constantly opening albums when I just want to do a gentle scroll.2) Shopping is way too easy...(I don't expect they would even want to change this, LOL)3) Sound and on/off button IS sometimes hard to access easily, although having a cover that turns it on/off is a plus...4) Wish it was lighter in weight (as I want to carry it everywhere)  It fits nicely in my pocketbook, but it IS a weight to carry around after a while.I rarely write reviews, but had to this time because I love this little device so!  Its one of the best Christmas presents I've bought myself!

Reviews.Title: Great Gift
Reviews.Author: KJ
Reviews.Content: This was a gift for my wife's birthday. She loves it. The screen is bright, clear and the sound is great. My wife is very pleased and so am I!

Reviews.Title: I  almost totally LOVE it!  ADDENDUM:
Reviews.Author: fathobbit
Reviews.Content: This is my second Kindle.  I received it on November 26th.  The 8.9 HD 4G LTE.  The lack of a charger was nothing to be concerned with as most are now universal anyway. Out of the box was a little frustrating as the first thing it does is a large download as an update.  Just seems like Amazon could have done that on their data usage instead of mine.  I do absolutely love the screen it is amazing.  I love the Swype feature, it makes reviews a breeze.  I have had a little time to get to know it better now and am so very curious WHY Kindle felt the need to do away with the bookmark feature or I should say revise the bookmark feature. The old Kindle would go back to any previous bookmark made in the book, the new one only allows for the most recent bookmark, VERY annoying as I sometimes like to go back to a previous spot to recheck my memory of a person or event. Why would kindle feel the need  to fix something that wasn't broken. For that one very annoying thing I would have given it 5 incredibly awesome stars. Still the absolute best devise out there for the money!!I found the bookmark...instead of looking under bookmark look under"note" and VIOLA notes and bookmarks pop up....oh my I would feel like an idiot except notes are NOT what I was looking for...ENJOY your NEW Kindle!!!!

Reviews.Title: Kindle
Reviews.Author: Deanne
Reviews.Content: Awesome love my new kindle HD. Gave daughter the old one. My sister bought the new one also for bigger screen. Great colors

Reviews.Title: WOW
Reviews.Author: Into the Past "PDW"
Reviews.Content: I started with the first Kindle. I love to read and hear music. This one does it all and is transportable. Fits in my purse with a case. I have a wifi and the $49.00 per year program keeps me online. Easy to learn and operate.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet
Reviews.Author: Terri Berry
Reviews.Content: I've been very pleased with my Kindle Fire so far. The picture quality is excellent. My two year old grandson steels it from me all of the time to watch his children's shows on it. I also love that is so easy to shop from the Amazon web site from it. I would recommend the Kindle Fire HD to anyone looking for a simple, inexpensive tablet.

Reviews.Title: You Get What You Pay For - Kindle Fire died and so has my faith in Amazon
Reviews.Author: FranTodd
Reviews.Content: Read the reviews thoroughly before buying.  Our Kindle Fire froze on the boot screen just four months after the one year warranty expired and all Amazon could do is offer us a refurbished Kindle for half the price of a new one if I return the old one.  If you read the reviews this is a repetitive problem for Amazon and they are probably making money hand over fist on the refurbished units.  I love saving money, but when Amazon advertises the cost of a Kindle being much lower than an iPad, you have to factor in the cost of replacement.  I've had an iPad for many years with no problems whatsoever.  Granted, I dislike Apple's OS, but the unit hasn't died on me.Amazon refused to replace my unit, even with a refurbished Kindle, to save face with a customer who has given them business since the day they started.  I'm also done with Amazon.

Reviews.Title: you get what you paid for and a lot less than you expected
Reviews.Author: Andrew Edmundson
Reviews.Content: Since the only thing that Amazon seems to be able to dream up in their marketing is that kindle fire has a lower price than other competing products it should be no surprise that it is an inferior product. It is a mediocore performer as a reader and Silk is a joke. Constantly crashing with even the simplest browsing.Amazon should be embarassed by quality and performance of their product and even after a few years of many complaints  from users offered no update to improve Silk.Over a year of frustrating attempts to use my Kindle Fire and still Disappointed .

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Tere
Reviews.Content: I've had people come and ask me what I have.  Can you say green?  People who have other mini-laptops are so green!  I feel sorry for them.  The HD is crisp, the audio is great -- even without headphones that I recommend be used to get the full enjoyment.  As I am a member of Prime, I can tell you watching movies on this is just an incredible experience (especially when husband is asleep next to you and you wear headphones!) and I love it.The ONLY problem I have is wi-fi just SUCKS up the battery charge.  I haven't bought the FAST battery charger yet -- next payday -- but you'll want one.  And probably a keyboard, if you prefer to type rather than using a stylus.  I use this to take notes in class, and it is wonderful!  (See my review of the HP wireless printer, the HP 8600 Premium Pro -- I can print my notes right from my Kindle!)I thought about the HDX, but heard the rear camera wasn't all that great, I can't advise to that.  The special ads I've already learned to overlook them; they aren't that intrusive.  When I bought my model, it wasn't available without the ads, so I just got it. I'm not sorry I saved the money, LOL.  There are more apps than you'll ever need (be careful to read ALL the reviews and take heed as I've bought a few that just don't work!).  If you don't need the rear camera or the "Mayday" key (I don't) then buy this.  Also highly recommended is the extra two year warranty plan.

Reviews.Title: We were lied to and misled
Reviews.Author: B. K. Wallen
Reviews.Content: The kindle is not a bad book reader. Having said that however, anyone with children BEWARE!  First, the default is one click purchasing.  This will usually cost you around $50 if you catch it quick enough.  Much, MUCH more if you don't.  No kid can resist instant gratification with a single click, consequences down the road.  GAMERS BEWARE!  Most free games have many, many add-ons available for PURCHASE (think 'one click' ease).  Recently our device completely reset itself (Amazon blames us). Guess what happens to every purchase (other than books) ever made.  THEY COMPLETELY DISAPPEAR!!  No problem, you purchased these via Amazon one click so they can be restored. Right?  WRONG.  Amazon advised they keep none of this.  Try going to each individual 'developer' of these apps to try to restore your purchases.  We are not sure how to figure out exactly who each developer is as the purchases are listed simply as 'Cuddly Puppy' and such.  No developer info is given and we are not sure which game each add on goes with or how the developer will be able to go back through amazon and provide this for us.  Will their customer service be like amazon's?  Hope not.  No more add on game purchases and NO MORE KINDLES for us.  We are extremely disappointed in Amazons business model for the Kindle.  Apparently it is just an income producing shopping conduit for Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Very disatisfied customer!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Art Liberatore
Reviews.Content: Total BS, you pay close to $300.00 for the equipment  to get, and it comes with a cord and no plug.  If that's a way of doing business, trying to squeeze even more money out a consumer then I want no parts of any anything this company sells.  If I could of given no stars, I would have.  I will tell all my friends and family about this and recommend they go else where!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Donna Lynch
Reviews.Content: I am a faithful Kindle owner, also have several friends I have encouraged to buy a Kindle, so it pains me to say I am disappointed with this purchase. I bought this as a Christmas present for myself. I went with the bigger size, but opted for just the HD because of the price.First off, the larger size makes it hard for me to hold in the palm of my hand (and I have big hands, really).It's really, really, really HEAVY!!!  I knew it weighed more than the HDX (kinda wonder why that is?), but figured it couldn't be THAT heavy...it is.I didn't buy the charger plug, thinking I had just bought a new one and it should work...wrong.  So, I am forking out another $20 to buy the plug, based on reviews I've seen here. Wondering why this wasn't included without the full charger.  Like buying a car without a gas tank.It takes FOREVER to charge, and on top of that it no way stays charged for 10 hours, more like 4.Now I know why I saved $70 on this purchase. Amazon is trying to get rid of this lemon of a tablet.Extremely disappointed.

Reviews.Title: I'm disappointed.
Reviews.Author: Jacquelyn Briggs "carb queen"
Reviews.Content: It freezes constantly and I have to restart.  Also, it doesn't support  flash, which I had on the original 7" Kindle Fire.

Reviews.Title: I LOVE Kindles......when they work
Reviews.Author: Motherskiss "PROUD AMAZON ADDICT"
Reviews.Content: I have had 4 Kindles. The first time I received the Kindle Fire (1st gen) I knew the charging design was flawed. Sure enough not 6 months later...charging problems. by that time the 2nd gen was born. I was hopeful all would be well. Nope charging problems. So I am sitting here having gone almost two weeks without my Kindle. I requested a replacement the moment the screen flashed out never to turn on again. That was almost two weeks ago. I have been calling Amazon everyday since. Finally yesterday they agreed my replacement should have been here by now, so they sent out another. Hopefully it wont take a week to get here. i had to actually pick up a paper book to read. Made my earth footprint just a little bigger.

Reviews.Title: Love this Kindle!!!
Reviews.Author: Jorge Salinas
Reviews.Content: I had bought my wife a kindle fire before.  She loved it very much and got great use out of it.  I had no idea what to buy her for her birthday and saw this advertised on your website.  After a little bit of research, I found this would be an ideal gift for her.  At first she was taken back by it being much larger than her other Kindle, but she quickly adapted.  I hardly see my wife anymore, to be honest.  She is lost in the world of kindle.  :)

Reviews.Title: wifi connectin issues.
Reviews.Author: barry massey
Reviews.Content: I love my kindle fire hd and all you can do with it...except for the wifi issue. The device will not stay connected to the wifi. I have to go in and turn off wifi and then turn back on every time I use it. Otherwise it is a great product.

Reviews.Title: Personally, it works for me
Reviews.Author: L. Semmel
Reviews.Content: I have had my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 16G for roughly 3-4 months. I originally did not want a tablet; I already had a Kindle 3G (which I love) and a smart phone (which I hate) and my desktop computer for internet when I needed to do something online. I have been pleasantly surprised. I am not technologically dumb, or especially tech-savy, but contrary to many reviews I read I found the Fire to be pretty easy to use. Maybe because I took time to figure it out and had no preconceived notions or expectations? I don't know.Short versioin: Do I like it? Yes! Could I live without it? Yes. Are there things I would change? Of course. But I like it! :DLong version:-Physical features. Heavier than I expected, but manageable. Occasionally I turn it off without meaning to, usually when I'm trying to adjust the volume and hit power instead. I wish the power button lit up when plugged in to let you know if it was fully charged or charging. Its kind of wierd that the speakers are on the back of the device; the sound can either be amplified or dampened depending on where and how you have it sitting. It does not come with a charger, only a USB cord, which I think is stupid, but since I already had one from my Kindle 3G it wasnt as big a deal as it would have been. It does charge a little slower than I expected, and the battery only lasts about 8-10 hours, less if you're playing a game.-Readablilty. I like that I can adjust the screen brightness for interior light. BUT the screen glares horribly outside, even in the shade. If I know I'm going to be outside, I take my Kindle 3G instead. Otherwise, I have no problems.-Ease of use. I don't know how other tablets are set up, since this is my first, but I find it fairly easy. The carousel holds all of the content you have accessed recently so you can scroll through and find what you want. There are also tabs at the top marked games, books, apps, etc so that you can search by media type. There is a search bar above that, but I haven't used it at all so can't say whether or not it's good. When away from the home page, a bar at the bottom offers home, back, search, and favorite buttons. You drag down the top bar for settings, which is where you go for parental controls, applications, security, etc. Books in the carousel tell you the percentage you've read at the top corner, but I do wish I could sort my books into "read", "new", etc, like the regular Kindles. Overall, I think it's pretty simple.-Preloaded content. The HD comes preloaded with a few things I find helpful, such as Skype, Facebook, Pandora, and an email management program that allows me access to multiple email accounts from one location, which I really like. It also comes with Kindle Free Time (which my kids are mostly too old for), OfficeSuite (which I'm still trying to figure out if I even need) and IMDB (which for me is a waste of space). You cannot remove these from the device. Why must this stuff take up space if I am not going to use it, EVER? They are not necessary, so why are they there? That's that much more space I could have for books! But then again, they only bug me when I notice them, which is not very often.-Silk browser/WiFi. I had a bit of trouble connecting to the internet at first, but a 15-20 minute phone conversation with tech support got the problem (my router, not the Kindle) sorted out. I have taken my Kindle all over and had no problems with the WiFi anywhere that has a signal, even a low one. Even out in the boonies. Silk browser works fine for me, have no problems with speed unless my internet service is being wonky. It comes with Bing.com as the default search engine, but you can change this in the settings. Absolutely love that I can use it for recipes without having to drag the laptop to my tiny kitchen!-Movie/sound quality. I have only watched YouTube and FB videos so far, so no movie opinions yet. YT and FB seem to be fine, relative to the quality uploaded to the site. Sound is better than my laptop, not as good as my iPod. Again, wierd that the speakers are on the bottom.-Camera. I dislike that the camera only faces one way. To take pics of something other than yourself, you have to turn it and look at a wierd angle. Pic quality was not great, either, but that might have been operator error.-Shopping. The Fire HD has two quick-links to Amazon shopping; the "Shop" tab at the top, and the "Shop Amazon" widget in the carousel. My biggest complaint is that when shopping for books and apps the page is a little hard to navigate. In all fairness, I'm comparing the "computer store" to the "tablet store", but it seems that some categories available on the computer are not available on the tablet. I can still find what I'm looking for, but it takes longer, especially if just browsing.-The ads. A lot of people have a problem with the preloaded ads on the Kindle. If an ad doesn't interest me, I don't pay it any attention, just like tv. The recommendations at the bottom of the carousel also don't bother me, and if they do, I can turn it off. If you think they will bother you, then either get the more expensive one with no preloaded ads, or pay the $15 or whatever to have them removed.

Reviews.Title: Changes made from the original, not good changes!
Reviews.Author: Jeramie Coffelt
Reviews.Content: A couple of things, first Flash is NO LONGER SUPPORTED.  They use their own version but it doesnt work worth a dang and you have to do some work around to get flash player to work (Download Dolphin Browser).Also, the touchscreen doesnt seem to work worth a dang.  Perhaps its mine alone but honestly, it is slow to react pretty often.

Reviews.Title: The icons won't stay where I put them, and the Amazon Cloud sometimes goes missing!
Reviews.Author: Merrall G.
Reviews.Content: I've got an iPad (4th-generation), a Kindle Keyboard, a Kindle Paperwhite, and this Kindle Fire HD 8.9" In addition, I've got the Kindle App on my iPad. Of them all, I like the Kindle App on my iPad the best (because it allows outside content to be saved on it, ie not only from Amazon). Apart from that, I like, or dislike, each of the Kindles for different reasons.Since this review is about the Kindle Fire HD 8.9", I'll just refer to the others where it's relevant.Bear in mind that I'm 72, and I'm Australian (with an Australian billing address), and I'm currently in South Korea (where I'll be for a while). Those three pieces of information are relevant to what I have to say.KINDLE FIRE HD 8.9"When I bought my Kindle Fire HD, I was actually on a trip to America. Naively, I thought that - having bought the Kindle Fire HD in America (although using my Australian billing address), I'd be able to download movies, for watching while I'm traveling around (which I do a lot). Moreover, I thought I would be able to join Amazon Prime, and have access to all the thousands of movies, and TV programs, that Prime members can download - just for their $79-per-year subscription. Also, I expected that I'd be able to get access to individual songs, as MP3 downloads.However, despite the fact that, as soon as I got my Kindle Fire HD, I was sent an e-mail from Amazon, telling me all the wonderful things I'd get as a Prime subscriber (including free 2-day shipping) - and giving me a one-month trial to boot - I could not, in fact, be a Prime member.  As soon as I tried to activate Prime, I was told that I was geographically restricted - couldn't even get one-track MP3 downloads. It seems that - to get into the Prime deal - one must have a US billing address, and a US home address.So that was a big disappointment. I was initially so miffed that I thought I'd return the Kindle Fire HD to Amazon, especially since I was still in the US at the time I found I would be subject to geographic restriction. But I kept the Kindle Fire HD because I realized that it was better for a few other functions, than either the Kindle Keyboard, or the Paperwhite.PLUS FACTORS for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9"1) AUDIOBOOKSIt seems that audiobooks don't have geographic restrictions, as movies, TV programs, and music have. So I've bought several audiobooks and, although the speakers aren't really powerful, they are powerful enough, if you are sitting in a quiet room, to hear the book reading very clearly. In addition, it's possible to use a bluetooth speaker, to get louder sound if it's wanted. Since I majored in English Literature - many years ago! - I'm on a mission to listen my way through all of the classics of the English language (which is so much more relaxing, via listening, than doing all that eye-wearing reading, with a hard-to-hold paperback that won't stay open at the pages you want it to). For example, I've just finished listening to "The Great Gatsby" and that was easy listening - except that the reader, Jake Gyllenhaal, wasn't able to project any sort of vocal personality for the all-important females - Daisy in particular. Just listening to Jake Gyllanhaal's effort to "find" a voice for Daisy (unsuccessfully) left me feeling there'd be no way that a listener/reader (who didn't already know the book well) could believe in Gatsby's obsession with a Daisy that the wish-washy unnoticeable voice personality that Jake Gyllenhaal's narration assigned to her.Given that it would surely not be easy for a man to render the voice of a young, upper-class, beautiful temptress, with any subtlety or authenticity, I think Audible should use cheaper unknown actors, so the budget could stretch to both a male and female narrator. What Audible seems to be doing is trying to tempt buyers by hiring big-name actors to do the narration. If Jake Gyllenhaal's no-impact rendition of Daisy is an example of the worth of using famous actors, it's a strategy that could backfire.2) MUSIC VIA THE AMAZON CLOUDAlthough I can't get single-track MP3 downloads, I can get instant music to the Kindle Fire HD, if I buy CDs (with AutoRip). As soon as you pay for those CDs - to be delivered to somewhere (anywhere for CDs - expensive shipping to Korea or Australia, but cheap to a friend in America, especially with free shipping for an order over $25), all of the songs are automatically delivered to your Kindle Fire HD (as well as to your PC, Kindle App, etc.) So I'm very happy with that - I've now got about 17 albums loaded up: everything from Vera Lynn and Frank Sinatra to Jackie Evancho and Josh Groban. As I write now, on my PC, I have "David Foster: Hit Man and Friends" playing in the background (on the Kindle Fire) - a bit away from me, rather than blasting out of the PC in front of me, to distract me.3) GADGET/SOFTWARE INSTRUCTION BOOKS (IN KINDLE FORMAT)Amazon has zillions of instruction books for IT gadgets and software programs: Kindle Fire HD itself, iPad, Android, Dropbox, Evernote, etc. For those sorts of instruction books - which have colored pictures, and screenshots, it's useless trying to learn from them, on a Kindle Keyboard, or Kindle Paperwhite: the pictures, tables, and screenshots don't translate well into black and white format, and the screens are too small to be able to get  "pageful" of text and graphics at the same time. I've never used a Kindle Fire 7", but I'd expect that Kindle to also have a screen which is be too small for these kinds of instructions book. But the screen size of the Kindle Fire HD is perfect for showing pretty much the information (plus graphics) that would fit on the page of a real book - or on the iPad screen.A second advantage of having those gadget/software instruction books on the Kindle Fire HD is that you can keep the "pages" open on the Kindle Fire while you are trying out operations and techniques on, for example, the Kindle App on the iPad, or on the iPad itself. So it's really like having a book beside you.A third advantage is that, if you had those instruction books on an iPad, (for using as a reference book "beside" you, while you learn on another gadget), too much of the iPad charge is being used up to keep the books "open" for long periods of time. (It seems that the iPad gobbles up power a lot faster than the Kindle Fire HD does.) So, if you keep the iPad on its default auto-off setting (2 mins), to save the charge, it keeps turning itself off - unless you are actually touching the screen. The Kindle Fire HD stays "on" better, because there's not such a risk of running out of power too soon, if you leave it set at a higher time period for auto-off (such as 30 mins). Of course, it's possible to set both gadgets to "Never" to keep them on all the time you want that "reference book" open beside you - and I did that once, with the iPad. But I forgot to put it back to "2 mins" when I'd finished. So the iPad stayed on "forever" - presumably keeping a sensor fully employed, checking for Wifi hotspots wherever I went (even though it wouldn't have found many that I could connect to, since I don't have a cell-phone with a Wifi hotspot). The result was that, the next time I went to use the iPad - thinking it was still well charged - it was stone dead! Well, the Kindle Fire HD doesn't run out of charge as fast as the iPad, so it seems safe to leave it set on something like 30 minutes (auto-off) all the time - although it would probably be a good idea to set it back to 5 minutes, when finished using it.4)GOOD FONT/BACKGROUND COLOR OPTION FOR GLARE-SENSITIVE EYESI have eyes that are very sensitive to glare - white glare from screens, and glossy surfaces. The Kindle Fire HD, unfortunately, has a very glossy screen (compared to the Kindle Keyboard, and Kindle Paperwhite). But I've found a very good way to deal with that glare, such that I can comfortably read from the Kindle Fire HD screen. You can choose your default screen colours - with three options: black font on white background; black font on off-white (sort of like the Kindle Keyboard buff color), and white font on black background. I find that, even with the Kindle Fire HD's glossy screen, I can read very comfortably with that white lettering on a black background. It's a great way to reduce all the glare we get from white screens.NEGATIVE FACTORS for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9"1. GEOGRAPHIC RESTRICTION FOR MOVIES, TV PROGRAMS, MP3 MUSIC DOWNLOADS, AND PRIMEOne big negative, for me, was outlined above: with an Australian bill-paying account, I can't download movies, TV programs, or MP3 music tracks - or be a member of Amazon Prime (although on my account screen, I keep getting messages that inform me I should join Prime, to reduce the shipping charges that I'm incurring - to Korea,mostly, and that's definitely not a free 2-day deal).2. KINDLE KEYBOARD AND KINDLE PAPERWHITE BETTER FOR READING LONG BOOKSDespite being able to set the screen for white lettering on a black background, it's nowhere near as comfortable to read lengthy books (such as novels) on the glossy KINDLE FIRE HD screen - and it's quite a bit heavier to hold up. For general book reading, I actually prefer the Kindle Keyboard best of all - with the e-ink off-white background that's not so glary, although it's handy to have back-lighting on the Paperwhite for reading at night, on airplanes.3. CAN'T PLACE YOUR ITEM ICONS WHERE YOU WANT TO PUT THEM, AND MAKE THEM STAY THERE!If you've got a lot of books loaded on to the Kindle Fire HD (and this is also relevant for the iPad Kindle App), you can't make them stay on the Home screen, in some order that suits you. It always happens that, as soon as you access one book, it comes to the top of the heap (so to speak), and so you've lost your grouping of similar kinds of books. In my case, I've got a bunch of RV books, many Instruction books for gadgets, various Travel guides, and Novels, etc. So it annoys the hell out of me when I've gone to the trouble to have all similar books "sitting" arranged beside each other, on the Home screen display. Then, as soon as I access one book, that book comes to the top of the display (or the beginning of the display), and will then end up mixed up with other books that are not in a similar category.Now, compare this with iBooks, on the iPad - which is excellent from this point of view.When you save a book for reading in iBooks, you can hold your finger on the book (or pdf) icon, and then move the icon to wherever you want it to be, in your collection. Subsequently, having placed each icon where you want it to be, it stays there - such that, every time you access that book (or pdf), or any other, the items go back "to bed" at the place on the "bookrack" where you put them. Not only does that allow you to keep all your collections grouped together, but it also facilitates developing a visual memory of where particular books or pdf files are, on the bookshelf - very useful if you've got a large collection of pdf files, and they all look pretty much alike, until you bring them up on to the reading screen where you can read the "cover" print more easily.This feature (or non-feature) is particularly a pain (on the Kindle iPad app), with Lonely Planet pdf files of their guidebooks. Lonely Planet has a few guidebooks as single-file pdf files. But, mostly, they supply the books as a bunch of separate chapters (like mini-books)- without an overall single-file pdf for the books that you've bought. So, just imagine what a mess you can get into with all those individual chapters - especially since the topics of the individual chapters can't easily be read until you bring them up fully on the screen. In addition, for almost all of the guidebooks that come in chapter bundles, the background colors are the same. Each country group of chapters has a unique picture on the cover of every chapter in the collection, but the pictures are small and you can't really see them until you bring a book (a chapter mini-book) up for reading.Consequently, you get a really messy situation because of Kindles (for the iPad app, or stand-alone Kindles)not allowing you to place your books, in the display, where you want them - and where they will return to after use. For instance, if I bring up a chapter of "Nicaragua" (out of perhaps 13 chapters), and then I bring up a chapter of "Columbia", and then one of "Bolivia" and also "Peru" - all of which I've got on my iPad (saved in both the Kindle App, and iBooks) - I end up with all of the chapters totally scrambled in the filing system; that occurs because no one chapter goes back to "its place" among the other chapters for the guidebook that it belongs to.So I have to use up more of my iPad's memory than I'd like, by saving all those chapter pdf files into both places: in iBooks, to keep the chapters where I want them to be "filed"; in the Kindle App, so I can access the contents page, touch on a topic in the contents, and get taken immediately wherever I choose to go. (With iBooks, for the same LP guide books, you can't access the contents page as a list, touch on a topic you want to go to, and be routed instantly to that topic - a very helpful feature of the Kindle App.)4. CAN'T USE THE AMAZON CLOUD TO COPY PDF FILES)FROM THE iPAD KINDLE APP TO THE KINDLE FIRE HD.When I buy those pdf files of guidebooks, from Lonely Planet (and they are not the same as buying Kindle-ized books of LP guidebooks - which are usually awful, with unreadable maps), I can save those pdf files to the Kindle App on the iPad, and that's fine - except for the mini-book chapters not staying where I want them to stay! However, the Amazon Cloud doesn't seem to allow me to then copy those pdf files on to the Kindle Fire HD - where I'd really like to have them.Imagine wandering around the back streets of just about any Latin American city (where I intend to be for some months of next year), with your iPad in your hand for consulting your off-Wifi guidebook. If you're foolish enough to be doing that - particularly an old woman like me - there's a pretty good chance some local desperado will grab the iPad and run. On the other hand, a Kindle Fire HD 8.9" would be a way less attractive trophy for a street-roaming snatcher (one who can tell an iPad from a Kindle Fire HD!); the Kindle Fire HD would also be much lighter for carrying around all day, and consulting; plus, even if the Kindle Fire HD does get grabbed, it's a whole lot cheaper to replace than an iPad.So I'd really like the Amazon Cloud to allow copying of pdf files from my iPad Kindle App, to my Kindle Fire HD. It's probably possible but I can't figure out how to do it. The Amazon Cloud doesn't seem to want to talk to anything not directly bought from Amazon, even if the pdf files are now "in the Amazon system" by virtue of being saved into the Kindle App on the iPad. .Now, here's the point of this for Amazon's bottom line. The Kindle Fire HD, as we all know, was designed to make it easy for all of us to buy Amazon books, audiobooks, movies, etc - although I, with an Australian billing address, can't manage to buy movies, TV programs, MP3 downloads (or join Amazon Prime). We know, and accept, that this gadget was definitely not dreamed up by Amazon, to facilitate open-sourced buying. But you would think that a Kindle App on an iPad would be able to talk to a stand-alone Kindle, via the Amazon Cloud. Seems not - friends only if Apple is the friendship broker.Nevertheless, it seems to me that Amazon could benefit from allowing Lonely Planet pdf files to be transferred, via the Amazon Cloud, to a Kindle Fire HD. Why? Well, as most people have probably discovered, it's nice to do all the travel research on an electronic gadget. But, when it comes to the boots-on-the-ground traveling, nothing beats having an actual dead-tree guidebook - extensively thumbed, and defaced with with notes, stickers on pages, and highlighted text. It's very difficult to have those user-friendly possibilities if you are interacting with any kind of tablet, except for trivialities - such as the best places to sleep or eat.Therefore, allowing Lonely Planet's pdf files to be uploaded on to one's Kindle Fire HD, from an iPad Kindle app, would probably produce sales, from Amazon, of the real books when the travel time comes. Why again? It's way cheaper to buy the actual LP books from Amazon than from Lonely Planet, even if you live in Lonely Planet's country: Australia. For me, the price of buying an LP guidebook, in Australia, is about twice the price that I'd pay from Amazon (with no shipping charge, if I was passing through America, on my way to all those Latin American countries, and had the books delivered to my USA-transit accommodation, before my arrival in America).For example, I made a trip just to San Francisco about three months ago and, despite having some LP chapters, for San Francisco, on my iPad (as pdf files - before my arrival), I still bought two other SF guidebooks, from Amazon, and had them delivered to the place I intended staying at, in SF. Plus, also from Amazon on that SF trip, I bought several real guidebooks for Japan: Tokyo, Kyoto, Walking in Japan, etc.So if Amazon allows the uploading of LP pdf files on to a Kindle Fire HP - as Amazon Cloud transfers from an iPad Kindle Fire app, it doesn't mean that Amazon will go broke supporting non-Amazon booksellers. In fact, by allowing such transfers, it just builds greater customer loyalty to Amazon, and its Kindles - AND it's pretty good advertising if little old ladies, like me, are wandering around Nicaragua, Columbia, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Panama, and Costa Rica - and Japan - with their Kindle Fire HD's constantly on show. Amazon couldn't get that kind of advertising if the company paid for it!Therefore, I think there is a good reason for Amazon not to block pdf files from other publishers - especially from guidebook publishers, such as Lonely Planet, and especially if the pdf files are already in the Amazon system, saved into a Kindle App on an iPad..

Reviews.Title: A Good Tablet for a Good Price, but Not Without Some Drawbacks
Reviews.Author: Ryan
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD is a very good tablet for the price. I quickly bought the first generation Fire upon its release, and it was my first tablet. After using that smaller tablet for over a year, I decided to pick up the larger 8.9 inch HD model. After using it, I must say I actually prefer a smaller, 7 inch tablet. This is not a knock against the Kindle Fire HD 8.9, just a personal preference of mine regarding the size.The Pros:The price is a big selling point, in my opinion. I do not believe you can find another tablet this size for a cheaper price, but I may be wrong.The graphics and resolution are wonderful, and colors are very vibrant!The operating system is a step-up from first generation Kindles, but still not perfect (more on that in a bit).Some areas of content have a great selection! If you want to watch movies on your tablet, this is a great one to have! Amazon has a very good selection of films to rent or buy. And of course, don't forget about books. Amazon's selection of books is unmatched, and purchasing and downloading are very easy. I especially like how Kindles "communicate" between each other. For example, if I stop reading on my Kindle Fire HD, my other Kindle knows where I left off, which makes reading across devices very easy. The fact that all Kindles on an account sync with each other, if you want them to, is very helpful.The Cons:The app store just isn't very good. There are some decent games (my son enjoys many of them) but not anywhere close to the games available for Apple, or even Google Play for that matter. There are even fewer productivity apps, which is a big drawback for me. There also seems to be quite a few cheaply made, low quality bad apps. Because of this, the Fire is essentially a device to consume media on-that's it! If you're wanting to edit video or play around with photos, you'll be disappointed by the Fire.The camera is pretty weak, and is really only for video conferencing.The operating system, as noted elsewhere, is a heavily modified Android (and by heavily modified, I mean basically unrecognizable). I have an Apple phone, and love the iOS. I have never used a straight Android operating system, but only played around with devices. From my very limited experience, I think the unmodified Android is far better than what Amazon gives us on the Fire, and wish they would stop tinkering with it so much.Rumor has it a Kindle Fire HD 2 will be available later in 2013, and upon its release I look forward to seeing what improvements have been made. If enough enhancements have been done, I will most likely buy a 7 inch. While the Kindle Fire is not the best family of tablets, it is a good tablet at a good price that fits perfectly into the Amazon ecosystem of which I am firmly entrenched.

Reviews.Title: a ebook reader with tablet function
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have to say, I have high expectation of this kindle fire hd. I've used it for a few months now, and I feel disappointed. The pros are obvious, I like the high res screen, the amazon content, both books and prime videos. These are big big advantage over the ipad and other tablets, and that's the reason I didn't return it.The CONS are so many, I just list a few I don't like the most:1. low quality apps. not many really useful apps you can find. The app quality is worse. Take skype for example, it always drops connection, and has much lower video quality than my ipad2. my old ipad2 seldom drops connection.2. Web browser app, Silk, is a pain. I don't know how many people really use it to browse the web. It's slow, inefficient. even with its much larger screen, I still prefer browse on my iphone use chrome.3. Even the native kindle book reader app, is not as good as on iOS. Though amazon brag it's audio book sync function, but i don't find that much useful for me. To activate the dictionary, you need to pinpoint your finger right on the words very precisely, I often find myself trying two or three times before get the right words I want to touch. But using Kindle app on iOS, I never had this problem. Guess it's mostly due to the kindle fire operating system amazon stocked.4. Battery life is a pain as well. I didn't tested seriously, but in my impression, it's way worse than ipad2. I used ipad2 more than this kindle fire hd, but charge ipad2 less frequently.5. The audio quality is a selling point when Bezos introduce this kindle fire hd in the keynotes, but I have to say, when watching videos, I always felt the sound is too little and it feels like the sound goes away from me (rather than towards me). Speakers are on the back, maybe that's the reason. But why ipad2 doesn't give me this feeling? I am so confused.All in all, you get what you paid for. It's a very capable ebook reader, and a good device to access amazon's huge content in the cloud. But I won't recommend it if you want a full functional tablet.

Reviews.Title: WOW
Reviews.Author: Maimouse "MSC19"
Reviews.Content: Was looking for a replacement for my Galaxy Tablet which after 2 years is finally dying. However, the Verizon plan is expensive and I needed an alternative. as I use my Tablet for reading, GPS and occasional email, I looked into the Kindle. I figured let me just order it as I have a 30 day testing time to return it. I just fell in love. It is large but lightweight. They certainly mean HD as the images are crisper on this than a HD TV. Suffice to say I am keeping it and getting the great AT&T; promotional wireless pricing. I highly suggest this product!!

Reviews.Title: No Charging Option?
Reviews.Author: brijeffnel
Reviews.Content: I have the first Kindle Fire version and I like it a lot, so I decided to get the newest version for my mom for her birthday because she does not own a computer but would still like to explore the internet, download books, etc.  The unit itself looks nice and is easy to master, but I could not be more disappointed by the fact that it only came with a USB cable as a charging option.  My original Kindle Fire has a transformer that plugs into the wall, so I just assumed the newest version would have the same.  So my mom used the Kindle when she got home until the battery died but then had no way to charge it!!  She is not at all computer literate, so seeing just the USB cable meant nothing to her so she ended up going to Radio Shack to ask someone how to charge it.  I got the tablet specifically because it was easy to use and did not require computer skills to operate - so I was extremely disappointed to find out that the only option to charge it was on a computer if you didn't already have an adapter.  This is a pretty poor assumption on Amazon's part - I realize most households own a computer, but to sell a product without an option to charge it out of the box is ridiculous.

Reviews.Title: I want access to google play
Reviews.Author: Jason Brooks
Reviews.Content: The "Silk" browser that come with the Kindle is garbage. You can side load google chrome, but the process is tedious. This would be a five star product if Amazon would loosen up a bit, give us access to google play, and ship the product with a decent browser.  I bought the Kindle because I do most of my online business with Amazon. I'll continue to do business with them, even if I have access to a decent browser on my kindle. So Amazon, lighten up a bit, ok?

Reviews.Title: A review for the non-techies among us
Reviews.Author: Aidan Brookman
Reviews.Content: After reading so many asinine 1- and 2-star reviews, I thought I should go ahead and get my review out there. And before anyone has a chance to question it, though this is not a verified purchase, I DO own this device. My folks were kind enough to let me purchase this through my Dad's account, and pay him back over time. But anyhooooo, about the device...The first thing I noticed when I opened the box was how thin the Fire was! The original Fire, though I absolutely love mine, was rather blocky. My new baby was charged up, so I turned it on and checked out the picture. Absolutely freaking beautiful! Before I really played with it, I plugged it in and charged it up. No, a charger was not included with it. But I READ the product description and knew that, so I had already ordered the quick charger, even though I already had other chargers.When it was pretty quickly charged, I got down to some serious playing. I have to admit that I am totally blown away by the beauty of the picture. I don't own any other HD devices, so I was not prepared for just how gorgeous the images would be. I was easily able to explore the Fire, as the quick tutorial explained what was needed to get started. I loaded a number of books, lots of music and apps, and some pictures. I am thrilled that this device can be loaded with my personal pictures. It was extremely easy to do through the cloud. And they look fantastic!I checked out the sound. Dang, Green Day and Pink sounded absolutely awesome coming through the Dolby speakers! No, it doesn't sound like a Bose sound system, but come on....this is a tablet. I think it sounds fabulous. Haven't tried it with headphones yet, but I will.I then played on the reading app. Love it! Though I do most of my reading on my Kindle Keyboard and Paperwhite, it will be very easy to read on this device. Everything was crisp and clear...I especially like the sepia background; it's very easy on the eyes.Now we come to the apps. No, not all of the apps I had on the original Fire would load onto the Fire HD. Nor did I expect them too. And I frankly don't care. If I want to play them, I'll play on the original Fire. Rooting? Side loading? Huh? Nope, don't even want to attempt that. I'm very pleased with the content I can get for my device from Amazon. I bought this tablet for entertainment purposes. And I know as time goes by, more apps will be adapted to work for the Fire HD. The 8.9" screen makes such a huge difference when playing apps. I no longer worry about going blind playing Mahjong on my smaller screen!I then decided to check out some TV episodes I bought. Copper looks fantastic on the HD screen! I also checked a Prime movie - X-ray is such an awesome idea. No more going crazy trying to figure out who is playing a particular role; I just look it up without having to go to the web. Watching movies is truly a beautiful experience on the Fire HD. I haven't used HDMI (did I type that correctly?). I don't have an HD TV. Besides, I like to watch on my 8.9" screen.My Yahoo and Hotmail e-mail accounts were easily set up. I like the e-mail app on the Fire HD better than the one on the original Fire. I went to the browser and put my favorite websites on and bookmarked them. This device is much faster than the Fire. I will admit that the browser locked up and reset a few times. I'm using a stylus, and sometimes I tap more than I should (which I did on the original Fire because I had to). I'm getting used to the screen, though, and it's happening less as time goes by. And I have had tabs not respond; but they recover so quickly, it's a total non-issue for me.I believe Amazon Prime is a MUST if you own this device. Besides the free shipping on millions of items, you WILL want the free Prime TV shows and movies to get the most out of your Fire HD.I highly recommend the Fire HD 8.9" 32GB with no hesitation whatsoever. I mentioned some of the asinine reviews I read and would like to touch on a few points. If you read the product description, you will know what this device can and cannot do. Unless you live under a rock, I don't know how anyone doesn't know that Adobe no longer supports flash and is no longer used on new android devices. And I can't say I know absolutely for sure what flash is, but I know I don't miss it! Same goes for the device not coming with a charger; it's not listed in what comes in the box, and it has been discussed here more than once.. Someone said his Fire HD had sharp edges. Eh? Still trying to figure that one out! The edges of mine are very nicely rounded, thank you very much. There's no forward facing camera! Call me crazy, but if I want to take pictures, I use a camera (or my cell phone if it's a "photo emergency"). Reviews have downgraded the device because of packaging or delivery times. Sorry, but what does that have to do with the performance of the device? There were also the reviews that were not reviews of the Fire HD, but were plugs for their favored Nook or Apple devices. Then there are the defectivebydesign mindless Zombie reviews. No comment. But my favorite bad review was the guy who couldn't stand touchscreen devices. Then why the heck did you order one that you KNEW was a touchscreen device?!?!?!Get one of these babies for yourself and check it out. I think you'll love yours as much as I love mine!

Reviews.Title: Ahhh Yiss
Reviews.Author: Princess Luna
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent improvement upon Amazon's Generation 1 Kindle Fire. I ordered the 8.9" after my original Kindle messed up in a major way. Before I go into the details about this product, I must give a shout-out to Amazon's customer service team for the excellent way they treated me when my first Kindle messed up. It was almost out of warranty, but they still sent me this particular item at a deep discount. They were very polite about everything, and I got it 2 days later. I am now a loyal Amazon customer.This particular Kindle's screen is bigger and clearer, it has dual speakers on the back, and comes with the option of turning on Dolby Digital Stereo from the Kindle screen's menu. It has volume controls on the side which enable you to change the volume in a hurry if need be or if you don't want to mess up your viewing experience with the drop-down volume screen. By the way, it appears to sound better when laid on a table than when it is being held up. It has dual plug-in ports: an hdmi port and a charger port. The problem I have with this is that they are very similar looking in size. One is just slightly bigger than the other. So please be careful when plugging it into the charger and make sure you use the right one. Overall I am really satisfied with this product.As to small details having to do with customization, the only drawbacks are that this particular model does not support Go Launcher or allow wallpaper apps to work. ADW launcher works just fine however, if you don't care for the carousel-style screen and want something even more tablet-like. It is a bit more delicate than the original first generation so I would be careful about letting a child play around with it. If you have a child and want to get them their first real tablet, I would go with the original 7" Kindle 1st generation. It just seems to be more durable and thicker and seems to be up to the task of being treated slightly rough.

Reviews.Title: Life after Ipad
Reviews.Author: Lostie4ever
Reviews.Content: I have had a 1st gen Ipad since it came out and loved it. I did not like the fact that being only roughly 4 yrs old Apple has decided not to support it anymore with ios updates. This will eventually make my apps worthless as some already were becoming because they required the newer ios.With that said, I decided to look into the Kindle Fire HD 32gb. What I discovered was that it did everything that I previously used my Ipad for. Sure the App store is more limited but the trade off for me anyway was getting a Prime membership so I could use the instant movies/TV shows, borrow a free book a month and upgraded shipping. I really like being able to stream shows while I ride my exercise bike and the Kindle does a fantastic job of that.The other consideration was the Kindle Fire HD has a way better price point. I just could not see spending so much money again for an Ipad that might one day in the near future not be supported again and become nothing but a paper weight.I'm impressed with the picture quality. Streaming works flawlessly. Apps work great. Speakers sound good and produce enough volume. Syncing your Kindle with new Apps or updates is easy and learning how to use it was simple and straight forward.Cons: Battery life seems short. I've improved it some by reducing the screen brightness. Charging is really slow. I am using a 5w charger. Maybe I'll give the 9w Amazon charger a try to see if that speeds it up a bit. 19.99 seems overpriced though.I do miss being able to customize my lock screen and other screens. Oh well, not really a big deal. I did not pay the 15.00 to remove the Ads. They really are not intrusive so I will save the money.Again, the App store being limited is a con. So you need to consider that and look over Amazon's App store to decide if you can live with that. I also think the App store needs more Apps that are made for Kindle Fire HD and not just Android phones. Hopefully it will continue to grow!Suggestion: If you are looking for a cover for your Kindle try the one Amazon makes. I just got mine and it is well made, slim and works well doing the auto on/off. You can also easily fold the cover back and it is still slim in your hands. For me, this was important because I read a lot of books and I did not want a bulky cover.Bottom line: I love my Kindle Fire HD 8.9! I have no regrets and highly recommend it for people who use a tablet similar to me.

Reviews.Title: Great for books; okay for movies; browser improved but just okay
Reviews.Author: MaxStryker77
Reviews.Content: This review is edited as of 8/23/13 with respect to the Silk browser, which was recently updated.  My experience with the updated Silk is much better.  It hasn't crashed once and it seems considerably faster.  Since I purchased the Kindle a few months ago, I have gotten more familiar with the web interface, but it still isn't as intuitive to use as those on my Android phone  or iPod browser. I changed my rating from 2 to 3 stars based on the updated Silk software. I would probably give it 3 1/2 stars as I really enjoy the tablet, but I only use it for a few things.  I don't use it for emails or web browsing as much as I would like since it's not completely user friendly, but at least it doesn't crash anymore.My original review follows:I bought a certified Kindle HD 8.9 with expectations that I would be using it primarily for watching movies and TV shows.  I should preface my critique by admitting that I'm a huge Amazon fan (and stockholder), and take a neutral stance when it comes to product reviews.  With that, I feel the Kindle HD 8.9 is a very flawed product, especially with respect to its software and interface.I have pretty much given up using the Silk web browser, as it freezes continually. My ipod touch and android phone work more reliably than the Kindle for browsing.  Further, it seems  Silk is much more invasive when it comes to tracking activities, e.g., "Individual Website Data" settings are difficult to view and clear.  I certainly would avoid doing any financial transactions with Silk (note: I'm not a tech head, so perhaps others may find an easy work-around, but Silk just "feels" less secure than surfing on Chrome or Safari).The screen and sound are top-notch, and while Amazon over-hypes the quality of sound, it is clear and amplifies more than other tablets. Hi-fidelity it is not, but that's appropriate given the size of the device.  The screen isn't as vibrant as an Apple screen, but it is ample for viewing almost everything.  For photographers viewing pictures, note that the Kindle screen doesn't have a neutral white balance.  Pics are sharp and vibrant, but color accuracy is off a bit- biased slightly to a green hue (on min, at least).Books looks great, but the device is a bit heavy (especially with a cover) for hand holding for any length of time.I requested a return on the item after experiencing stunningly bad web surfing, but begrudgingly decided to keep it due to the relative positive book and movie viewing experience.  Early May, Amazon said their web developers were working on fixing the issues with their Silk browser in the "next few weeks," but I haven't noticed any improvement as of 6/20/13.If I had a do-over, I think I would have chosen a Nexus, Samsung or Apple Mini, but given the reasonable refurbished price for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 and its capable book and movie delivery, I'm semi-content for now.Last, the "Ad" version seems very user friendly - I don't find it annoying at all; in fact I hardly notice it, so I would delay spending an additional $15 to remove the ads when purchasing, and remove it later if you find it obtrusive.

Reviews.Title: Love my Refurbished Kindle Fire HD 8.9"  with data package
Reviews.Author: SCRN soccer mom "soccer mom"
Reviews.Content: I originally ordered a refurbished Kindle Fire HD 8.9" wifi only and it was great but decided I really wanted to be able to use it anytime, anywhere.  I returned it with no hassle at all, and then ordered a refurbished one with the data package.  I love love love it.  I did not want an iPad and I do not care for iTunes.  (We have an iPad and 3 iPod touches).  I do most of my browsing etc through Amazon so it made perfect sense to go that route.  I have the Amazon Prime which is fantastic for instantly downloading music, videos, books, etc.  The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" has many features I haven't even used yet, but so far I am very excited and really, really enjoying it.  I saved a bundle by going with a refurbished one - it has the same warranty as a new one - and access to everything I need it for.  If you are looking for a user-friendly tablet that is a great price, seriously consider the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" with the data package.  Amazon does a great job of comparing this device vs. the iPad, and for me, this was not only the better deal, but also suits my needs perfectly.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Grandma Zona "Grandma Zona"
Reviews.Content: I had a first generation Kindle (bought in the first couple of months it was out) and finally traded up to a Kindle Fire. It's easy to use and the backlight when reading isn't a problem. It is a little heavy, but works fine if it's propped on something. There has to be an available WiFi close by that you can log in to if you want to use the browser or download books. I must admit I got spoiled with the first gen one in being able to download books anywhere. The color is fantastic, and the brightness can be adjusted as necessary. I haven't needed to change the font size since the default works fine for me. Battery life is great - I mostly use it for reading right now - even using the browser. Recharging is easy once I figured out how to plug in the charger - there are two ports that look similar. I have had this for barely a month, so I'm still trying out stuff, but I would highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: I love my new Kindle Fire HD 8.9" and take it everywhere! (for the over 65 group)
Reviews.Author: Barbara Lynard
Reviews.Content: I'm in the "over 65" group so probably use my Kindle for different applications than the younger folks but I wouldn't be without it.  I not only read books on it I use many of the apps available for games, weather and news.  I've downloaded many recipes and cookbooks on it and it's handy to have with me in the kitchen when I need it.  We have a house at the beach and I take it there with me when we travel as it so much more convenient than dragging along my laptop.  I especially love to watch movies on it and the quality of both the picture and the sounds is amazing.  I actually have 2 Kindles...one of the older, smaller ones plus this new one so I can have one charging as I'm using the other one.The only complaints I have are for some of the buttons/functions.  I had a hard time seeing and finding the off/on button plus the volume button as they are recessed into the side of the Kindle plus being black the disappear for me.  I bought a case to use with my Kindle which makes it much easier to use as it turns on/off when I open and close the case plus the buttons are much easier to see on the case as it's a lighter color.I don't like the charge port being on the bottom of the unit as when I'm watching movies I like to keep it charging and the cord at the bottom gets in the way.  Would be much more practical being on the side like the older Kindle.Other than those little inconveniences I love the Kindle and it goes everywhere with me.  Recommend it to older, retired folks!

Reviews.Title: "Game Changer!"
Reviews.Author: Book Glutton
Reviews.Content: I had an original Kindle Fire, Full Color 7" Multi-touch Display, Wi-Fi. I received it as a gift. I used it occasionally. I knew someone more interested in it than I was. Yet, I was not willing to give it up until I looked into this HD 8.9" model. I really liked what I saw. From the day it arrived, I have gone nowhere without it. It has become such an integral part of how I do things. It has been the tool I did not know I was looking for. It's like carrying a personal office manager, research library, on-the-go resource environs, all your leisure time beneficial stuff, an audio & visual entertainment center, and more. Bring your Microsoft Word and Excel work with you. For this, there is OfficeSuite Professional 7 and other apps. Let your Kindle become your "note-catcher!" Do even more with Evernote. What PDF files do you like to keep handy? "Send-to-Kindle" those articles, memos, and other snips that cross your desk each day to read later. No longer let them pile up on your desk. Be overwhelmed at how DejaOffice can synchronize and simplify your office, laptop, and home computer calendars, contacts, notes and tasks (I gave up working with Outlook.com). You too will love doing all you calendar work, etc. on Kindle. Do your email. Text! Let WeatherBug for Kindle Fire check the weather. Get your news. Watch the Markets. Organize your Spiritual Life. Carry meditations and other prayers, or services like iBreviary or subscribe to Divine Office - Liturgy of the Hours Audio & Text Catholic Christian Prayer. Read the Bible, it's easy and cheap: Bible: New American Bible, Revised Edition 2011 (never mind all the rest that you can read). Carry your scholarly resources. Enhance your office with the New Oxford American Dictionary. Read the Classics! Write! Read audiobooks. Carry plenty of them for trips. There's 32GB. Use Bluetooth to make use of this in your car, with your home stereo, your desktop, or with a great headset (my favorite, for years, has been the Plantronics Pulsar 590 Bluetooth Stereo Headset) -- you can even pair a full-size Bluetooth keyboard. Of course, there's the Web! And surprisingly, this is all done with WiFi and not a subscription to a 4G network. You can also have the convenience of having complete wireless access to your Kindle via WiFi File Explorer PRO.Surprisingly, this is what I have been doing with the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" Tablet in less than 4 weeks and it feels like I'm just getting started. It really is a "Game Changer!" Like me, you may not know what that means to you until you have one!

Reviews.Title: Visually impressive, in all other aspects markedly inferior to the Kindle DX
Reviews.Author: John A. Kuczma "RogueUlfric"
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is a comfortable mini-tablet sized e-reader with beautiful resolution and vibrant color.  It is easy on the eyes and displays even color text and photos flawlessly.  However, beyond that, it is a disaster.The means of navigating through a given book is slow and inexact, causing significant delays and frustration in finding any particular location in a publication.  Further, the only options for listing the books on the Fire 8.9 are full color mini-covers of each book or a somewhat smaller 'list' format that displays the books in small horizontal bars with an image of the front cover and a text description of title and author.  In either case, it is necessary to physically scroll through the titles (which are arranged alphabetically) to find any specific book.Once a book has been located, navigating within the book is equally slow and frustrating.  One must basically use a tedious scrolling through each individual page by pulling a finger across the screen either from right to left or left to right dependent on which direction in the book one is moving.Further, there is no reasonable means of grouping books, as was available on the DX, either by category or author.  It is equally difficult to delete a book that one no longer wishes to maintain on the Fire 8.9.With some major revisions, this may one day be a superior electronic reader.  At the moment, however, it has a very, very long way to go.

Reviews.Title: New to the tablet world.
Reviews.Author: L. Horner
Reviews.Content: Although I'm new to the tablet world, I did a lot of research before purchasing the Kindle Fire 8.9 with 32G. I haven't been disappointed.  The picture is great, the sound is spectacular, and as I learn how to use it better I'm sure that new worlds will open up.  This is one Senior that embraces this new and wonderful technology.

Reviews.Title: love it!
Reviews.Author: Marilyn Martyna
Reviews.Content: My kids bought the Kindle Fire HD for me for Mother's Day. I love it! I was surprised how much heavier it is than my regular Kindle, will take some getting used to.

Reviews.Title: KINDLE FIRE HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: MIKE
Reviews.Content: I bought my wife the K-Fire "7" for Christmas but my 5-year old son and my sister-in-law took it over! So my wife ask me to get the new K-Fire HD 8.9 an although she's only had it for a day or so she can't seem to put it down! Also the "QQ-Tech Removable Detachable Wireless Bluetooth ABS Keyboard PU Leather" case is very stylish and functional and a steal for the price!

Reviews.Title: Works for me
Reviews.Author: Malcolm Nunes "gownupgeek"
Reviews.Content: My wife has and ipad and she put it down to take over my kindle for the first week I had it.  Can't add much to that.I will also congratulate the product development guys - the kindle HD got me to upgrade to amazon prime.  The extra content that I can view, and the HDMI out to my TV just made this well worth it.

Reviews.Title: Great Value but could be more functional for users
Reviews.Author: STLFRADTWEWRTPAPRG
Reviews.Content: We bought the Kindle Fire HD to have for the kids to use instead of the iPad and for the HDMI out to watch video on the TV.  On the positive side, it is a great value and operates smoothly.  The HDMI output to the TV is sharp, though sometimes experience slight delay in the video.  Disappointments include not being able to use Google apps like YouTube and in general the much smaller number of apps available vs the iPad.  Our kids still end up using the iPad most of the time due to being able to find more apps they want.  The Kindle Fire is definitely configured to ease your shopping needs with Amazon, but to take it to the next level, Amazon needs to give the user more freedom to use the device as they want.

Reviews.Title: Nothing special
Reviews.Author: john
Reviews.Content: Ive had the origanal kindle for a year now and this doesnt seem much different. The One negitive i find is the speakers do not live up to the hype. My cell phone sounds better.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: Bettye Isbell
Reviews.Content: Wow.  Now I know why this Kindle Fire is so great.  I had big problems with the first one thatI received and after receiving the replacement, it was so easy to add my wi-fi, facebook, email,etc that it almost scared me. I love reading and now I have something that I can take with meeverywhere (except the doctor's office where the wi-fi does not work). Thanks again for the great product!It arrived in perfect condition and I received it exactly on the date I was told it would be here! I am soexcited about having this Kindel that it is hard to put into words!  In fact, I love it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: I use my Kindle Fire HD more often than I use my laptop.
Reviews.Author: Marsha Holloway "Fast reader"
Reviews.Content: Since getting my Kindle Fire 8.9" 4G I very rarely turn on my laptop computer.  I can surf the net, read books, pay bills and generally do everything I would normally do on another computer.  And I can easily take it with me and use it anywhere.  I also like that I can take pictures with it.  I would like the camera lens to be on both sides so one could easily snap pictures of the kids performing in school or church plays.  However, after some trial and error, those events are recordable with the screen facing away from me.

Reviews.Title: E-Reader Great - Tablet Lacks A Workflow That Works for Me
Reviews.Author: Brian Moellers
Reviews.Content: I was going to avoid writing this because the fatal flaw in this is that I like to create a workflow on a device that works for me.For most normal people that just want a basic UI that they can adjust to, this is actually a great product.First, let me say that I knew this product had its own interface and that it differed from Android. I was okay with that, the main reason that I bought it was for reading technical software books that lose a lot if the code samples are not shown in color and on a larger screen. I still planned on reading my normal books (Physics and Sci-Fi/Fantasy - Yes I am a geek) on my Kindle Touch.The Kindle Fire works great for the purpose and my software books are wonderful to read in full color.The second reason that I purchased it was for the Amazon prime integration. I have prime and the lure of having the tablet play the free movies helped me go this route instead of a regular Android tablet with the Kindle App. Actually I was at first impressed with the quality of this and so were my coworkers. The trivia app is actually cool, but then I began to realize the only time I sit down and watch movies is when I am flying and have really never played with it again. I also found that there is an Android Prime application for the PS3 and so this feature became unimportant real quick. Still a beautiful feature if you are going to use it.So finally, why did I rate it as a mediocre product? Simple, as noted in the previous comments, I am a tech geek and a software developer. I don't think that the interface is bad for the basic user who is not someone like me where I take every device I have and make a workflow that works for me. However this device has no way to do this.An example: My Android Phone. On my phone I lay out my pages by how I use them such as a section for the calendar and a section for games. This is actually similar to the way the Kindle lays out its own pages. The difference is the "home" page. On the Kindle it is a non-useful scrolling of the applications in the order of last use. On my phone, the first thing that greats me is the weather for the day (as I am also a runner/biker/dog walker) and then my work email, personal email. On the Fire, I cannot display the weather but I can get an App for it, go to the apps page, and then load it and then it will be added to the list on the front page in front of my work email. Basically there is no way for the Kindle Fire to greet me with the information I require on first use. So I cannot use it for my daily needs, it becomes a reader.Even the pages that are like my normal workflow have no customization that I can easily find. In the apps, the order on the page is whatever the device decides so finding the weather app is not as easy as if I could put it at the top of the list.The final lack of customization is that you can view photos but you cannot change the screensavers. Okay I am being very picky but customization of the screen saver makes me feel like I own the product and makes the product easy to identify from others. Lay my Fire down with 10 others and I would not be able to identify it quickly at all without buying add ons.In the end I use this as an E-reader for texts that require color for more understanding. I use it maybe once a week since I busy with other work right now. Compare that to my phone which is almost hourly and my Kindle touch which I use to read at home to unwind daily, and this purchase may have not been the best for me. Perhaps a different customizable tablet with the E-Reader app would have been better.However for the general user that doesn't want to bother with the advanced features, I would probably have rated it at a four or a little higher but it just does not meet my life's workflow.

Reviews.Title: Buyers Remorse
Reviews.Author: dave
Reviews.Content: Overall it's good product, but I should have completed a little more research on the availability of certain apps I expected to be available on the Kindle.  I'm sure it's been addressed by hundreds of people by now, but if you are an Economist subscriber DO NOT expect to be able to read the Economist on your Kindle.  I don't know the details of why Amazon does this (probably to tether all customers to Amazon), but they have an Amazon special Economist program that cost about $10 a month.  Not a bad price for the magazine, but you have to pay for it even if you have a hard copy subscription.  For the extra cost you would be better off buying an iPad.  A little more expensive, but they have free Economist App for subscribers.  There are many other a little things I just expected to be able to download Yahoo sports apps, google maps, etc.  Otherwise technically seems to be a great tablet.  Movies are clear, sound is really impressive, etc.Before you buy it, take a moment to write down all the apps you currently use or think you would like to have access to on your tablet.  Then see if they are actually available on the Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Meh
Reviews.Author: Kiameshya Britt
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Kindle at the request of my employer for trade shows. I am already an iPad owner and if I have to compare the two, I think the iPad is much more user-friendly. The resolution is okay, but if you're looking for an all-purpose tablet, I would just fork over the extra bucks and get an iPad.

Reviews.Title: Ex Toshiba Thrive owner
Reviews.Author: Wilson
Reviews.Content: I am what you might call a tech geek, and having had 4 other tablets I must say I am very happy with this Kindle, the response time is amazing, the app selection is great and the Amazon prime availability is awesome, for $70.00 a year you can watch all kinds of new TV shows and older ones as well, and the movie selction is pretty good...I tottally recommend any one who wants a awesome tablet for a great price to get this one..............

Reviews.Title: It is Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Gwen Davis
Reviews.Content: I bought my 5 year old grandson one for Christmas and enjoyed playing it with him so I bought me one!  I love it!  It is easy to use and setup.  I use it for reading books, playing games, watching tv episodes and movies and checking email.  It is light weight, fits in my purse and I can connect it to wifi anywhere!
