Reviews.Title: Not for the visually impaired.
Reviews.Author: Gina M Rollin "Gina R."
Reviews.Content: For anyone who requires screen reading software don't let the "Accessability" of this product lead you on.  It does read some of the menus and you can navigate via a bluetooth keyboard, however be aware that any of the features that require web access are not supported by the Voice Guide system.  Some books are text tpo speech, but make sure what you buy has this feature enabled by the publisher.  If you need a screen reading system, save your cash and buy an iPad.  At least that has Voice designed to work with all features of the product.  It is nice to know the title of the song or book that you are selecting before it opens.  Note to Amazon:  Please train your associates about how the Accessability features on all your Kindle products work.  I hope this review helps anyone else who is looking at purchasing a Kind and has either low or no vision.Thank you.

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: fitegirl
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle Fire HD 8.9. I can watch movies, read books, hook it up to my tv, surf the web, check my email.  The picture is beautiful, great sound.  Easy navigation.  I dont even mind the offers that come up.  LOVE it.

Reviews.Title: Love my Kindle
Reviews.Author: Erica
Reviews.Content: It's great.  No complaints from me. If your not a techie person, like me, and all you want is to read a good book, watch a good show or movie, play some games, surf the net, and not spend a fortune on a device . . . then a kindle is perfect for you!

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: Dawna324
Reviews.Content: I love this Kindle Fire HD 8.9" better than the 7". So far I can't find anything wrong with it.

Reviews.Title: incredible!
Reviews.Author: LA
Reviews.Content: A friend recommended this product and WOW!  It;s really great! I've watched HBO, listened to Lady Gaga, downloaded great house music and lots more. I don't know what I'd do without it now.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful screen, good sound on Kindle Fire HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: Deborah McGraw
Reviews.Content: I just got this Kindle tablet a week ago so these are just first impressions.  I have a laptop but wanted something easy to carry around for Googling, checking my Gmail, looking at Facebook, and reading.  The Kindle Fire offers all of these things and is cheaper than an IPad so I took the plunge. Here is what I found for those activitiesGoogling - It comes with Bing as the default but I prefer Google (or at least I am most used to it).  It was easy to switch.GMail - This was where I had frustration.  There is a mail app that includes Gmail but I kep getting an error message.  I googled looking for reasons and got the idea that several people have the same problem but still no luck.  Yesterday I decided to try going into gmail by googling Gmail and used the login site.  I had to answer security questions because I was using a different "device" but once I did that, I was in.  Later, I tried the Gmail app and it worked just fine.Facebook - It is easy to get into and works but I am hoping to figure out how to change some of the settings.  As I scroll through the postings, I can't seem to get the movement just right to scroll when I want to and enlarge the pictures when I want to.  I figure as I get more used to touch screen, that will improve.All in all, I think it is working out well for what I want.  I am 71 and figure if I can use it so easily, anyone ca.

Reviews.Title: Ambivalent
Reviews.Author: Jennifer Webster
Reviews.Content: I waited a long time to buy a tablet, and when I finally did, I did a ton of research.  At the end of the day, I narrowed it down to the KIndle Fire HD and the Nexus 7.  I ended up buying this tablet first, but I ended up also buying the Nexus 7.There are things I love about the Kindle:For media consumption, particularly music and video, the experience is wonderful.  The screen is crisp and clear, and the sound is much much better than I've ever heard from a tablet.  In my own house or a hotel room, I don't necessarily want to have to have headphones in to watch a TV show.But there are a couple of key complaints:This thing is HEAVY.  Reading with it for more than a few minutes is not comfortable.The Amazon app store does have fewer apps than the Apple Store or Google Play, but this is not my biggest complaint.  My biggest complaint about the apps is that many apps that are free in other markets are not free on Amazon.  Even things like Instagram are not free on the Kindle.  So, cost of ownership for this tablet is higher than for other tablets, because the app costs are higher across the board.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 16 GB
Reviews.Author: Duffy
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9" is a welcomed improvement over the original Kindle Fire since it includes the possibility of viewing streaming video on HD television sets supporting HDMI.  Of course, there are may other improvements including the availability of a fast battery charger and longer lasting battery charge.  While the video and audio quality were excellent, my router's wireless signal strength was too weak for the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" to work in a reliable fashion on my HD set.  A wireless extender solved the signal strength problem.  Of course, the extender requires support from the Kindle Fire HD tablet.  Fortunately, the Kindle Fire HD tablet recognized the extender signal and walked me through the steps required to provide a secure wireless connection of the Kindle Fire HD to my HD television set. The trial Prime subscription service provided an excellent opportunity to test the performance of the Kindle Fire HD video and Dolby Audio signals. Samplings of the Murdock mysteries series confirmed the ability of the Kindle Fire HD to deliver a satisfactory picture and sound to the HD set. Duffy.

Reviews.Title: Lord, am I happy!!!
Reviews.Author: T. J. VanEtten
Reviews.Content: I was not sure what to expect fully until I tried this product myself.  I am overwhelmed with gratitude.  This is an excellent Kindle Fire and it looks like I can do just about everything I do on the computer.  The quality of the pictures and text is fantastic.  I'm still learning how to use everything but this makes me want to jump up and down with glee even though I am 69 years young!

Reviews.Title: Nice hardware, but the UI and App availability terrible
Reviews.Author: Ponnu
Reviews.Content: This is my second tablet. My first one was old generation IPAD (first release) and I just gave it to my wife and wanted to buy a cheaper one and ended up with this one. I am also a Prime member (that was one of the reasons to buy this device). To be honest, my old IPAD seems to perform better than this latest Kindle. I read a lot of PDF files, My IPAD beats this one down in that area. My old IPAD shows the first page of PDF file, if its a technical book, I know them by cover (first page). However in my kindle it all has same PDF icon and can not scroll more than few pages without seeing loading.. message.App availability- Initially I thought who wants all those unwanted Apps, but now after using for a week, I find there are nice apps which I regularly use are not availble for Kindle. I am not an Apple's fan,  but my next tablet probably be an IPAD. Wait..I do I still have this one. I am not saying its the worst tablet, its OK but not as good as an IPAD. And I need flash to watch my video

Reviews.Title: My 80 Year Cousin Loves It!
Reviews.Author: Pat W. Brown
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my 80 year old cousin who loves to read.  She had been haivng trouble using a PC but is flying on the Kindle.  I'l kinda of jealous - think I'll get one for myself.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9 can't be  beat
Reviews.Author: DNC
Reviews.Content: pros: "Everything" the wireless connection is great my router sets in the basement and I always get full bars.The sound is great two speakers are nice more than I can say for the third generation ipad I have the sound is much better than the Ipad and the wireless connection on my ipad has only one bar terrible connection compared with the Kindles.This is an Ipad killer for sure, I just put my Ipad on ebay I don't need it anymore I like the kindle 100 times better than the Ipad.Cons :My wife wants one now...

Reviews.Title: Perfect for our needs
Reviews.Author: Barb
Reviews.Content: We love this for so many reasons.  The HD display is brilliant, making watching videos a very enjoyable experience. The web browsing is fast.  The variety of apps available is also outstanding, even more so if you are a Prime member. The Audio is just amazing. When shopping for a tablet, I sampled the audio in a store and was just blown away.  It is clear, crisp, accurate.  I enjoy rising early on weekends and reading the paper (which I now do on the Kindle Fire HD) with jazz playing in the background.  One morning, my wife heard me from another room, and she thought the music was coming from a different source--an outstanding, and expensive, high tech name brand stereo itself--and was just as blown away as I was that first time I heard how nice it sounds. The kicker for purchasing this over other tablets?  The price! I definitely recommend this!

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD A Isolated  Red Headed Stepchild .
Reviews.Author: Croppled1
Reviews.Content: The multitude of reviews tell the story . Amazon designed the Fire HD to confine you to their system and limited storage to encourage subscribing to Amazon Prime for the cloud . You learn quickly any content there is lost if your subscription to prime lapses  . If your not open to that you more then likely should just buy a smart phone from Google ,  Microsoft's  Shadow RT , or at least a non modified Android entry .To say the makers of devices do not get along is a understatement . Google and Apple does not recognize the existence of the Kindle so you can't purchase from their ap store as a kindle owner nor are their conversion programs to convert them to useable . You can get around many of the shortcomings of the Kindle fire except for the lack of applications for which their is little motivation to write . Myself I believe the 7 inch model is the best deal as it is 1/3rd or less the price and you can use text to speech on books or increase the font size of print to solve the smaller screen size . Being able to just carry it on your belt or in a purse is priceless the 8.9 inch tablet really needs a 10.2 laptop case . I bought the one from case logic for $13 roughly and it fits the keyboard from Amazon basics perfectly  .You cannot upgrade the devices memory so buy as much as you can afford . I am so upset at myself for buying the 16gb model . It didn't take long to fill the memory up once you put on antivirus , some pictures , and video is a real resource hog . So far I have not learned how to add a flash drive . If I find a workaround for that I would be much more satisfied as I could free myself from the cloud . It was a nice find to use the Dolphin Browser for flash and Calibre on a desktop to download and rewrite books in the kindle format AZW3 .I hadn't read a book in years having bad eyes and suffering from severe chronic pain yet I took to it right away with the kindle . I wanted to use this while traveling but I now find my banks do not have applications that work with the kindle so it is merely a reader and video player limited to wifi though with Dolphin I can use the internet and purchase at most stores. I passed on the 4g since I saw how restrictive ATT was with a throttled data plan as well as expensive . Nothing short of the Sprint unlimited  plan would be acceptable for use . Someday someone will have satellite service you can plug in through the USB and I can't wait . Would be a great space for Hughs , Dish or even Garmin to enter . Would be nice if you could use a remote tuner just to access news and weather when off grid but so far I have not found a hint anything exists for that .So this is a nice machine but very limited and more for those who want to watch video where wifi exists and read lots of content of which not all is available for the machine  . Plan on using a small laptop bag or purse and not hanging this from your neck , or belt . Get ready to come up with endless work around's to become independent and if you use your device daily you will more then likely need to charge it nitely .That brings up another concern which is having to dock it to the micro usb port which are prone to wear out and or break contacts . I have had trouble since laptops were developed with charging connections on daily use machines . Paying cash to have them fixed is often 50% of the cost of the device . If the tech has changed you just scrap them .Well these are my thoughts outside what others have written or reinforcing issues previously discussed . Get ES Explorer , Dolphin ,Antivirus , Flash , plus Overdrive for library books with EPUB TO EWZ3 converter for kindle to read them with  Calibre for your desktop to download via usb and find free content . Take care will update after I have owned this for a while and learn more about work around's that are necessary and beneficial . I believe my next device will be a advanced smart phone with text to speech and banking abilities that works with Sprints unlimited data and access plans  . Very sad my institutions found designing apps for Amazons modified Kindle  OS not worthwhile but Google or Apple are covered . I wonder how the shadow rt devices will fair ? Though for those that use Fidelity Bank / Brokerage they do have a application that many speak very pleasantly about . That's a huge benefit for many who wish to use the tablet for day to day business when on the road and can control their fears over security at coffee shops , airports and other wifi hot spots away from home . Enjoy .Update : I think after trying the video content I can no longer complain about feeling like I am forced to join Amazon Prime . The truth is it is a great deal with the cloud . This device is sold very inexpensively and their is enough free content and applications available to keep one busy forever . This truly is a wonderful deal and is reintroducing me to reading on my terms . While wifi is not everywhere you can download content to view wherever you may be . My next mission to find a application that can download my newspapers while I sleep as it is docked charging . The possibilities are as endless as the kindle communities imagination . Oh and after trying Amazon Primes free video content I think I will cancel my Netflix . That will actually save me money and it is nice if you must stay at a hotel if they have wifi you can watch free amazon content . I opted to renew the prime though I do comparison shop before blindly committing to amazon for a purchase . It is hard to do but you have to be honest and figure in the cost of driving too and time for purchases elsewhere . The main problem is it is so easy to purchase items you do not organize your purchases as well as before since prime has no incentives to do so built in . I do like the add on items but wish it was easier to add something in as long as it hasn't shipped yet then delete then reorder taking a chance your previous item won't be sold to someone else or out of stock if you do . Still trying to learn how to print a document as well as write them on the Kindle . I think I need a class .

Reviews.Title: Even better than I'd hoped!
Reviews.Author: Induetime
Reviews.Content: I purchased a Kindle Fire when it was first released and was disappointed so I returned it.  When the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 became available, I decided to give the Fire another chance.  I'm happy that I did.  It is a great product.  I've encountered few, if any, problems.  The screen is as clear and sharp as any I've seen.  (I just installed my People magazine app and the magazine photos "pop" from the screen.)  The charger should have been included, as many have noted.  I bought the fast charge charger and it stopped working after a few charges.  Amazon shipped me a new one.  (Amazon customer service is great.  A lot of companies could learn from them.)  If you get the Kindle Fire HD 8.9, you should really get Amazon Prime.  The streaming is an amazing feature.  I don't know how they do it so well, but it's great.  And seeing an old favorite like "I Love Lucy" without cuts and commercials is a treat.  I don't regret, at all, my purchase of the Kindle Fire HD 8.9.

Reviews.Title: Love My Fire
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Denise"
Reviews.Content: This is my second fire, Initially I had the first kindle fire, which I now let my daughter use.  The only thing I can say about this that would begin to be negative is that I wish it had the back camera as well for taking photos with the device.  I also would like to be able to use a flash drive and put my documents on the device that way.  But this is a wonderful tablet.  I can print, read, watch movies, listen to music and so much more.  I would recommend this to anyone and everyone.  My daughter has her eyes on this device, but she will just have to wait awhile!

Reviews.Title: A good tablet as well as E-reader
Reviews.Author: Henry J
Reviews.Content: First off, the Kindle Fire is multimedia heaven. The screen is INSANELY high-res, with a pixel density just lower than that of the iPad's Retina display. The Dolby sound is no less than amazing. It's responsive, has low distortion, and is VERY loud. Don't buy a 60 inch plasma screen, huddle around this on movie night!The one thing that worries me is the camera. Amazon make you PAY to use it. However, ES File Manager allows you to access it without having to pay for something that should be included. (see below)DO NOT listen to the reviews saying "0MG T3RR18L3 T48L3T!!!1!" (OMG TERRIBLE TABLET!). This works well as an E-reader and a tablet. The Amazon Appstore is full of cool games for this and the other models of Kindle Fire.The storage can be HUGE. The 32GB model suits anyone nicely, as does the 16GB. It's actually very hard to fill.All in all, GREAT product.EDIT: I just noticed this review was posted on the 16GB, I have the 32. Oh well. I've used a 16GB anyways.EDIT EDIT: I'm going to hopefully replace my Fire HD with an HD X. This Fire is still going and works nicely, but I've noticed strange lag issues. It's rather old anyways and could stand to be replaced. NEVER FORGET! :PEDIT EDIT EDIT: The camera can be found in the Photos section, in one of the top corners.

Reviews.Title: Better than I expected
Reviews.Author: Todd McClintock
Reviews.Content: I went around and around looking,comparing, studying and fretting over which tablet to get. The best and obvious choice was the one I least expected. Since I already use Amazon for my mp3 s ,books etc. I went with the 8.9 kindle hd and purchased the Prime membership. I love it. watch movies, . play games, music email...I haven' t started my laptop since xmas!

Reviews.Title: This is the best thing that I ever bought for myself
Reviews.Author: Susan Molander
Reviews.Content: I recommend this for everyone. Amazon has all of the extra's and it is well worth its price.....I recommend everyone buy one now

Reviews.Title: Love my Kindle, but parents beware!
Reviews.Author: Emily Rivera
Reviews.Content: I have thoroughly enjoyed the kindle freetime app with my daughter, but recently came across a serious problem. She had swyped the top screen down and accessed the "exit freetime button." Then she touched the "reset to factory settings" link and then continued to do so. My daughter is three years old, so does not read and didn't know what she was doing. Yet, within seconds, she reset my kindle to factory settings erasing many important notes of mine and causing me additional hours of resetting up my apps and kindle for home and work.I would suggest that resetting to factory settings be password protected to prevent this from happening in the future. Freetime is a wonderful app and I would like her to continue using it without my supervision.

Reviews.Title: Great Value for the Money
Reviews.Author: Malinda
Reviews.Content: The Kindle Fire is a great product.  The resolution is wonderful and it does run a lot of apps.  The only problem I've encountered thus far is with Skype.  The audio works great, but the other party must download Skype for Kindle Fire.

Reviews.Title: SO FAR
Reviews.Author: Pamela
Reviews.Content: As stated in the subject line so far I am very pleased with my new HD Fire purchase....I am very capable as far as using software which I am familiar with but very cautious with any new software...my goal is to use any particular piece to it's fullest and thererore patienetly move forward and learn about said capabilities....I have found the help provided with the new "FIRE" most patient and accommodating.I am also becoming very excited with the latest "state of the art"  capabilities available to me through the new "KINDLE FIRE HD" I believe the price is most fair when compared to other devices and to date would recommend this as a very serious consideration to purchase.If in the futurue I find any real problems that I can attriubte to the actual device I will most certainly update my review.At the moment I am very excited (my 6 year old granddaughter is totally enthraled with the "FIRE") and am sooooo looking forward to the endless possibilities it may provide.

Reviews.Title: awesome
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey Hynes
Reviews.Content: Worked as expected, worth the money. Definitely worth the investment. I haven't had any issues with WiFi, even on my work network. Even my iPad friends are jealous

Reviews.Title: Awesome device
Reviews.Author: shayfurk
Reviews.Content: Being a technology addict, I have a number of different devices, such as a Nook, a smart phone, laptop, a couple of desktop pc's etc. After having this new Kindle Fire HD 8.9" only a couple days, I have to say that I'm impressed. I have a wifi router that is located in a large building, quite a distance from my office, and on a different floor. This device gets far better wifi reception than any other device that I own, including my laptop, smart phone, and Nook. At even this distance from the router, Netflix streaming is seamless, with no buffering at all. Web surfing, downloading apps etc. are also relatively quick. When I am closer to the router, speed is lightning fast. Graphics are very nice as well. I'm very happy with this purchase. About the only thing that I don't like is that every app that I use is automatically added to an onscreen carousel. I really like to keep an uncluttered screen, and manually removing these apps from the carousel is somewhat of a pain. There may be a way in settings to disable this feature, but if so, I haven't found it yet. I do like the favorites feature which is easy to use. Having this feature is a better way of accessing what I want quickly and the carousel of recently used apps seems redundant. To me, it would be far better to only add things such as most recently read books to the carousel. That being my only complaint, I would definitely recommend this device to others

Reviews.Title: LOVE THIS KINDLE!!!!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Kat 65081
Reviews.Content: WOW Blown away by this Kindle,-  Kindle Fire HD 8.9", Dolby Audio, Dual-Band Wi-Fi, 16 GB - Includes Special Offers  ,  I have an Ipad and Love this so much better and so do the Grandkids, they are 31/2 and 5 yrs old.. SO had to get another for Christmas, took advantage of the $50 off yesterday :)...............  WE ARE HAPPY HAPPY!!!!

Reviews.Title: My Kindle Fire HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: R. Graves
Reviews.Content: I really like this kindle.  It is like having your desktop computer in your hands.  The picture is so clear and sound is awesome.

Reviews.Title: kindle fire
Reviews.Author: Norm
Reviews.Content: Love it! Use it everyday for my email, games, photos ....nice big screen and leather case fits perfect...just need hdmi cable.

Reviews.Title: Meets all expectations
Reviews.Author: F. Macli
Reviews.Content: Have used the HD 8.9 for three weeks and it has met my expectations. Vast improvement over Fire 1st gen. Only downside is the slow performance of the Silk web browser. Have side loaded the Dolphin browser to get around this issue. Hopefully future software update will address it.

Reviews.Title: my Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: Mary Lundrigan
Reviews.Content: I choose this one because i have the regular Kindle Fire and was very happy with it....I love the H. D. and the speakers are nice...Love to watch movies on it!!!I would recommend this to everyone! So easy to use the color is brilliant! You will love it...

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9"
Reviews.Author: march17
Reviews.Content: I am loving my new kindle.  I really like the bigger screen, and it is so nice and clear to look at.  I love it.

Reviews.Title: Very happy
Reviews.Author: Suzste
Reviews.Content: Much cheap cheaper than ipad. works as well as my friends ipad. I like the weight and size.  Love it

Reviews.Title: Tablet for the whole Family
Reviews.Author: Asiana
Reviews.Content: Perfect for the whole family specially the FreeTime function.  My 4-yr old loved it and don't want to play with his LeapPad anymore.  I can limit his game time, reading time,and video time without accessing my account.  The best part is I can limit the apps he can access and when he reached his time limit, it won't let him access them.The sound system is awesome, I played a couple of movies and the pictures are perfect.  So clear and vibrant and don't have to worry about battery life. Web browsing is not a problem, very fast.I actually bought one for my teenager as a Christmas gift. He has the original kindle fire and he's upgrading to the 8.9" HD.

Reviews.Title: YES
Reviews.Author: Nancy Sheehy
Reviews.Content: As a older Kindle owner.. I love the ebooks instead of paper bbooks for obvious reasons.. Preordered this one for my birthday present to me!  I ahve found very little to be disappointed from and so much to be so hapy about!  Not only can I read my books, but.. do so much more! I love the internet capabilities, the apps etc.. Did NOT like that I had to buy app for photos, cable for HDMI output and the regular plug in charger as I really think those items should be included.. However.. They do NOT detract from the fact That I LOVE THIS FIRE !  Really looking forward to some updates that may fix some little issues with some apps, but.. not tied to Apple chains and have all the great capabilities..  btw.. my free time has become so much fuller.. LOL

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Nancy A. Gregory
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle Fire HD.  I had an older version of Kindle Fire; and love this one so much more!

Reviews.Title: AT&T; Broadband
Reviews.Author: Becky Ogden "bpiggden"
Reviews.Content: My dad has purchased this for my mom for Christmas. He had it sent to my house so that I could have some apps loaded and it would be "straight out of the box" ready to go Christmas morning. How in the world do you get the broadband registered so that you can use it. I am beyond frustrated. He paid the $50 for a year of service and we can NOT get it to register. Can anyone help?? PLEASE!! I know Mom is going to LOVE it. Heck, I love playing with it. Luckily I have WIFI so that I CAN use it.

Reviews.Title: glare problems
Reviews.Author: tony
Reviews.Content: Really a great tablet. I just received it and already enjoy it  much but ... the glare is very annoying. I have not yet found any environment were glare and reflection did not interfere with image on the screen.

Reviews.Title: Almost Perfect
Reviews.Author: Angela Dino
Reviews.Content: Perfect for movies, books, surfing and shopping. I use Evernote to take notes easily with two thumbs. It's a great iPad substitute in my already overloaded back pack. My biggest gripe is that the Amazon Android store doesn't have all the apps that I use such as YouTube, Marvel Coming. I have to "side load" them from other stores. The other gripe I have is that pesky back button is too close to the delete key...I'm always pressing it accidentally when I try to correct my key entries.

Reviews.Title: I love It
Reviews.Author: Razan Abbass
Reviews.Content: Was surprised how much I liked it! Moved up from the old Kindle, and was worried about the brighter screen for reading, as I work on a computer for a living. Was thrilled to find that it doesn't bother my eyes at all! Am absolutely amazed at the quality for videos as well.

Reviews.Title: kindle fire Hd 8'9"
Reviews.Author: chris
Reviews.Content: I love my new kindle, I have the orginal, also love that,  But this was well worth the wait. The bigger screen is clear and crisp, great for watching movies and perfect  for reading books. not to big and not too small, its just right. The kindle does everything I need it to do and more.The only thing I would change , is to be able to personalize the lock screen.

Reviews.Title: kindle 4g lte is a great product but for price, wall charger should have been included
Reviews.Author: glory
Reviews.Content: Just received the 4gb lte model and for price paid, amazon should have included the wall charger! kindle weighs less than my ipad and will be my new travel companion.

Reviews.Title: excellent tablet
Reviews.Author: Joanne "Joanne"
Reviews.Content: I own the original Kindle Fire and just purchased the Kindle Fire 8.9.  It is a fine tablet with excellent sound and graphics.  The internet on the Kindle Fire 8.9 seems to handle going in several levels deeper much better than the original fire.  It has audio ability on books set up for this option.I had problems setting up my uncommon email address on this tablet, but it was easily solved by using the K-9 email app found on the Amazon site.

Reviews.Title: I am lovin this
Reviews.Author: Sandra
Reviews.Content: this is wonderful. I am like a kid with this. except I am a grandma. Love my movies and the fact that I can get my old black and white movies and books,games, everything !!!!

Reviews.Title: Loving my Kindle Fire HD 8.9"
Reviews.Author: Mary C. Eustace "Lover of Oldies"
Reviews.Content: So far, the best ever. So much better than my first Kindle. Does so much more. It will be much easier to take with me when I go away. It was very easy to download my books from my other Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire & Accessories
Reviews.Author: Lisa Agee
Reviews.Content: Great product!  I love ordering from Amazon.com.  Very prompt and very easy to locate products.  Reccomend this sight all the time!

Reviews.Title: great
Reviews.Author: Donna Sisson
Reviews.Content: this is a christmas gift for my son i am glad to know it is durable and strong easy to use and it also has the kids feature on it so you can choosd how long they stay on there

Reviews.Title: Great Great Great
Reviews.Author: R. Hamilton
Reviews.Content: I enjoy the larger display.  This is my third Kindle and have enjoyed them tremendously.  The larger screen and HD makes reading magizines easier to read.

Reviews.Title: A few Flaws
Reviews.Author: Swilli "Swilli"
Reviews.Content: Im sure no Pad is PERFECT! this is my first pad, it has a 1.5 ghz prosessor making it one of the Fastest pads on the planet! as i found, this thing is pretty darn fast! I Like the 8.9 kindle fire, i got a book allready started reading, i love how i can put it on talk and walk away and listen to the books!! that is awesome! also i love how it bookmarks and you can save certain sentences! this thing is aweeesommeee! of corse it is new so you might have to wait for a few apps like pogo and other certain apps but all in all i like it!! very nice little pad!

Reviews.Title: Nice Kindle ... crappy "computer" / tablet
Reviews.Author: J. Wegner
Reviews.Content: As a book reader this device is a 4 star.  It's not a 5 because my other two Kindles (an original and a recent model) display books just as well but they weigh a lot less and they don't rotate the image if I roll over in bed (yes, I know that the rotation can be locked.)As an Amazon movie viewer this is a 4.5 star.  The only weakness, as a personal movie viewer, is that the sound, although amazing for its size, is still a little weak in some cases. Maybe it deserves a 5 star but I may be feeling a little negative due to the other weaknesses.Then there is "Everything Else This Thing Is Supposed To Do."  Mostly 1 star.E-MAIL:  The built in capability for email handling is terrible.  I found an app which is workable for sending/receiving and since I'm fortunate enough to have a provider whose services include good sorting, folders, archiving, etc., that part is fixed.  However, wait until you try to "type" an email.  SWYPE is cool but gets really old, really fast.KEYBOARD:  Nah. The screen keyboard is for Twitter posts and IM -- not for anything remotely like notes, data entry, or anything that you might want to not have vanish when your finger accidentally brushes some spot on the screen.  Plus there is not workable copy/paste or search or any of the other rudimentary text handling features that have been around since the Apple II and DOS 1.1  And, the prompted-word/auto-correct feature is good for several years of Facebook jokes: "Look what he typed!"By adding a Belkin Blue Tooth keyboard there is a bit more utility (I'm using it to type this) but that still doesn't give you CTRL feature capability that you're used to with any real computer and the select/copy/paste type functions are still pretty kludgy.BROWSER:  Oh, my blessed Flying Spaghetti Monster!  What a piece of crap.  The browsers coming out of the various university backrooms in the 1980's were more fully featured and stable than this thing.  I've spent a good bit of time looking and cannot find one that will load and run on this HD 8.9.  Wow ... and I "used to" do a fair amount of Internet work.  How do you invest all of the time and money into something like this machine and then load something as brain damaged as this browser into it?SOFTWARE:  There is none.  Zero.  Nada.  Oh, "Apps"?  You mean those games or pieces of pseudo-software that are featured on Amazon and on the online store? (which quite often tells you that "Your device is not compatible.")  First, everything that I've looked at is (to be polite) "snoopware," which might not quite qualify as malicious spyware but you have no way of knowing.  Almost everything I've looked at wants you to permit the app's creator to have full access to all of your data, contact lists, history, etc.  Everything on your machine.  That'll happen ... not.Word processor?  Nope.  Spread sheet?  Nope.  All the app review areas are full of people commenting on them being snoopware AND, THIS IS IMPORTANT, almost all of them require that you be in a spot with WIFI access while using them.  Other reviewers complain that trying to create or manipulate files for use on office machines either does not happen easily or at all.Come on Amazon.  I don't give a dip about free or $14.99 apps.  I've paid hundreds of dollars for real software and would pay that much for an "office suite" of software to make this book reader into a really useful part of my life.For the Facebook users out there, don't bother trying to use the app that comes with the brain damaged browser.  You'll put a bullet through your new Kindle.  There are apps available which make the experience a little better but, compared to any regular computer, it is still hard to live with.TOUCHSCREEN:  My touchscreen experience is fairly limited but this one seems to work as advertised.  The problem is ... to what end?  Selecting bits of screens or highlighting text is stupid with a touch screen. Gimme a mouse.  Zooming with finger tips?  Cute.  Not much better than with a mouse wheel.  Spinning the carousel?  Where's the utility vs., a desktop of icons?  Drilling through menus and lists?  I have to tap more than once, frequently.  I never ever had to click a mouse more than once to execute a selection.  Gimme a mouse, unless I'm standing up or on the go.  For my uses, that rarely happens.  Maybe I'm not part of the HD's target consumer base.OTHER STUFF:  Well, I didn't look at the specs well enough and had no idea that there is no provision for any type of direct data transfer, like an SD card slot.  Cripes, the little junk video cams from China have micro-SD slots.  They can't be that expensive. So, for us old fossils without blue tooth cameras and the latest of the latest phones, what are we supposed to use?  The USB slot?  Ssssslow.For something without a fan or a hard drive motor, the battery life sure isn't very impressive.  I get about 5-6 hours of simple online time -- NOT using intensive processor features.  My guess is that a streaming movie or heavy graphics game will eat it much faster.I guess I won't go on because there are so many other reviews that this may never be read by anyone.  Just close this out by saying that it's a nice Kindle but as a former netbook user, I wish I had my netbook back.Update September 2013:Well, I've given it well over 6 months now and none of my opinions above have changed.  If anything, I'm way more negative about touch screens than before.  I've become much more swype proficient and now use it for short twitter-length stuff but really think that swiping or thumb stabbing is stupid compared to keyboard use unless you're keyboard challenged and can't touch type.  Insofar as selections, edits, copy/paste and accurately moving around a computer environment, touchscreens are a cute novelty which has no place in serious work.  I guess if you've never worked a keyboard, keyboard shortcuts and a full featured cordless mouse then you might think a touch screen is pretty slick.  It is not.

Reviews.Title: Slow and clunky
Reviews.Author: A. G.
Reviews.Content: Its got a nice screen, but its slow and clunky, web browsing is a pain, can put third party android apps but they don't always work well. Also got the 250Mb per month data plan from ATT, but that doesn't work very well either and teh 4G LTE service is flaky at best in my area. Hence, this Kindle is lying around gathering dust while I continue to use my 3 year old iPAD, which doesn't even have a data plan. Waste of my money on all fronts withis Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Day 1...I'm hoping I can write a redeeming update in the days to come.
Reviews.Author: PeepToePrincess
Reviews.Content: First of all, I am a die hard Amazon fan. I have referred quite a few people to prime and convinced a few people that the kindle was the way to go for an awesome e-reader (I read outside a lot and the kindle can't be beat for that). So of course when I saw the student prime deal for $70 off the Kindle Fire 8.9" HD, I knew it was too good to pass up! I should point out that I have an iPhone 4 but I am in no way one of those people who thinks everything Apple is better just because it's Apple. Anyway, I setup my Kindle Fire and let it charge for a bit. Then I downloaded one app. I was hanging out with a couple of friends after work and during our discussion, I decided to search for something on the web...this was when I learned my "great deal" so great after all. I did one search using the laughable web app, silk. The app crashed multiple times, froze, and then I even got an auto reboot. I don't have anything on my Kindle yet and I can't even do a web search? Don't worry, I had my 3 year old iPhone to use. So there I was telling a group of people how excited I was about  my new Kindle Fire and they get to watch me put my frozen Kindle down to use my old iPhone to do a web search. On a lighter note, the ads aren't so bad...Update (9/11/13):  It's been a couple of weeks since I received my Kindle Fire HD 8.9" and well, it's ok.  I received an email today from Amazon regarding my review.  Basically, they responded to my horrible troubles with Silk by clearing the app data and then doing a device restart.  So, you're telling me that in order to get a brand new item to work properly, I should have cleared all of the app data and done a device restart when I received it (you know, brand new)?  Wow.  As far as the device goes, it's alright.  I have had some videos crash and it's not exactly the most user friendly (Sorry Amazon, you wanted to design something anti-Apple, and you did, but you neglected one of the most important things that people love about Apple (being really user-friendly)).  I don't hate the device like I did that first day, but I can't say I love it either.  I've updated my review from a 1 star to a 3 star because of this.

Reviews.Title: GREAT!
Reviews.Author: Lori Jo
Reviews.Content: Loving this "new baby" - simple learning curve - my only other "device" is the Kindle 3 (keyboard reader) - I waited for this generation and pre-ordered - the only COMPLAINT I have is that U.P.S. delivered it to the wrong house and I had to go searching for it at 10:00 p.m. on the day it said "delivered" - it was delivered to the same house number as mine but on a completely different street in our neighborhood that was nowhere near me - the resident had it, she actually accepted the delivery earlier that day at 6:02 p.m., and then RELUCTANTLY handed it to me, I really feel like they were going to keep it, I was EXTREMELY UPSET.  This was obviously a U.P.S. mistake; but in addition, perhaps Amazon can stipulate "SIGNATURE REQUIRED" on expensive electronics with its shippers - I consider $100 and higher expensive, this item was $299.  Thank you!

Reviews.Title: Issues With New Fire HD
Reviews.Author: Loki Ryan "Loki"
Reviews.Content: I thought my apps from the Old Fire would work the same on the new Fire HD.  But I was wrong. Here are some problems:1. Documents to Go. Nolonger plays powerpoint PPS slideshow automatically. They have to be manually advanced.2. OfficeSuite: Plays powerpoint PPS slideshow slowly. A 4-sec interval slide advances after 20-30 secs.3. CineXplayer, Es Explorer Player nolonger play MOV & M4V. I have to download Movie Player VISTA to handle these files.4. The Built in Personal Video Player plays m4v too jerky to be useful, even though the sound is good. I wish there was a way to select which files it manages, so I don't have to see them on start up.5. No APP to manage built in camera. You either buy one, or use ES Explorer to access the system's built-in camera app.6. No light to indicate that the Fire HD is charging, and when it is complete. Not sure if I should always leave it plugged in?One would think it was a problem with the apps, but when multiple apps have similar problems, then it just might be a Kindle Fire HD issue.Overall I love this new Kindle Fire HD, and I am happy that I upgraded. I just don't have an easy way to play my powerpoint slides shows automatically without converting them to an mp4 format. I can't find any app that works on the Fire HD.

Reviews.Title: I LOVE MY KINDLE FIRE HD!!!
Reviews.Author: BBs Mama
Reviews.Content: OK, so I am not a tablet guru or anything, and I will admit that this is my first tablet.....but, after much research, I decided that the Kindle was for me.  I am pretty sure I have made the right decision.  It is ready to use right out of the box, just put your personal touches and you are ready to go.  It is very easy on my eyes, which was a concern for me.  The HD is wonderful! My whole family is addicted! I plan to buy one for my four-year-old for Christmas!

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: V. F. Taylor
Reviews.Content: My new Kindle is still charging but I was able to set it up before it was fully charged and was plugged in.  I love that it updated and set up with no effort on my part.  The screen and resolution is beautiful.  I know I will love this product.  I am a bit disappointed, though, that the camera is only front facing.  How are you supposed to take pictures of something else?  I would have liked a light that indicates that it is charging.  I was  having problems viewing some of the free videos that come with my Prime Membership.  The engineers worked on the problem and got it resolved.

Reviews.Title: No desktops No widgets
Reviews.Author: petrakis konstantinos
Reviews.Content: The worst menu on tablets ever. No desktops - No widgets. I'm not against the amazon dependance of the device but I can't accept that I cannot have desktops and widgets and the play store as alternative for applications.

Reviews.Title: Amazon Hits A Home Run!!
Reviews.Author: Gina Ladner
Reviews.Content: I wanted to start by saying this tablet meets all of my needs.  Of course, I researched this tablet when it was announced as well as read reviews after its release. This is my 4th Kindle.  I have had my new Kindle Fire for about a month now, and it is definitely a keeper.  I will touch on a few issues below that have been mentioned in other reviews.THE CHARGER (or lack thereof):  I knew from research that it would come only with a USB cord for charging.  I have other chargers (one for the original Kindle Fire) but opted to purchase the PowerFast Charger for the ½ off price of $9.99 which is an option for everyone who purchases this tablet through Amazon.  The location of the charging port on the device does not bother me because I can just turn it upside down while charging and watch a movie easily without it being in the way.FLASH PLAYER:  I’m not going to say much about this except that there is a work-around for this by downloading an older version of Flash.  Read the comments on other reviews for details.DESIGN:  Fabulous is all I can say.  It is just the right size, not too small, not too big.  Thin and lightweight.  I purchased the Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9 case for $54.99.  It has a low profile and I like that.  I also have one of those AmazonBasics Netbook Bag for 7 to 10 inch tablets with a handle.  It carries my Kindle 8.9 (in the case I mentioned above), USB charger, and PowerFast Charger, whenever I am traveling.PICTURE QUALITY:  Fantastic, sharp, crystal clear movies and shows.  The high definition is really obvious when compared to my original Kindle Fire.  A++ in this area, Amazon!!WiFi:  I had no problems setting up WiFi.  After inputting my router security code, it recognized it and connected immediately.  I tested streaming a movie in the opposite side of the house where the signal is the lowest.  When streaming a movie on Netflix on my ORIGINAL Kindle Fire, it would sometimes lag and show a “buffering” message, but on the NEW Kindle Fire HD 8.9, there was NO lag or slowdown of streaming the same movie.  Movies and shows stream seamlessly and I have no connection issues, even low signal areas.SOUND QUALITY:  Dolby sound is very nice as well, however, 90% of the time, I use headphones.CAMERA:  For my use, the camera is a nice add-on, but I don’t intend to take pictures with this camera, anyway.  I have an iPhone for that and with this Kindle HD 8.9, it has the ability to import your photos from other mobile devices (iPhone?) and Facebook or Twitter directly to your tablet.  Love that feature!  I would primarily use this camera for Skype, probably.4G LTE WIRELESS:  This seems to be a bit issue with a lot of folks.  I’ll admit that I was attracted to the $49 one-time fee for a year’s worth of 250MB/month 4G LTE Wireless coverage.  But I knew that 250MB would not be enough for me.  We have 3 iPhones in our family through AT&T.;  So I went to the AT&T; store with my Kindle.  I dropped my current family plan and changed to a Mobile Share Plan which gave me 10 gigs of data per month for 3 iPhones and 1 Kindle Fire Tablet.  My hubby and son don’t use much data at all, and I use maybe 3 gigs per month.  So, in my world, this is a win-win and I’m spending only about $30.00 more every month for 10 gigs of data.  As you may recall, the other options given on the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 during 4G setup were 3 gigs for $30 a month and 5 gigs for $50 a month.  I’m getting 10 gigs for $30 a month.  Thank you AT&T;!!!PRICE DIFFERENCE:  OK, stay with me on this......I compared the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 32 gig for $369 and the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 4G LTE Wireless for $499.  This is a difference of $130.  So you pay $130 more for the same high end, 32 gig model just to include the 4G LTE capability.  THEN, the average person signs up for the $49.99 for the first year 4G LTE Wireless for 250MB of data per month.  So you are paying $179.99 MORE for this Kindle Fire HD 8.9 4G LTE Wireless just to get this feature.Now, when you look on AT&T;’s site, to get a data plan for a tablet equal to 250MG per month, it normally cost the average person $14.99 a month for this data plan.  This amount times 12 months equals $179.88.  So, really, AT&T;, is getting their money in the long run because Amazon is probably forking over most, if not all, of the profit they receive selling the 4G LTE version of the tablet to AT&T.;  Amazon probably views this as an acceptable loss because they know that they will recoup this amount plus more when people purchase media from their website.  Of course, this is only speculation on my part, but, it does sound feasible, doesn’t it?So, in my opinion, this tablet exceeds my expectations.  NO disappointments, NO frustrations, and NOT a waste of money, as many would claim in the 1 star reviews.  You just have to know what YOU need in a tablet, and know WHAT you are buying.  This is a media consumption device, pure and simple.  It’s not meant for heavy duty productivity, spread sheets, etc.  I LOVE IT!!

Reviews.Title: Better than iPad
Reviews.Author: C. Stowe
Reviews.Content: This is great and easy to use. I think it is faster and easier to use than the iPad. Love it

Reviews.Title: Decent for what it's designed for
Reviews.Author: Paul Cohen
Reviews.Content: This is primarily an Amazon consumption device.  For that, it is GREAT.  I hav several devices.  Nexus 7, Galaxy Note 10.1, iPad 4, iPad Mini.  I get them for my review blog and to play.  Each one has a uniqueness I like about them.I got the Kindle to be primarily my video, book, magazine, music player while at home.  I have a Roku and Cable, but sometimes I want to chill in bed and consume some media.  I dont care about e-mail or other apps as I plan on using this at home as a multi-media type device.The screen is awesome.  I will match it up with my iPad 4 on most things concernign video.  The sound quality is better than all but the Galaxy Note 10.1 which has 2 front facing speakers!!Reading books is awesome on this thing.  Magazines are even better.  Movie play is great in HD and I can easily have my eyes on the screen for an entire movie and not get strained.It is not the "do everything" tablet you might need.  If, however, your MAIN objective is to be tied into the Amazon system, then this is a device worth looking at.  The screen size is perfect.  It's a little heavy, but still not too bad.

Reviews.Title: My new Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: garriott
Reviews.Content: It's a great tablet. I got the 12 month $49.95 AT&T; 4G plan. Works great and simple to use. I love It!!!!

Reviews.Title: HD in your hand
Reviews.Author: James B Cox
Reviews.Content: This is exactly what was advertised. The picture clarity exceeds expectations. I can not comment on the sound quality because of a hearing problem, but the volume is satisfactory.

Reviews.Title: exactly what I was looking for
Reviews.Author: tizgirl
Reviews.Content: I have previously owned several kindles, from the second generation kindle, kindle keyboard and kindle touch, plus the original kindle fire.  The only things I wasn't thrilled about the original kindle fire are fixed in this one - a larger screen available, 4G option, and other upgrades make it very worth the upgrade.  This new kindle fire is exactly what I was hoping it would be.  The screen is amazing, very responsive to touch.  As usual all of my previous amazon purchases (books, movies, aps and music) were easily downloaded from the cloud to the device.  And am thrilled to finally have access to 4G so I can take it with me more places.  I have an ipod touch and love it for something small, but if you use amazon and especially if you have amazon prime this tablet may be for you.  I will probably always prefer reading on my Kindle Touch, but for magazine, games, movies and internet this is a wonderful addition to the Kindle family.

Reviews.Title: My second Fire - still ambivalent -  update 4
Reviews.Author: dd9000
Reviews.Content: Kindle Fire HD 8.9 - 32 GBUpdate 4: more information about the keyboard, touch screen, appsN.B. This is written for people like me: your first tablet was the original Kindle Fire, and you are trying to decide if you should upgrade to the HD and, if so, whether you should go for the 7" or 8.9"  model.  I assume that you are familiar with the technical specifications (from Amazon, Amazon customers, or other review sites).This is a long review so here's the get-to-the chase summation:1. One cannot comfortably hold a tablet this size in one hand.  This will be obvious to anybody who has a large tablet but for newbies, or those used to a 7" model, the difference is much greater than one might have expected.2. If you decided to get a second Fire rather than one of the alternatives because you figure all your content will be there and you won't have to learn anything new, you will be disappointed.  Anything with a userid/password must be set up again (which would be true if you switched to a different vendor).  Only Amazon content is saved to its cloud.  So if you have books you downloaded from other sites, or applications you have side-loaded, you will have to do that by hand (also true if you change vendors, except you will have to recreate everything). And applications that ran fine on the original Fire may not run at all on the HD.  Also, there are enough differences between the interface on the HD and the original Fire that I think the learning curve is probably just as great as if, say, you switched to a Nexus.3. UPDATED:I thought the original Fire was the deal to end all deals.  It has its limitations but, for the price, I don't think there is a better bargain on the market.  The new HD models are another matter.  These cost "real" money, and I can't unequivocally recommend this tablet. But, I want to be clear here, this is not to say that the HD is a bad device.  It is, simply, that while I could excuse Amazon's pitiful App Store, and UI issues, for a device that cost me $200, I am not willing to excuse those deficiencies for a device that cost me $450 (plus tax).Background:The original Kindle Fire was my first tablet, and I was satisfied with it, in spite of some shortcomings, from Day 1.  I have rarely, if ever gotten so much bang for the buck with a tech purchase.  During election season, I and the Fire rarely parted company.So, why did I buy the HD 8.9 WiFi tablet?  Three reasons: First, although I've been very happy with the Fire, I've run out of application space (something that truly surprised me) and have been shuffling apps in and off the device.  And tablet technology generally has improved in the past year.So, why didn't I just get the 7" HD?  Because, second, after listening to iPad users assert for months (until the mini came out of course) that 7" tablets weren't "real" tablets, I wanted to try out a larger tablet.Third, I wanted to see if magazines, like The New Yorker, and web pages, would look better on a larger tablet. And it seemed to me to make sense to stick with Amazon on the theory that the learning curve would be short.Initial Reactions:After adding in the $15 to get rid of the ads and the $20 for the AC adapter, we're talking $400. Add in $55 for the Amazon cover, and we're up to $450. (See my review for the cover; I am not happy with it.)Is it fair to include these extra costs?  Yes.  According to Amazon, if you charge this tablet via your computer's USB, it will take 14 hours.  Right, 14 hrs.  The "fast" charger does the job in 5 hrs. (about half the battery life, 10 hrs., cited by Amazon.) But Amazon considers the "fast" charger to be an optional accessory?  It was excluded from the base price for the same reason that Amazon charges extra to get rid of the ads: to hit the price point it wanted to hit.  The AC adapter should have been part of the price.  As for the ads, I think Amazon should have offered the ads as a way to reduce the price rather than the other way round.UPDATE:I have had the 8.9" for 7 days now and I may update these remarks, but, in general, although I am not as disappointed as I was at the end of the first day, I am still not thrilled.  As I said before, my threshold for satisfaction re a $450+ device is higher than for a $199 device and perhaps it was too much to expect that I would love the 2nd generation product as much as the 1st generation product.Size:iPad owners are nuts.  A tablet this size is no doubt better for watching videos than a 7" tablet.  But it is only marginally better at displaying web pages. (I'll get to magazines in a moment.).  It feels heavier than the original Fire, but the main problem is simply the size, at least for somebody my size.  It is, quite simply, too big to hold comfortably with one hand, and if one needs two hands, well, then one has to make some kind of adjustment.  NOTE: I am not blaming Amazon.  I obviously knew I was getting a large tablet and bought a large tablet on purpose.  If you have a 7" tablet and are thinking of getting a larger size, I can't emphasize enough that the experience of holding a large tablet is very different from that of holding a smaller tablet. So think about how you use your tablet.  To read books, surf the web, watch videos?UPDATE:  With both Fires next to me (the original 7 inch and the new 8.9 inch) which one do I automatically reach for?  The 7 inch. It is simply way more comfortable to hold in one hand.  And I can throw it in a backpack or messenger bag to take with me.  If I keep the 8.9 inch, it will be for home use only.User Interface:Amazon does not make good use of the added real estate.  When you turn on the HD, you get the carousel, absent the physical representation (the icons sort of  "float" on the screen), on top of "suggestions" which change with the items on the carousel.  I found that annoying, so I turned off the "suggestions" in the Settings.I had assumed, naively, that with a larger screen, I would be able to see more items.  But Amazon chose to increase the size of the icons rather than use smaller ones to fit more on a screen.  This design decision exists throughout the software: books, videos, web, everything.  Amazon has simply increased the size of the icons so one doesn't get any more items per screen than on the 7".  The ones on the carousel, on the opening screen, are HUGE. If you have vision problems, you may appreciate this decision, but I wish Amazon would offer a resize option. UPDATE:  Under Bookmarks (Web section), you get 3 screens of 3 broad icons showing the top of your web pages.  On the original Fire,  you get 12 thumbnails showing about ¾ of the web page (bottom row shows about ½ of the web page).Amazon has also introduced a number of changes in the UI, from how to get to the settings, to the way you get to the home button, to the options in Silk - well, I could go on, but if your primary reason for buying a new model Fire is because you assume it will be easier than learning the interface for a different vendor's product - you are in for an unpleasant surprise.  Yes, vendors are always changing the UI, but I have yet to find a change that makes using the HD easier than using the original. So for me, so far, the changes come under the "why on earth did the vendor do this?" category.The most annoying change for me is the list of options at the top of the first screen.  They are, in order, Shop, Games, Apps, Books, Music, Videos, Newsstand, Audiobooks, Web, Photos, Docs.  Notice what the first is? Shop. And if you want to get to the Web, you have to swipe left because the first page display ends at Newsstand.  Yes, you can use the carousel or favorites to get where you want faster, but Amazon, please, pretty please, let us organize the sequence to match how we use the HD.UPDATE: The touch screen on the original Fire has always seemed to me to be way too sensitive.  Stuff launches, scrolls, etc. when I've barely breathed on an item.  The touch screen on the HD seems much less sensitive.  Sometimes I have to press quite hard for an action to occur.  No happy middle, I guess.Externalities:Others have mentioned that it is hard find and distinguish between the external volume and on/off button.  They are different sizes, however, so I think most people will get "trained" to recognize which is which.  Still I suspect we will always find ourselves running our fingers from the edge in because there is no way to "see" either button.  And since it is awfully easy to accidentally turn off the HD while you are feeling along the edge for the volume button, if you are right-handed and go in from that edge, it is probably wise to teach yourself to move in from the left edge for volume, right edge to turn off.  UPDATE: I am no longer accidentally turning the HD off, but I do still need to "search" carefully with my fingers to find the right button.There is no charging light (red/green), so the only way you know for sure that it is charging, or to see if it has finished charging, is to turn the Fire on, pull down to get the options, select more, choose device, get battery usage. Or get a battery monitor and make it a favorite.  This is just foolish beyond words.The USB and HDMI connectors are now in the middle of the long edge.  UPDATE: This was not a good idea.  First: you cannot reorient some games (this includes Angry Birds) in landscape mode.  And the position they like is the one with the USB connector on the bottom.  So you cannot play one of these games and recharge the HD at the same time.  I tried a video and it did re-orient itself properly but in Amazon's cover, the HD still can't be used while charging because of the way Amazon designed the "stand" part of the cover.  Also, I find it disconcerting to have the USB cable right where my hand is (vertical orientation, either side) when I am using the HD while it is charging.  With the original, which I always use "upside down", the cable is at the top so it doesn't matter whether the electrical outlet is to my left or right.  With the HD, it does matter.BooksThere is STILL no way to organize your books into genres.  You can only sort by name, title or most recent.  No doubt Amazon wants people who read a lot to spend $250 for the latest Paperwhite Kindle.  That's the only excuse I can think of for treating reading on the Fires differently than reading on the non-Fires.UPDATE: With Amazon's cover/stand, there is no way that I can find for charging the HD while reading if you want the book propped horizontally so you ccn read while lying on your side. (The cable gets squished.) And reading is also just far more comfortable with the 7 inch, which is pretty much the size of a largish paperback.Applications - UPDATED Nov. 25.A couple of the applications I depend on, like Dropbox and GoToApp (which I think is essential for anybody who has more than a dozen or so applications), did not work on the day I got the HD.  I was able to sideload Dropbox and SugarSync, which I prefer, is in the App Store. The paid version of GoToApp now works on the HD and I have bought it.  There are still other applications that don't work, but they matter much less to me.  Your experience may be better or worse.None of the Angry Birds games I bought (the original, Rio or Seasons) will run on the HD.  They do not even show up in the "cloud' when viewed from the HD.  In a way, this is irrelevant since Amazon doesn't save your games to the cloud.  So, even if you could downlad them, you'd have to start all over.  But it is still irritating to find out that games I paid for, and bought from Amazon, will not run on the HD.  (I have applications designed for Windows 95 that run under Windows 7 without change.)I haven't yet tried all my apps. To get them to your new device, you must download each and every one which, given the number of apps, and the speed of your WiFi/ISP connection, may take a while. And all of those downloads turn up on the carousel so then you will waste time deleting them from the carousel. This is a minor annoyance and one for which there is no good solution, so file it under "need to know/plan for".I sideloaded Firefox 14 but it simply crashes.  I have been able to install Dolphin and Opera but not Maxthon.  Why another browser?  Because Silk not only has its old flaws (like the lack of folders) but has a somewhat different interface.  And those bookmarks and history you've got?  Forget them.  There is no way to transfer either to a new Fire or to keep two Fires in sync.  Silk has also hung badly several times on the HD, something that rarely happened on the original.Amazon has created 3 sections for its Web access: Starter, Bookmarks and History.  You cannot set it so that, for example, Bookmarks or History is the first section.  Starter is the new screen that always pops up first if you're not going direct to a web page from the carousel.  And what does Starter consist of? 3 "shelves":  Most Visited, Trending Now, Selected Sites.  Because the icons on the shelves are HUGE, you can see only 2 ½.  Yes, that's right, in vertical mode you get to see 2 1/2 items (5 ½ in landscape mode).  There appears to be no way to set, for example, Bookmarks as your entry point, nor does there appear to be any way to get rid of the Trending and Selected Sites under Starter. These extra shelves may not bother you.  You may find them useful.  For me, they are a waste of screen real estate.  (And another example of Amazon's well-publicized policy of using the hardware to entice buying.)NOTE: I really, really, really do not like icons, especially very large icons,  I would much rather see just text whether I'm looking for a web site or a book or an application.  Just a simple text list that I can order the way I want. Nothing is worse than the way Amazon displays, in all versions of the Fire, videos which is, as far as I can tell, purely random.  It, quite frankly, hurts my eyes so much to keep scrolling dozens upon dozens of unorganized title icons that I usually give up after a couple of screens.  If you are looking for something specific, the search box works fine.  If you are just browsing, it's a pain.The New Yorker UPDATE Nov. 25: This was the most unpleasant surprise.  It works fine on my original Fire, contrary to the experience, I know, of many.  But I could not access it on the HD.  I suspected the problem was with the HD's autocorrect. Somebody should tell Amazon that userids and passwords often do not resemble real words.  My id and password for The New Yorker certainly do not, but Amazon's spellchecker kept "correcting" my entry and I wasn't even able to delete the incorrect characters.  I had to close the Sign In box and start over.  I finally got the spellchecker trained to accept my user name, but I suspect the reason that the app couldn't authorize me is that the spellchecker was somehow changing my password which consists of letters and numbers.  Finally, I went into More/Settings/Keyboard and turned off Auto-correction, Auto-capitalization, and Next word prediction.  Voila!  I was able to sign into the app.(UPDATE NOV. 26: The first New Yorker edition I downloaded, Dec. 3, was 255MB. More than twice as large as the largest edition I downloaded on the original Fire. The download for the original Fire was 165MB. I'm assuming/hoping the large size is due to the inclusion of an opera video clip.)NEW & UPDATED Nov. 26: KeyboardIf you are having any kind of trouble typing, I recommend that you try the same thing. "Next word prediction" seems to be particularly perverse.  For example, I wanted to type "A link" in Plume (Twitter client) and could not type the "l".  Literally, could. not. type. the "l". I turned off "next word prediction" and the problem disappeared.I don't know what kind of dictionary Amazon uses, but even with the original Fire, I have found that the words it knows are occasionally more obscure than the words it doesn't know, and that it seems deficient with respect to internet and other acronyms.The keyboard on the 8.9 HD is, of course, larger.  But there have ALSO been changes in the format.  The <-X (backspace) key now reads "Delete".  If you press and hold down the ",kb icon" key, the keyboard will split in two, which may be useful in landscape mode.  Press and hold again and the full keyboard will appear.  There are a number of other differences which, for the most part, I like but it does make typing a bit confusing since I use both tables (original and HD).Conclusion: UPDATED Nov. 25, 2012.Will I keep the 8.9" HD?  Yes, but I am still extremely ambivalent about it.  (In contrast, I liked the original Fire from the first day; within a week, it had become part of my life.) I have asked myself what I would do if I returned the HD.  Would I try the 7" HD? Or, say, the Nexus 7". I have part of the answer to that: I would not look for another large tablet.  The larger size is definitely better for watching videos, but I don't watch enough videos to make it worth the price. If I did, the larger size in addition to the improved video and sound quality would probably count more for me.Bezos emphasized the importance he placed on pricing a full-sized tablet right: the best features for the right amount of money.  It is time that he paid attention to the App Store which continues to be in a very, very distant 3rd place to Apple and Google, the need for synchronization (on demand) of bookmarks and browser history for people with multiple Fires, and ways for users to personalize/change the way the UI works.Musings which may not interest you:In short, I recommended the original Fire without hesitation to anybody who had never before used a tablet.  I stand by that recommendation.  But we are now into Generation 2 Amazon.  Our standards should be higher because the price is.  Assuming the only difference between the 7" HD and 8.5" HD is the size, would I recommend the 7"?  Probably, if it is somebody's first tablet and that person is an Amazon customer.  But otherwise, well, the playing field is more level now.  I'm not an Apple fan, to say the least, and don't want to be part of its ecosphere. But I'm beginning to think that, at these higher prices, Amazon's ecosphere imposes too many limits on the user so the tradeoff between price and functionality is much more complex. Especially for a second tablet.My original Fire works fine.  It's only real problem is the lack of application space, but I can get around that by keeping only the most important apps on the 7 inch, and running the others (the ones that work) on the HD.Finally, I've decided to postpone until next year any decision about getting a second 7 inch.  But I will not automatically choose a Fire.  This time I will take a good hard look at the 32 GB Nexus 7 inch.Bottom Line:If you take one thing away from this review, it should probably be the fact that the 8.9 HD has not convinced me to get a 7 inch Fire HD should I want upgraded features in a smaller package.

Reviews.Title: Open it to more Android Apps
Reviews.Author: Douglas D Snyder
Reviews.Content: great for video and music, good for reading, disappointing for web browsing and email.Biggest problem is the unavailability of so many popular, useful Android apps.Silk is a big let down. It simple doesn't function with a couple of my frequently used web sites. I have to go back to the phone for those.Edit: After several more weeks, I can only say that I wish I had spent more for an Ipad. It really seems that Amazon is working very hard to frustrate its users. The unavailability of apps continues to be a frustration as does the poor performance of Silk. When I really need something, it's back to the phone because I know the Fire is unreliable.I'm also very disappointed with Prime. The biggest complaint here is that none of the video is available for download. If I can rent (pay) for content and download it for viewing away from wifi... why can't I do the same with content from Prime? I've already paid for it beforehand with the subscription.The problem really isn't the Kindle Fire as a device. The problem is Amazon and their desire to strangle their product in its infancy.

Reviews.Title: I thought I wanted this, but I did not
Reviews.Author: BPM
Reviews.Content: I bought this initially because the price was right and I wanted a portable media device/reader/movie watcher...at least I thought I did.  The more I played with it, the more kept trying to figure out how to make it do more work related stuff than media stuff.  The screen is indeed beautiful but I felt the UI was laggy, sometimes "froze" a bit before catching up, but seemed friendly to navigate.  Once I started trying to figure out how to root it I realized that I was trying to make this something it is not, so I returned it.If you want to watch movies and read books this is the way to go.  However, I though the app store was lacking in the tools I usually use for work, which made me feel cheated in some way.  And the apps that did work were glitchy (facebook didn't work, flight sim game kept flipping over when it wasn't supposed to).  This was more APP problems than device problems, but clouded my interpretation of the experience.  Again, you can 'sideload' and all that jazz, but thought I didn't need the hastle and most of the apps I sideloaded were interfaced yet through another app, etc etc.The tablet is really cool but just did not serve my needs.  Wish it came with free previews of magazines and newspapers, as well as books.

Reviews.Title: Got it for the Whispersync
Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: My son is deaf with an Advanced Bionic Cochlear Implant and we have been reading novels together with audible.com books,  following the written word to the audible words so that he can train himself to listen to English and remember the pronunciation of words.  The whispersync function that hi-lites the words of the e-book as it is being read enables him to read novels all on his own and build up the memories of the pronunciation of the words.  It works great!  He connects his Cochlear implants Bluetooth to the reader and has the audible book pipe right into his CI's processor.

Reviews.Title: Frozen games
Reviews.Author: patricia mcgee
Reviews.Content: The games seem to freeze when you play it for more than 30 minutes.  It's very frustrating when you pay to play and then the game freezes.  Too bad you can't get a refund on those games b/c that's money down the drain.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD Review
Reviews.Author: Judy Miller
Reviews.Content: I really enjoy my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 tablet, the size is great for emails and games.  The size of the keyboard is actually advisable and useable with or without using cheater glasses.  The graphics are great and there seems to be an endless supply of free games.

Reviews.Title: kindle vs iPad
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: If you are deciding between a kindle fire and an iPad, I would choose the kindle every time. Having to deal with both support techs the kindle crew is hands down the BEST.

Reviews.Title: Awesome!
Reviews.Author: oktravelchick
Reviews.Content: My original Kindle Fire was getting rather used up and when this one was on sale (around Thanksgiving), I snatched it up! So glad I did! This is truly my favorite possession. I am either reading or playing games - some free, some paid. Amazon has plenty of each. The screen size is so much better than my old one (old was 7"), colors are bright and vivid. No ghosting during games. I did buy the adapter for accelerated charging, as the original plug seemed to take much longer than I wanted to wait.

Reviews.Title: Another Bezos Success Story
Reviews.Author: DIGITALSHOOTER "Canon5D-man"
Reviews.Content: The Kindle, regardless of which version you own, is a leap into the world of brilliant Technology and the very active & colorful brain of, Mr. Jeff Bezos...The Kindle is a device that has just begun to give back what it has been designed to do, which is so very little in the span of where it may be in just 5 short years. I find it to be somewhat frightening, for the unknown usually is a land that brings good & bad, but for sure, a land of the unexpected...What the Kindle offers to date, is an amazing array of educational & entertainment entities, combined with a plethora of Apps and communication objects, that are constantly evolving...It is one of the most important devices to come along, in the world of Tablets...

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: JenSom
Reviews.Content: I went back and forth between this and an iPad. I finally chose the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" and I love it. I use it every day for something from reading books to watching movies. I even found an app to make it useful at work! I was originally concerned that I went with the Wi-Fi only version. However, now that Verizon has made it easier to use our phones as HotSpots that is a little less of an issue. Simply put I totally love this product and am glad I chose it.

Reviews.Title: great
Reviews.Author: Jeff Rees
Reviews.Content: this is the 1st kindle I have ever owned. it is meeting all my expectations @ this time. im happy.

Reviews.Title: Good experience
Reviews.Author: cathy Prosser "Cathy"
Reviews.Content: Even though I have the very first Kindle, when it finally died, Amazon was very helpful and offered several options after determining my kindle was really done.

Reviews.Title: I am SOOOOOO Happy With My Very First Kindle!!
Reviews.Author: Kim T.
Reviews.Content: Patiently waited for a good deal and the time finally came to jump in and BUY!!  Easy to use, though re-furbished it looks new, works great, color good, fun to read books on, small enough to travel with, I could go on and on.  I'm pleased and love my beautiful Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Silk browser not good!
Reviews.Author: Everett Blake
Reviews.Content: My experience with the silk browser has been frustrating. This is my second review of the Kindle and my complaint is the same as it was before, Silk browser not good. With the exception of the browser every thing about amazon, the Kindle, customer service, etc has been wonderful.  But after contacting amazon the first time and getting a replacement Kindle because my first one had a problem with the browser freezing or suddenly stop functioning, again I'm experiencing the same problem, browser suddenly shutting down and getting the message that the browser suddenly stopped do you want to restore your settings? I will not be recommending this product to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HD 8.9
Reviews.Author: A. Jane Smith
Reviews.Content: I love this tablet! Beautiful clear image and very fast. I would recommend to anyone looking for a personal tablet.

Reviews.Title: Not great for college students, reading on the go
Reviews.Author: Jenjen
Reviews.Content: Background info: This is my second kindle fire. I originally used the first gen for quite a while before "upgrading" to the HD 8.9. I am a working professional, but I primarily use this tablet for college textbooks.II was excited when I received this kindle as a gift in Nov. 2013. I spend hours each week reading through textbooks, highlighting, and taking notes. The larger screen was greatly appealing to me b/c I do not exactly have the best eye sight.
